Updating my review because I need to say this...don't by the game if you like winning. Buy it because its fun. The game is challenging, you will die...a lot.

 playing with perks/potions/wands/ and spells will give you a plethora of possibilities on how to defeat enemies, survive the sometimes deadly environment, and navigate the world. 

the gold economy makes mining always seem worth it no matter how long it takes (with the right wand), and a high variety of enemies and stages will always feel like a whole new experience.

Don't touch the mods until you play vanilla for a while. Otherwise, in my completely biased opinion, you're cheating yourself out of a fun experience.

Only ONE thing that is irritating as hell about this game is that it randomly crashes. Sometimes I can play for hours without interruption, other times I can't play 15 minutes without it crashing multiple times. But that's really it.

TL;DR : Game very good, but crash sometime. Still worth it.

[b]Noita[/b] is an amazing 2D roguelike in a fully destructible physics simulation. Float around and blast dudes and kick their bodies off of cliffs. The game feels very sandbox, with nearly limitless ways to interact with the environment and a plethora of spells, but also countless ways to die in hilarious and embarssing ways due to how easy it is to cause utter chaos and devastation.

There are many, many video games that has magic as a mechanic, but the MAJORITY of the time this is more or less differently colored ranged weapons (think Skyrim). In tabletop settings, and in books/ shows/ movies, magic is often depicted as an unstable, barely controllable power that is unpredictable and dangerous. [b]Noita[/b] is one of the very few games that depicts this well (somewhat akin to the Magicka series). Within the levels, you will find new wands/ spells with which to mix and match in between each area, and you can create some STUPIDLY overpowered wands. Imagine shooting fireballs out of a wand at a fire rate of 50 per second, that level of insane, or shooting a tiny beam that creates 10 bombs whereever it hits, or teleporting through an entire level in an instant. The possibilities are endless and irrational and hilarious all at once.

Becaues of this random nature, [b]Noita[/b] can often be frustrating as you will likely die in unexpected and confusing ways, but you can't really take it personal. The sandbox, anything goes nature of the game is by design, and it's endlessly addicting for someone like me to constantly try and experiment and find out what new insane stuff I can get up to. Highly recommend this game! Also runs very well on the steam deck!

[h3]Imagine your dad gave you a car.[/h3]

He warned you that driving would be difficult and that you'd need to pay close attention in order to avoid bad stuff from happening. You get a few dents on the car as you are still learning your ways but that doesn't discorage you. You keep trying and trying and trying until you eventually start to enjoy driving, even with the hardships. On a fateful day, however, as you're driving and paying close attention, [b]a monster truck being driven by none other than your dad appears outta nowhere and crushes your vehicle with you inside[/b]. You die a gruesome death without even understanding why you got killed.

This happened to me in this game. But instead of a monster truck driven by my father it was a wand placed in a pedestal by the devs. I arrived at the [spoiler]Vault[/spoiler] biome, picked a wand, read through the spells' descriptions to make sure I don't die a stupid death and, upon casting a spell, [b]exploded my goofy ass into smithereens[/b]. I don't care if the wands are randomized: your tool shouldn't be an insta-kill to you. This problem becomes even worse when you consider the vagueness of some of the spells' descriptions. This isn't about learning the hard way, it's about dying and not learning anything.

This game isn't bad, but it is unfair ([spoiler]and in an unfun way[/spoiler]).

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Bought to check out the physik simulation, got addicted to a good rouge like.

pretty nice, recently beat the tutorial (killing the final boss). Loosing a long run is very painful, so the main downside of this game imo is that you can't play it for too long continuously without being demotivated. But I suppose that's a skill issue. Early game is a bit slow as wands are basic and you generally go for the same things each time, and as you find out more stuff to do near the beginning you end up extending that section to your own detriment, but ah well.
The particle physics are nice but pretty simple and don't interact with gameplay much. The main meat of it is in wand building, with you becoming progressively more dangerous to yourself as you make more destructive weapons, 'cause those are the ones that deal the most damage. A successful run seems like a cartoon ball of snow rolling down a mountain, my first victory ended with me having a wand devastating enough to kill everything I saw (including the final boss, and myself if I misfired) in one shot. You just build up your doom weapon as you go.

The world is very big, I've explored maybe a tenth of what exists despite having beaten the game. So there's a lot more in it to reach, though as a fairly new player the idea of even leaving the Main Path of the game and then surviving out there seems alien.

This Roguelike game has a very high variety in Wands, Spells, Enemies, Exploration and Biomes to make it really hard to ve stale after multiple runs. You always learn something new, adapt to whatever spells you got in each run and try to make it work as far as you can. Which most of the time, you won't until a couple deaths and runs were put in the game.

Environmental damage is very satisfy in this game, every liquids and vapors all react differently and blowing things up never got old here. You can drown enemies with careful planning, or even set them up to fall into lava pit. The game rewards creativity in this regard and that's just a one mechanic.

Wands and spells building are another part of the game that rewards your creativity. Making simple spell with trigger and timer to be more powerful by combining it with another spells and putting it in the right wand you found exploring is part of the challenge where you need to manage resource such as your health and trade it with exploration deeper and deeper into somewhere you are not familiar with.

Overall a very good game. Have patience, explore at your own pace. Death is a set back to be expected in this game but you can always get better, being more careful and manage your resources. Try to look this game as a survival where you need to decide when to push and when to call it a day and proceed to next resting point. You can always find a way to comeback to explore the beginning area again eventually.

It was only when I had played 274 hours did I get a run where I was collecting more orbs then I had ever before, exploring biomes I had never visited and through all that travelling at mach 3 with my teleport wand. 
Strangely, I ain't mad that it took so long. 
The whole Noita experience, from you being a weak little witch, to you becoming a god, are all incredibly fun and challenging in their own ways. Despite being ravaged several times due to RNG or simply my own incompetence, I always come back for more, for every single seed is unique and special in its own way.
I'm so glad that the Noita community exists, if it wasn't for them, I would've quit long ago. Seeing game-plays, tips and tricks, lore videos and so much more made me inspired to try my hardest and to achieve a god run. (I just wish I had that inspiration with fitness lmao)
Thanks to my online friend who recommended this game to me. I got to experience one of the best single player games of all time! :))

As there's no class or level and unlockables, Noita is not a mix between roguelike and roguelite. You die, you go back to the beginning with a simple wand with random basic spell and a glass of something.

Noita, this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game man! Honestly it's a game that relishes in your failure. So much time spent mastering spells and crafting the ultimate wand, all for nought. Just when you think you've conquered it, some random enemy blows you up, mocking the effort you've put in. It's infuriating, a cycle of build-up and sudden demise that leaves you open mouthed and thinking why you even bother.

AND I LOVE IT!! 

The very elements that drive me to despair – the unpredictability, the challenge, the sheer ridiculousness of it all – are what keep me coming back. It's a masterpiece of frustration and fun, a game that tests your patience only to reward you with a sense of achievement that's all too rare. Despite everything, or perhaps because of it, I love Noita. It's a beautifully infuriating experience that I can't seem to quit.

can't go wrong with overwhelmingly positive games...

This game takes a impossible premise and somehow made an amazing game with it 

Noita is a game that takes the spirit of roguelikes and throws it into a huge, open world, making it quite unique. In most roguelikes, you encounter walls that you can't break, and you just move on. But in Noita, everything is breakable, and experimenting with your surroundings can lead to both good and bad outcomes, which adds a magical touch to the barriers you face.

When you start playing, you might think it's just another cave dive, but there's so much more to discover, different areas, tough bosses, hidden items, and cryptic secrets. Figuring out everything the game has to offer is an incredibly welcoming surprise.

Noita is tough. It's just like your average roguelike however the game is massive, and while there's tons to do, surviving is no easy feat, even with this in mind the great graphics with the dynamic soundtrack makes fighting very enjoyable. For reference, the main route of the game, the cave you explore, is actually called the tutorial as a running joke by the players and devs.


Overall, it's a great game that's definitely earned a spot among my favorites.

Cons:
Your luck can make or break a run, and skill doesn't always count for much, especially in bad runs. This is typical for roguelikes, but Noita's bad runs can drag on, making it a bit of a time sink.

This luck-based aspect makes noita have rare highs, which actually made the game way too addicting

Super major con: finnish game studio

Noita=Life

Noita is one of the most fun and frustrating games I've ever played. It's challenging and at times unfair.

As a Roguelike, Noita relies on experience to be your teacher. The only real way to learn about the game is to keep going and interact with new enemies, spells, and environments. Most of these will kill you before you realize what happened. This leads to a typical gameplay loop, where the player will start a run, limp through the first two or three areas, and eventually die, forcing them to begin again.

But eventually, Noita will *click*. You will reach a point where the game makes sense, and you can gain power faster than your enemies do. You'll still die, to be sure, but it will no longer feel like it was inevitable. It will be a clear, sharp lesson, and retracing your progress won't be as much of a chore. And once you hit this stage, your first win is very likely to come soon.

But the biggest trick up Noita's sleave is this: beating the game is only the beginning. You might explore a bit and get a sense that the world is larger than the standard path you are intended to take down to the bottom, but just HOW BIG is something you cannot understand until much later. Noita's world is so massive that the main game occupies about 10% of it's map... and then you realize how far it goes beyond even that. It's a world of mysteries that no one player could have a hope of solving on their own (and even some that the community as a whole is still puzzling out years later).

The bottom line is that Noita isn't for everyone. The intense difficulty and time investment required to master it will turn most players off. But if you enjoy challenging gameplay that rewards clever thinking as much as fast reflexes, with a massive, mysterious world full of wonder and danger, Noita is unbeatable.

---REVIEW--- 7 hours
This looks like one of those games with a thousand hours worth of content.
---

---EDIT--- 157 hours 
I have now played this game for around 150 hours. I tried to really learn as many game mechanics and quirks as possible, and I must say that the skill ceiling for Noita is extremely high. There is always something to learn.

I am now at a point where I can relatively consistently win a run if my goal is to finish it. Don't listen to all those people who say that this game is too hard and that you will get killed by random and unpreventable things and get "noita'd." 99.99% of the time you die, it is a preventable death. There has been a death where my game crashed and reloaded my character into a wall of cursed rock, but that is truly a rarity.

Even if you get one-shot by an enemy outside of your screen or killed by a pixel of polymorph, I truly mean it when I say that all of those deaths can be prevented if you know what to look out and prepare for. Don't believe me? There is a win streak of over 200+ recorded wins in a row on Twitch (check the leaderboard on the Noita wiki.gg), and all of them are done in a reasonable amount of time.

This game is definitely a game where you need to rely on the knowledge of the community to truly master it. Wand crafting is so complex I am not joking when I say that you can write PhDs on it. There are still puzzles in the game that haven't been solved by anyone. Every run, I learn something new.
---

This game looks like fun, until you play it. 

Lots of really cool looking spells and areas to explore, all kinds of bosses, really neat physics and interactions. An insane amount of secrets and crazy objectives. But, hold on, before you get to see any of that, you get to die over and over again to random bullshit you couldn't possibly understand.

So get ready to be dead and confused.

No help is offered through the game itself, I don't believe anyone has ever finished, or played through any significant portion of this game without excessive use outside aid. Maybe it was easier to get into when the game was barely developed, but coming into it now seems quite insurmountable. I had a much easier time getting into Rim World, which is probably the most complicated game I've ever tried to learn.

Even after watching as many hours of videos as I've spent playing the game, I am no closer to understanding anything about it at all. In fact, I think I now know even less.

I'm guessing you have to spend at least 40 minutes to an hour just collecting gold on the first floor, while also getting extremely lucky with a powerful damage wand and a teleportation wand, in order to have any sort of chance at getting anywhere else. I only assume that because every tutorial video out there is someone with a crazy wand blowing everything up in sight while they teleport themselves all over the place at extreme speeds, while also having thousands more health and tens of thousands more gold than I've ever seen. All by the time they get to the ice caves.

No amount of skill or being good at video games will help you here. This game is about knowledge, luck and extreme patience I'm guessing. 

It is impossible to just pick this game up for fun.

You have to dedicate your very soul and existence to it.

Pass. 

Maybe some day i'll get curious and try again, Or maybe i'll just cheat until I understand every detail and nuance.

But until then, pass.

Update: I learned to git gud.

After spending at least 50 hours watching Youtube videos and Twitch streams about this ridiculous game, I learned enough to be successful. And I've got to say, this game is insane.

Even with a dozen or so victories now, and a handful of bosses slain, I have not even come close to beating this game. I'm not even sure i've actually played it at all. 

I'm actually still looking at the store page, is how little of the game I've actually played. 

It just keeps going. Once you understand how incredibly big the world is, compared to the dungeon you are guided towards, you'll poop. Go to google images, and search "noita map" and look at how big it actually is. Then, if you think that's big, go ahead and make your way through the cursed rock on the east or west side of the world. If you don't die, you'll end up in another world. And you can just keep going.

Your power potential in this game is practically unlimited, if you're wise enough and lucky enough to get there. 

Biggest tip for starting out, is to just cheat health. Watch some youtube tutorials on how to wrap spells, and how to heal. There aren't too many healing sources, but health is your most valuable resource by far.

Anyway, I hope we can all laugh about my initial review of this game.

Edit. The first version of this review is a rant about the vanilla version of the game, and I still stand by most of what I said there regarding that. On the other hand, I can absolutely recommend playing the game's mods. Not only are there plenty of QOL mods that solve many of the issues I talk about below, e.g. shop reroll, edit wands always, etc., there is loads more content you can play around with. Version 1 for vanilla
This game, although technically a masterpiece, is very mediocre, especially considered as a roguelike. Each area takes far too long, especially if you're trying to find good wands and spells. The environmental effects and alchemy and such are far too gimmicky, punishing, and ultimately shallow. Polymorph comes to mind especially. It usually takes too long to become powerful, and you usually jump from being completely defenseless to being practically invincible very quickly. The game is far too rng dependent. If you get the good spells, wands and perks early on, it's playable. Otherwise, I hope you enjoy torment. 
If Nolla sped up the gameplay loop, made resources much more plentiful (or at more reliably useful), and LET YOU EDIT WANDS ANYWHERE ALL OF THE TIME, this would be a much better game. Basically, if Noita was more like Risk of Rain, it would be a much better roguelike. 
On the other hand, Noita also pretends to be a metroidvania, although its areas are not remotely connected enough for that and the powerups unlocking new areas are either very specific, like All Seeing Eye or Black Hole, or non-existent, you can just walk in at any time. Their idea of exploration is literally just go farther horizontally or do  a stupid amount of backtracking and then go farther horizontally. The gameplay loop is either just press on like a normal roguelike or let the pacing grind to a halt as you waltz back to remote areas for stronger equipment, before you return to the normal path and just obliterate everything. The map design is ultimately terrible because they are trying to make the condition for unlocking new things dependent on what secrets you have deciphered. However, they completely through away the pacing of the game, especially the mid and late games, in order to achieve this. 
Finally, sandbox doesn't mix well with this kind of roguelike. If the game were much shorter and smaller, the combination would work quite well. But there is nothing worse than losing hours of progress to some mechanic that you hadn't encountered yet or that has no defense against it, like poly.

I got about 7 perks, but if you don't make yourself immune to everything, you'll die almost randomly just trying to explore. I hear mods somewhat help, but they should not be required. TL;DR: Amazing roguelike w/super deep systems. Throw yourself at the game until you learn the hard way and it will feel very satisfying when things start to click. 

Took 60 hours for me to win a run and I haven't even scratched the surface of how much content there is. Every aspect of this game has so much depth and care put into it, world gen, element interaction, wand building, and so much more. 

Part of me wishes they gave you at least a little guidance (like a map you can look at) aside from the glyphs in the beginning w/the controls, but the process of learning/becoming competent at navigating the world and its hazards is such a fun gameplay loop in itself that it's honestly not even necessary. 

There are tons of bosses that I haven't even encountered yet as they are hidden behind some puzzles that aren't the easiest to find/figure out/survive long enough to get to without looking it up, but it seems like you really shouldn't even try to go after them until you really know what you are doing. 

There are some good mods you can download for things like a mini map or even the ability to make save files if you want to make it easier while you are learning, but honestly throwing yourself into the deep end and trying to just figure it out is probably the best way to play imo. 

This game is one I will definitely come back to for years and years to come.

One of my favorite games, hands down.

Pros:
- Insanely deep, and a gigantic world.
- Every run can be different, or it can be directed towards the same goals.
- Very thorough wand crafting system

Cons:
- Unforgiving and difficult, can suddenly kill you in very unforeseen ways.
- There is nothing to help the player out, the whole game has to be either figured out or looked up. Mystery and exploration is all well and good, but there should still be room for intuitive gameplay.

[b]Brutally[/b] hard at first.  Grab some cheat workshop mods like [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2182627060]Edit Wands Always[/url] and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2076042167&searchtext=]Reduce Damage Taken[/url] so you can survive for more than 60 seconds, and work out what's going on.  (At least, that's what got [b]me[/b] over the hump.)
It's not "souls-like" hard, it's more like finding candy in the dirt in an alley, and eating it to find out whether it's candy, prilled ANFO, or thyroid medication.
You will probably also want precision aiming, so while gamepad "works", you'll be at a disavantage compared to mouse-and-keyboard.

If you play this game like a traditional roguelike, you will not have a good time. This game is ridiculously hard and frustrating, often killing you for things that aren't your fault.
Instead, play Noita like a sandbox game. The simulated pixels and ridiculous spells allow for great experimentation.
Get creative! Dying doesn't matter! Make a wand that kills you! Make a wand that kills everything! Set everything on fire! Hunt for secrets! Try to decipher the cryptic secret that you just found! Destroy everything! Fight a boss that kills you in two seconds! Cheese that boss with an overpowered spell combination! Download a mod that adds new enemies! Die to those enemies! Download a mod that explodes stuff! It doesn't matter! Noita is as fun as you allow it to be.

One of the best and somehow most frustrating game I've played. There is so much I could say about this game but I feel like I could never do it justice.

If you are going to buy this game, get ready to die. Then die again. And again and again and again. This game offers no helping hands and it feels everything, is out to get you. This is a constancy throughout the entire game; it's extremely challenging and everything is a lot more nuanced under the surface. There is so much to this game and should you buy it, I highly recommend looking up tutorials and explanations. Nothing is ever really taught to you except the fundamentals. But, the longer you play, the more you know; the more you know, the more powerful you are as a player. Slowly the world becomes your playground, challenges that completely overwhelmed you in the beginning are nothing more than a minor inconvenience. By the third stage, you have become an unstoppable god. Maybe you even beat the "final" boss, and complete the game. But you haven't even experienced a fraction of what this game has to offer. I have a almost 350 hours, a minuscule amount of time in the eyes of the community (and for good reason).

If you don't know how to handle losing hours of progress to a single mistake, you won't like Noita. 

I once had a nearly 3 hour long run where I had a super strong wand which shot 12 projectiles super accurately, each dealing over 40 damage. I was exploring in one of the later areas when I saw one of the wizard type enemies and started shooting at it (I had encountered a few of them before and they always have some weird mechanic that really screws with you, so I knew I wanted it dead.) turns out, that particular enemy swaps places with you upon taking damage. So I hit it with one 40 damage projectile, then swapped places with it and took the other 440 damage straight to the face and died instantly. 

The thing to take from this is: sometimes Noita is bullshit, what's important is that you remember that bullshit and never fall for it again. This game will utterly fuck with you at every turn. Pay attention to everything, because any slight mistake means it's right back to the beginning. 
It's the best rogue-like ever made, and I can't recommend it enough.

Noita exhibits an incredible physics based system that rewards experience based on trial and error. This is no game for the impatient type. If you have the patience to delve deep into this game, you'll find that there is much more to Noita than meets the eye. Each run is different: You'll be unfairly dying during your best and surviving on adrenaline through your worst. This is the kind of game that satisfies that late night gaming sort of mood. You shouldn't mourn your losses nor celebrate your small victories. The fun in this game is simply in enjoying the moment and finding a fine balance in the hand you're given while appreciating all that can come from an endlessly challenging game purely driven by RNG and pixel physics. I highly recommend it.

As a longtime player of Nethack, this hits everything I love about old-school roguelikes, which I never expected to find in an action platformer. It's incredibly complex, packed with mechanical depth that will both kill you (suddenly and frequently) and provide you with the tools to survive once you figure out how to handle them. It also seems to have some pretty intriguing lore...I say "seems" only because so far, not having even reached the final boss yet, I've only managed to find just a few clues here and there. At any rate, both the gameplay mechanics and the world you're put in offer endless opportunities for discovery and exploration. Discovery and exploration both punctuated and driven by dying in various ways, but I can appreciate a good old-fashioned YASD!

Calling this game huge is an understatement. The amount of spells, enemies, biomes and secrets (so many secrets) leaves you with so much to learn and discover, even if you have seen content of the game before. Took me 350 deaths to beat the game, and I wouldn't want it any other way.

Noita is a game. You can play it. If you like playing games, then play this one. However, this game probably has the steepest learning curve out of any rogue-like that I've ever played. Then again, I haven't played a lot of rogue-likes, but I am a fan of the genre.

The game is so deep, so rich with content, and it rewards (and punishes) your creativity and willingness to explore beyond what is shown to you. While dying means a complete restart, you do retain your knowledge. Knowledge of wands, enemies, key locations, interactions between different materials, and other niche knowledge will make your next run better. Sure, luck does play a part, and sometimes you get noita'd, but a good chunk of the game is under your control. How you build and use your wands makes a major difference, even the position of your spells can turn your wand from a peashooter into a machine gun.

Overall, if you're looking for a casual experience with short runs, this might not be the game for you. However, if you're willing to take the time and really learn the game for what it really is, you will sink your teeth into this and never let go. I'm currently in the longest run I've been in (~8 hours) and I'm just amazed by how much there is. There's still more I can do in that run. I can easily just fight the final boss and beat the game, but there's more for me to do.

Anyways, I've gotta finish that run.

Noita is a creative, if unbalanced, arcade roguelite about building custom wands with spells you find along the way. [b]You will die.[/b] Over and over and over. You'll build an overpowered wand, and then you will die again. Then you will decide if it's time for a fresh run or time to take a break. Just remember: failure is that thing we call not getting back up. Even with how frustrating it is, Noita is a TON of fun to learn the skill curve.  Nothing compares to obliterating everything in your path.

Noita is a game that makes you truly feel like a wizard, an incredible example of the magic (hah) that happens when a complex systems and simulation based engine is given structure and purpose.

If you ever played the "falling sands" games and wished there was more to do than mindless interaction, noita is a game that will entertain you for hours as you find new and exciting ways to destroy your enemies, your environment, and more often than not, yourself. It also offers a massive bounty of secrets to be unearthed by the intrepid magi, rewards and horrors alike await you in every dark and secluded corner of its world.

Noita is well made, but it does not respect your time.  AND It's not a roguelike in my opinion.  You always start from zero after every run.  Like pac-man.  So it's more of an old school arcade style game.  But after peeking at the guides, I see the game is huuuuuge and there's no way I'm going to see 99% of it and neither will you unless you're prepared to die literally (and I mean LITERALLY) 300,000+ times.  It's 2024, over 3 years after Noita was released.  Give us a mode that's more forgiving for Pete's sake.  
If you're in the 'git gud', 'it's a skill issue' crowd, good for you.  There are so many games in my backlog and my play time is finite.  More fun and exploration and less frustration please.  I'm putting Noita back on the shelf and keeping my fingers crossed for an update that lets you select what % of damage you take or something.

Great roguelike game that is far bigger in scope than you would initially think due to countless complex mechanics operating in almost every facet, but is held back a bit by its 32bit antique nature. I recommend playing with either a high end modern cpu to brute force it into running well or accepting the fact that it will run slow on even normally invincible i7's from a few years back. 

The game does not have frameskip due to its nature, so fortunately you will get smooth gameplay regardless of cpu load/lag/tears, meaning that even though it might get a little slow-mo sometimes, it is always playable.

GPU load might as well not exist on anything newer than the statue of liberty, but some graphics settings may reduce cpu load so turning down graphics could end up helping a lot. It is not infrequent that large explosions and complex reactions can occur with or without the player causing them, and such cpu burdens may be impossible to negate even on the latest i7-90 billion or whatever is now considered high end.

I like the idea (fully destructible environment and physics simulation) and the execution is probably fine (not many other games to compare it to, really). It just has the same problem as most roguelikes have for me personally, which is that there is little story or it's hidden behind a progression that resets with each death. I gave it an hour as part of my attempt to get through my backlog of unplayed games, had about 2 halfway decent runs and a couple of stinkers. Yes, it is a skill issue. But also, it is a motivation issue, as in that hour and 5-6 runs I already got sick of seeing the first level. For fans of roguelikes this has probably infinite charm (and the reviews suggest as much), but for me this is the wrong game. I cannot recommend it at that price for non-fans of the genre, everyone else can happily ignore me.

This is genuinely one of the greatest games I have ever played. It starts off as a pretty run of the mill rogue lite where you go deeper downwards and kill the enemies to get to the final bottom level. But that is such a disservice to what this game actually is and there's so much content here for easily hundreds of hours.

I will try to just cover the surface without going to deep so you can explore this genuine masterpiece for yourself:

Looks:
Firstly, it has an incredibly simple yet beautiful art style. Fires can quickly spread illuminating a dark hallway and spells trail through the air impacting with the environment creating craters and holes. The player is is constantly surrounded by a breathtakingly dynamic and deadly environment. Without getting into spoilers, the actual playable area is much larger than the player initially realizes, which helps really sell the world as there is much to see and explore.

Gameplay:
The interact-ability with the world gives way to a lot of emergent game play. One play-through you shot a weird spell and now the ceiling collapsed killing you and your mother. The second play-through you died because you have a cool electric wand, but you thought it would be a good idea to use it while in kiddie pool with all of the other shitters and now everything in that puddle including you is dead. The player is forced to pay attention to the environmental dangers of the world around them before even engaging with some the enemies in the dungeon. Everything is a threat and the game does not hold the players hand, you learn to quickly tread carefully and the farther you go the more intense things get.

This is with out even touching the wand building mechanic, which is what makes me come back to this game still. Imagine playing a game where you have the ability to create a build out a generic rock turning it into a heat seeking missile that rips through the air killing everything in its path. This is on of those things you might need to just google to see how insane and deep this shit gets. But there is no game that really gives the tools to create such interesting builds and interactions with the spells/wands/perks provided. The combinations are truly endless, and Im still learning and making new builds 200 hours in.

The Bad:
There is no bad, Perhaps maybe the occasional bug, there really isn't much I can think of besides it being maybe too challenging for more casual players to actually get started. But I dont actually believe this to be a flaw, as its just part of the Noita experience for the player to overcome. And overcome you will, when you learn just how powerful you can actually get. Take your time my child.

All in all, 
Its one of the games that I believe deserves the title of "Masterpiece". And in terms of what is humanly possible, in many ways I believe this game to be perfect. I hope you don't delay, and you pick this game up and just stick with it for a while. Don't force it, but push yourself to learn it, if you get bored maybe look up "Sun seed quest" and you will start to see the potential of this amazing game.

Fuck it dude, this shit is HARD. You will die. You will be attached to a run and then you will be destroyed and you will blame the game. If you are like me, you will drop Noita for months at an end because the game betrayed your trust.. only to realize that that's part of why you love it.
I personally want to get sucked into a game, like completely in there, and Noita has provided that for me. It is deep, it is expansive, it is brutal, it is complicated at times, and it has the best secret system I've ever seen. Take it from somebody who has a crown and necklace, rewards from the two hardest secrets in this game, if you like an enveloping world that really requires you to sink your teeth into it, then Noita might just be for you.

It also helps if you're a masochist like me-

Noita is a very chaotic and fun take on the roguelike genre, that includes many roguelike elements as well as secrets to be found within the game. It's extremely unforgiving and challenging, so don't assume you will get a balanced experience. However, the forefront and selling point of this game is the physics. Noita has an exellent pixel styled physics engine that can work either in your favor or against you. Most of the time it's the latter. 

After 13 hours of Noita, I'll give the game an 7/10. There is lots of things to explore in this game and it just so happens the actual gameplay meshes really well with the physics. Noita struggles in it's build variety and fairness, not allowing the player to experiment and stack abilities. This is something present in roguelikes/lites such as Hades, Slay The Spire, Nova Drift, Wizard Of Legend, and many more. It helps keep the game fresh and strategic. This game changed my life. I'd always known I wanted to be a mage, but it always seemed as if I wasn't cut out for it. I would try, again and again, always getting so, very close to learning SOME kind of spell or tome, but always to no avail. I felt as if I just wasn't cut out for wizardry, and it sent me into a deep depression for many, many years. 

But this year is when all of that changed, when I discovered Noita. I'd disregarded Finnish magic as Nordic pagan slop for many moons, but oh how wrong I was. This game has finally, at long last, helped me discover my deep, deep, deep adoration for witchcraft. Ever since picking up and playing this silly little roguelike, my magical abilities have blossomed. Despite my short playtime, the last two weeks I have spent doing nothing but casting spells. I picked up incredibly quickly, and that never would have happened if not for this game. 

I've gotten so good in fact, that I began teaching others just how easy it is to cast spells, using my knowledge learned from this game. I now aspire to be a teacher of wizardry, educating the public on how to use magic for their own benefit. My prior hatred of magic has all but vanished, and has been replaced with an incredible love. Pick this game up, and I promise you, it will change your life.

Noita might be my favorite video game.

Noita is a game of intricate wand building: buying spells and wands, unlocking even more powerful spells, and implementing them to create weapons of unparalleled power. Learning how spells are arranged, how wands work, and which spells in which orders create death or victory genuinely feels like studying the arcane arts and becoming a wizard. The sheer number of different powerful wands you can create gives this game the same charm of deck builders. Yet despite all of this, this game is really hard. Any number of things can kill you (often your own wand) but the game challenges the player just enough to be addicting. Every run, every stupid death, you learn something. Again, this contributes to this emergent sense of growing stronger, smarter, and more knowledgeable.

But I haven't even talked about the scale of this game yet. A good rule of thumb is that no matter how big you think Noita is, there is always more. It is always bigger. Entire quests, secrets, lore, bosses, and areas are completely hidden from the player until they are discovered naturally. This does bring me to my one complaint, which is that the game is so big that  the average player may never find some of the best parts of this game. My advice to new players would be to just "win" first, then start using the wiki and glancing at maps. This game is massive and deep, and there is always more to explore.

The music is reactive and catchy. The graphics are beautiful. The lore and world is fascinating. The mods are excellent. The gameplay is fun as hell. I just love absolutely everything about this game. No other one game has made me feel as stupid or as smart as Noita has, and every run has something new and fun to offer.

Ridiculously unforgiving yet incredibly rewarding.

What it does exceptionally well is its almost endless replayablity and physics. Once you get a hang of the game mechanic and understand how the game works and what it wants from you the only limit is your own capability of wand building.
In this game you can build wands that range from either shooting a purple bolt that disappears on contact to casting a spell that is an equivalent of an aneurysm inducing supernova on crack that ctrl+alt+del everything and everyone including yourself in a single frame. The map is way bigger than it may first seem. Seriously, its enormous. And on top of that every single pixel is simulated and acts realistic.
Example: Explosion in water => Water evaporates and turns to steam => steam rises to the ceiling => steam slowly cools and condensates back into water. (This is just a basic example and there are also a bunch of alchemic reactions in the game)
Obviously there are a lot of other great, interesting and unique mechanics but i just cant list them all.

There is a bunch of secrets but i recommend using the wiki if you want to find them because the game barely explains anything and if it does its cryptic as shit. Same goes for unlocking certain spells, the game can get kind of stupidly complicated to unlock certain spells. But if you love secrets and hidden messages then you will love this aspect of course.

That being said the game isnt perfect. It has its flaws like lack of explanation of game mechanics as i said before. You have to figure out everything yourself except the bare basic controls. It feels like the game is designed for people that are already pros at Noita and its incredibly frustrating at times. Some spells or perks have hidden stats or mechanics the game doesnt tell you about. Again, use the wiki for more infos on spells. Luckly the game has a great Steam Workshop with plenty of mods that can help you get into the game easier.

Overall its totally worth the 19€ if you enjoy roguelite games and its often on sale as well. I would give it a 9/10.

To sum up how I feel about this game, let me provide an anecdote from one of my runs.
In the minds, I stumble across a cool looking wand submerged in a pool of a strange pink liquid. I think nothing of it, and jump in to try and grab the wand and quickly jump out. Instead, I turn into a sheep with wings. Okay, well the pool has walls around it. I'll use my wand to blow up one of them and the pool will drain. Great job me! I use the wand, but the bomb bounces off the wall and falls down somewhere below. Oh. Well, okay, I'll drop a bomb on the inside of the pool. The wall blows up and the pool starts draining. Nice! I jump down and, trying to avoid the fire, I miss the floor and fall down to where the liquid is going. I turn back into a flying sheep and cannot fly back up to the wand, so I fall further down. Say, what happened to that first bomb of mine? I don't have to wonder any longer, because I find a burning vat of whiskey that I fall right into, and cannot fly out of. The polymorph effect wears off, and I turn back into a Noita, luckily not on fire. However, I instinctively click while I am still holding my bomb wand, firing my last bomb and blowing up the rest of the whiskey, as well as two explosive crates right next to it. I run away, and am able to escape with 94 health. Around 30 seconds later, I accidentally shoot a lantern which falls onto an explosive crate and kills me. 
I am in constant suffering.
10/10 would get Noita'd again

A roguelike game that really makes you feel like a wizard!
Spells and environments interact and not always predictably, which is a great source of entertainment in runs. Most deaths will be due to your own carelessness or lack of foresight. 
As roguelikes go, the game is hard but fair and rarely will you die to random nonsense you didn't cause. Enemies are cleverly designed to have great environmental reactions and some even attack each other. 
However, runs tend to be longer and the careful investment in each character means the losses at the end of each unique run will feel bad.
There is minor meta-progression between runs in the form of secret pickups that unlock spells for further runs but otherwise its all up to you. This game really encourages you to understand and get to know all the wacky things you can do, rewarding you greatly for thinking outside the box.
Don't be afraid to get Noita'd!

Let's get two things out of the way first.
One, the learning curve more closely resembles a cliff. The game is hard and doesn't hide the fact that it's out for your blood; it's very unfair by design.
Two, most of the content of this game is hidden from you. The loop of spawning and progressing to the "final" boss is but a small portion of what this game has to offer.
With that said this is a must for those that enjoy roguelites and challenges. The pixel-by-pixel simulation gives you a ton of freedom and replayability through randomness (and unfairness), and both the wand building system (your weapons and spells) and the alchemy system are very elaborate. This game is as close as you're going to get to the ultimate spellcrafting and spellcasting experience where you can spend hundreds of hours combining hundreds of different spells and modifiers to see how well, or how suicidal, it turns out.
If you can push through the almost vertical learning curve there's a lot of dopamine rushes to be had here.

- The whole selling point of the game is that "each pixel is it's own entity." But the game doesn't utilize this mechanic at all. Essentially what it translates to is "each pixel can kill you, either by exploding, or making you a one shot kill..." 
- The wand mechanic is the biggest part of the game, but it is incredibly convoluted (for me) and the game does not hold your hand at all, it is all up to you to figure out what the goal is, and how to play the game, which doesn't translate to a fun experience. 
I have no idea why everyone supposedly loves this game so much, when it sucks so badly. I am all for a challenge, but it is a game, make it worth my time, make it fun.

The physics, wand customisation, and enemy variety is very fun to experience, and I wish the developers focused on game mechanics to improve on this foundation. Unfortunately, they made this game an extremely unbalanced, luck-based rouge-like (Level 4 is basically impossible to survive unless you get a few very specific items or wands) where enemies have the ability to pick up world-destroying, framerate-slashing, insta-kill wands and use them on you. As mentioned above, the random item generation can make or break your run, which means that you can beat the game very quickly (Someone did it in around 20 hours in the Steam discussions) if you get lucky, but it could also take you hundreds of hours to beat the game once on the normal difficulty. During all of these runs, you will be running through the same areas over and over again with some differences and rearranged points of interest. Also, the game has a ton of content in the form of obscure secrets that most players will never find without looking at external tutorials. In addition, the game has random lag spikes and terrible performance in the later levels even if you have a PC that meets or exceeds the minimum system requirements.

TLDR: 7/10, the overall mechanics and game play are really solid, but the game has an extreme over-reliance on RNG, among other issues.
PROS:
-Phenomenal amounts of quality and attention to detail, I don't think you can actually run out of things to do in this game unless you have hundreds of hours spent in this game.
-The game mechanics are really solid, and I haven't personally encountered any bugs or issues.
-Great soundtrack and world building, it's definitely a treat to get to explore around without any real limitations.

CONS:
-The first thing you'll notice is how easy it is to die, but before you think "oh that's a skill issue", I'm talking about maybe 5 explosives, that literally do more damage than a nuke (a spell in the game) individually, being tucked away in a pile of snow, just for you to mine through it unknowingly and die despite having 1000+ health - kind of bad luck. A fundamental problem this game has is that no matter how skilled or knowledgeable you are, it's so ridiculously easy to die. This isn't a game that has a skill ceiling with the foundation of actual skill, it has one of sheer knowledge that you gain after dying hundreds of times (literally based off of anyone you ask) and just luck. The game is extremely unforgiving, there's a reason most people don't bother playing after like around 40 hours. 
-The secrets that this game has are just about impossible to discover yourself unless you google them, and if you do plan on doing that, well they still aren't all found, unless you only care about getting 100% achievements.
-This game doesn't actually really teach you anything besides how to use the basics and manage your very tiny inventory, you'll learn by dying by enemies or just killing yourself because you experimented with a wand.

OVERALL:
If this game was structured in a way that was a lot more new-user friendly, and wasn't 99% based off of RNG and knowing what garbage to not take and what stuff you just abuse and kill the boss and whatever other secret bosses there are, then I would recommend it even more. Considering the game is fairly cheap, I'd still pick it up. I personally love this game, but it certainly has problems.

somehow this is like my third or fourth most played game on steam so i think i'll write a real review instead of a meme one.  

first off a basic explanation of the game.  it is a brutally hard rogue-like inspired by the actual rogue (i think i dont play a lot of these kinds of games), and falling sand where you're a witch who goes into a cave for reasons i dont think anyone fully understands.  this cave is full of goblins who are all awful and i hate them. it's also full of gold!  you find and buy wands and spells in order to craft magical wands in order to make your life easier, or just blow yourself up.  Sometimes by accident, sometimes for fun.

i really really hate RNG and randomness in games.  i really love high difficulty games that allow you to completely break the balance of said game.  basically, i like if the game is hard but allows you to become an overpowered god if skilled.  i hate when luck is a primary factor because i am an insanely unlucky person.

noita combines the thing i hate most in games, with the thing i love most.  and it also adds in the falling sand game that i used to spend hours on in high school.  it also adds another game feature i despise, obtuse secrets that require you to be INTELLIGENT to figure it out.  im not smart man come on.  but it also has something else i adore, references to real life mysticism!

all in all the package is very endearing.  there's something very special about this game, and every time i play it i remember i both hate it passionately and love it more than any other indie game i've ever played.  the high stress moments are very balls retreating up your body, and the more peaceful moments are genuinely serene.  death lurks around every corner but as long as you're a brave, but cautious little witch you can generally come out on top.


also chainsaw is AWESOME.

one of like three games i think is a genuine 10/10.  there's some things i'd like changed/added/improved but what's here fits together all nicely.  not for everyone, this game is stupid.

edit: WHAT?  MORE GAME MECHANICS TO KILL MYSELF WITH AND LOSE 6 HOURS OF MY LIFE TO RANDOMLY GENERATED BULLSHIT?  SIGN ME THE FUCK UP.

There are exceptionally few games that I can recommend to the degree that I recommend Noita. The sheer amount of possibilities in this game is wild. You can summon oceans of sawblades, evaporate entire biomes or teleport across worlds. 

There's no wizarding game where you feel as powerful or godlike as you do in Noita, while still being able to be instantly killed by all sorts of random mechanics you could never realistically never have foreseen. This contrast is also what makes the game so fun - being an omnipotent allmighty wizard holds no meaning if it's something you easily accomplish every restart.
  
The mechanics of wandbuilding in this game are so intricate that very few understand even half of it, but you don't even need to understand all that much to have a great time. 

The only negative thing I can think of is that there's not *enough* of the game, although there's still probably upwards of 200 hours (probably more if you do the longest quests in the game) should you never consult the wiki. With that said, there's also quite a few content mods to be able to continue playing. 

There's no reason to sit on the fence for this one.

This game has that [i]quality[/i] that is so rare. The physics engine is basically unique and provides excellent emergent gameplay. One minute you love it to bits, you're casting spells that make you think you are invincible, then you die because you find yourself at the receiving end of some novel and possibly ridiculous chain reaction that you failed to anticipate. Sometimes it's just some simple thing that you just haven't seen before. Sometimes you just have to learn the hard way that something really is flammable after all. And every time you hate it a bit and have to go do something else. But then the game pulls you back in.

If I had to compare this to anything, I would go with FTL, because both seem more or less impossible to beat in the beginning and over time as you learn more and more you get further and further. You have only four slots for wands and four slots for other items like potions and it makes this hard in the same way that FTL or similar games are hard, and it's perfection because you have to think carefully about what weapons to prioritize. Some wands are better for digging, others are better for sniping, others you just fill with everything you can imagine and unleash mayhem that probably gets you killed in the process. It's wonderful how you can add, remove, mix and match spells and spell modifiers, sometimes with deadly results (resulting in more rage quitting, realizing what you did wrong, seething for a while and then starting a new run).

This is probably one of the best games I have ever played.
allemi

The game drops you in to the middle of things without any explanation, save for the basic controls. 

While this can be good, the lack of direction makes it difficult to figure out what to do. Noita would benefit immensely from NPC's that offer guidance on the many mechanics the game has to offer.

The gameplay loop is very repetitive in that you are constantly dying to try and learn more about how the game mechanics work. After enough deaths this just becomes tedious and exhausting rather than fun. Especially since you start from zero every time you die. Let me get to the fun part and learn without having to spend 20-30 mins getting back to where I was.

The lack of a meta progression system hurts in this regard too. This would at least provide some indication that the player is actually doing something right.

While Noita has pretty and shiny pixel graphics, its steep learning curve makes it hard to enjoy for the average player.

What was an impulse buy of a game I thought would be nice to have turned into a spiral of creativity and intrigue as Noita took me around what a video game sandbox can truly be. Every death feels unfair, so every success comes with the same feeling that other games only give you when you uses glitches to succeed. Noita is all about driving you to figure out some legendary strategy or genius wand from the knowledge that you alone scraped from your runs. Experiment, play slowly, and explore. Noita is absolutely nuts, and there is nothing like it in my 10+ years of gaming.

The first few times I tried Noita, I didn't really get it. I'm thinking it was the review score that made me give it a few more chances, and at some point it clicked.  It's really a masterpiece - the infinite amount of wand combos, the vast and mysterious game world, the hidden lore. And it doesn't hurt that the game is actually quite tough, so you have to try hard to make progress, and it's rewarding.

I got interested in Noita when I heard one of its secrets needed the knowledge of a masters in electrical engineering. I have no interest in electrical engineering but loved the idea of a game challenging its players to the extreme. The craziest part? The puzzle hasn't been completely solved yet.

I've died over 200 times and only won twice. It seemed impossible at first, until something clicked. Despite my constant failures, it was addictive. Plus, the music is great to listen to.

This game got me into learning Finnish, too. I'd highly recommend this game if you like hectic, beautiful gameplay and quick-thinking.

And I haven't even talked about the mods. The mods have largely contributed to the amount of playtime I have. They are a lot of fun and abundant.

In the shadowed crags of digital enclaves lies "Noita," a game where arcane pixels conspire to weave a tapestry of both chaos and wonder. Amidst a ballet of algorithmic alchemy, you will find yourselves cloaked in the robes of a sorcerer, navigating the cavernous abyss where the familiar laws of nature are but whispers and suggestions.

To saunter through "Noita" is to dance with uncertainty – every grain of the pixelated underworld is touched by the wand of simulation. Here, elements frolic with a mischievous gleam; fire sprints with wild abandon across explosive powders, water waltzes gracefully around your cloak, which is as whimsical as it is a repository of eldritch secrets.

Delve into this cryptic cavalcade, and you shall discover a bestiary most bizarre. Creatures of such pixel-perfect malice, they would give a necromancer's spellbook an existential crisis. Cast your spells – which I assure you come in more flavors than an interdimensional candy shop – but do take care not to singe your eyebrows. Magic here is a fickle friend; it giggles at the chaos it brings.

Every plunge into the cavern's heart is a fresh fever dream. The walls twist and the laws of physics are quaint suggestions, often scribbled in the margins of reality. Dabble in the art of crafting spells and watch as your creations either blossom into a flower of destruction or wilt into a herb of mild inconvenience.

Imagine the sight of a witch's hat, suddenly bestowed with wings, attempting to fathom the mechanics of flight and you won’t be far off. "Noita" embraces its own absurdity like a jester at the court of darkness. It is as likely to inflict a smirk with its bizarre interactions as it is to furrow your brow in bewildered defeat.

In its essence, "Noita" is the whisper in the dark, the chuckle in the face of demise, a potion brewed with equal parts wonderment and bewilderment. So, capes on, wands at the ready; just keep one eye on the shadows and the other looking for the next anarchic giggle. The game is a soiree of the unconventional, inviting all who dare to rewrite the rulebook in a land where even gravity is subject to negotiation.

Somehow this is the most frustrating, difficult game I've played in quite some time, dying all the time, starting fresh 5 or more times in one sit down, yet is one of the most fun and addicting games I've ever played. Every playthough you learn something new: how this spell works with that spell, how this potion can get me through this otherwise tough section, how this enemy reacts and fights, etc. Even though on a surface level, it seems as if you are repeating yourself going through the same areas, every game will be different, with different challenges you have to adapt to. You are never not kept on your toes.
If you are just starting out on this game, allow yourself the time to soak in everything. You will not beat this game quick, even if you have seen gameplay before you play it, you need experience and alot of it. You have to be a wizard, a warrior, an alchemist and a strategist simultaneously to achieve good runs, and that takes time and experience.

My personal favorite thing about this game is the fact that the descending progressing levels of increasing difficulty with the final boss at the end COULD be all that there is to this game and it still be a good game. But there is an entire WORLD surrounding it in all cardinal directions, filled with secrets, quite frankly to the brim. So if you get good at the game and beat the boss, try exploring a bit more, and see what challenges and strange places you may get yourself into. 

And most importantly, have fun. Don't become attached to a run, understand that the more you play, the more you learn, and with each death, you become a better player. But still pray to our lord and saviour RNGesus, because sometimes in this game, a single pixel could set off a cacophony of unfortunate events, one of those events being your ultimate demise.

Once in a great while a game like this comes along and proves once again you don't have to have a $900 graphics card to play awesome games. This game is deep. It's a roguelite that kind of expects you to have already graduated from metroidvania school. Even still, this game is difficult, but because of the you-never-know-what-youre-going-to-get-next element and incredible variations on wands, spells, perks, just for starters, it makes you want to play again and again just to see how far you can get.

Some people may not like the roguelite aspect of this game but if you're as old as me you'll remember Metroid was closer to a rougelite that most "modern" mertroidvania games. This game does not hold your hand and again, feels more like old-school Metroid than it does, say Hollow Knight (a game I also love.)

Even though the graphics are 8bit in look, the feel is very different. Nearly every pixel is affected by physical simulation and always seems to deliver surprises. This game is smooth, although at times it can drop frames a bit if you start causing lots of explosions all around you. There's really no map (there is a map of sorts in mid-late-game content.) The only real meta-progression is a series of achievements, or Pillars, as they're called in the game. Otherwise you start from zero every time, with 2 random wands (from a much shallower pool of possible combinations) and a flask of random fluid, of which there are many. As you progress (downward, usually, at least at the start,) you find more powerful and unusual wands, perks and other miscellaneous oddities.

Noita: Because who needs eyebrows anyway?

The game that made me question the value of eyebrows, the necessity of pants, and the structural integrity of pixelated caves. Welcome to the wizarding world where spells are your superpower, and accidental self-destruction is your university diploma.

Noita embraces chaos like a live hand grenade. Every run feels like a surprise party where the presents explode, and the cake is a cosmic horror.

Permadeath adds a dash of stress to the mix. Losing all progress is like losing a game of Jenga, except the tower is your self-esteem.

Warning – Noita might turn you into a wand  connoisseur. I can't pass a shop without buying more magical firepower.

This is one of my favorite games. I think it's great in
[olist]
[*]Graphics. This is probably the most good-looking roguelike I've ever played. They are not as blocky as other pixel art games, and the movement feels good. I like that each pixel has its own effect and interacts with each other, which makes them feel like realistic atoms. The visual effects of the spells are impressive. With a carefully designed wand, one can literally make scenes as cool as or even cooler than those in professional productions.
[*]Complex mechanics. The effects of materials, spells, perks, enemies and items, and how they interact with each other are very complex. They combine to give many interesting mechanics. On the other hand, the game doesn't force the player to know or master too many mechanics right away.
[*]Mystery. All those cryptic texts and strange objects pique curiosity. The world is huge and filled with secrets. It invites exploration and gives a sense of discovery. I like that it doesn't force you to visit everywhere and instead just sort of place them there. Once the player finishes the obvious biomes, going left, right, down, or up all leads to new areas.
[/olist]
Several things that I feel could be better for me are
[olist]
[*]The wand mechanics is confusing and not explained well. I have to watch quite a bunch of videos to understand how it works exactly. Even now I'm still not quite sure about how some of the advanced spells work. I think it would be interesting to add the knowledge of spells and wands as a reward within the game. This is an experience that only a mechanically deep game can give. A feature like an encyclopedia that gets populated as you experience things would be nice too.
[*]I hope there are more friendly/companion creatures or, even better, NPCs. The world is huge and after the standard biomes, it honestly feels a bit lonely to explore the world alone. While exploring a dangerous world filled with wonders is an experience in itself, I find it can get tiresome with a lack of purpose. I think adding some quests with stories can add more meaning to the exploration and make it more fun.
[/olist]

My experience playing this game changed over time. At first, I thought this game sucked major. I had no idea how to build wands and what to do. The game does not explain anything wand related. Once I understood the way wands worked then everything changed. And I mean it really changed. I made some totally broken wands that would kill anything in a second while digging through almost any material. I was finally able to fully explore the game and complete everything. 

So, if you take time to fully understand how the wands work and have a little patience, this game is really rewarding. The way the elements are used is awesome. Fire, water, earth, electricity, and everything else. No other game goes so in-depth. No other game will also kill you instantly more than this game will. Explosions, picking up wands that instantly kill you when you fire them, being on fire and out of your water flask. All kinds of death, over and over. Youtube videos helped me a lot. I beat the game and killed many of the optional bosses. There is a lot of content here. If you like roguelikes then I recommend this game. I found myself really liking the experience in the end.

In the ebon depths of pre-eternity, there was a spark. 
The enigma's incandescence ripped into the burgeoning plane and spun into new forms;
First there was Magick, the mesh and the weave, the interconnected relativity of all-thing.
Where Magick's matrix slacked, second there was Chaos, tumbling and twisting the unhemmed seams.
Those who witnessed Chaos conjured the third, Order they called it. Rules by which seen chaos might cease.
The Witnesses, made of Magick and Chaos, did not follow their own Order. So they birthed the fourth, and named it Sin.

In the time since, every civilization has suggested these things came in the reverse order. That the evil of Sin is inherent, and that Order is necessary to weaken Sin-- but that Order requires constant maintenance because of Chaos... And rarely do Witnesses speak truly on the formation of Magick.

Genuinely one of the best games I have ever played. At first the game looks a little simple and unforgiving, and although it remains unforgiving, the world is immensely complex. Noita has only a tiny number of rules that cannot be broken, but EVERYTHING ELSE is a suggestion. HP is finite, until you learn how to gain infinite health. Same with money, or spell uses, or mana costs. Wands can vary from doing nothing, to instantly killing you, to making you a walking god. All that separates these is how well you understand the game. Additionally, the game has amazing eastereggs and lore. Two of the eastereggs still has the community working hard to figure out, one of which involves cryptography. Additionally, Noita's lore is deep and cryptic, and you may learn it from the least likely places. The creative berth this game gives the player to alter their world is amazing and truly unique and genuinely unforgettable.

So Noita is probably my favorite roguelike. I'll structure this review by just giving you my three reasons as to why: The Spell Crafting, the Knowledge Progression, and the Content Quantity.

** Spell Crafting **

Noita's spell crafting system is truly special, and is something that I've been looking for for a long, long time. And I highly suggest that any developer looking to create something similar, to study this game. I want more games to give me brain-rot levels of theory crafting. I want games to let me attach so many modifiers to my wand that I crash my game. No, I don't *want* you to fix it. I want to feel like my meddling in arcane arts that I know little about caused the universe to implode.

The Spell Crafting system can make the game feel entirely different from one person to another depending on how experienced they are. GamerGonzales2009 might settle for just putting on a bunch of Reduce Cast Delay modifiers with a standard Spark Bolt and call it a day, where as XxXCosmoNebulaWizardXxX might be one shotting bosses by boosting his spell damage for each pixel he spawns on screen prior to firing it and going to parallel universes.

Seriously - this game is as deep as you want it to be. I'd also like to give two recommendations for new players:

1. Get a mod that permanently gives you Edit Wands Anywhere. Dev says they took away the ability to edit wands anywhere because players were spending too much time tinkering with wands. I say, that's half of the point of the game. So just do it. There's exploits that allow for the functionality near enough anyway, and Hardcore Mode has it by default. So you might as well.

2. If you REALLY want to know the ins and outs of wand crafting, I highly recommend the Spell Lab mod. It'll give you some interactive challenges that teach you more in-depth things about the game's spell systems. You don't need it to have fun, and infact I first encourage you to do a few runs on your own. But if you want to take your wands to the next level, there's no better way to do it than with Spell Lab's tutorials.

** Knowledge Progression **

Noita is a roguelike with basically zero permanent upgrades. The closest it gets is that whenever you discover a spell it then becomes possible for it to appear in shops in later runs. But that's about it.

However, whilst most of Noita's worlds are randomly generated, they *do* have a number of areas, events and items that are either guaranteed to spawn, or otherwise have a high chance of spawning.

The best way I can explain this is by pointing to Terraria: every world is randomly generated, but there's always going to be a Dungeon to the far right or left of the world, there's always going to be beaches that will have chests under the oceans, ect.

Noita has A LOT of things like that. And learning these is crucial, because you can go from barely surviving with a wand that shoots eggshells, to entering each early-mid stage of a run with powerful modifiers, items that can be exchanged for strong wands, and so on.

I'm not gonna spoil the big ones, but I will give you a small example: In the beginning mines area, going to the left will eventually take you to an area called the Dark Cave. You'll need a good digging wand (TNT, Bombs, ect), but you can blow an opening into the cave, and within it, there's a guaranteed max health upgrade. You'll need a light source of some kind though. 

That's the most BASIC example. I'm not joking when I say the game is filled with things like that. To the point where your 'route' through the game can vastly impact your success, vs just constantly going down, down, down.

** Content Quantity **

And lastly, Noita has a TON of stuff in it. From the sheer number of spells and modifiers, to the areas, bosses, collectibles and endings. It's not as huge as something like Binding of Isaac, but let's just say that Nolla Games didn't waste their time over the years - if you want to see most of what Noita has to offer, you're going to be putting *atleast* 70~80 hours into the game. Hell I'm sitting at 200+, and I havn't experienced everything the game has.

Noita is no longer receiving official updates, but it lives on through mods, with official modding support.

This might be one of the coolest *Tech Demo*s I've ever played in my life. My mind just can't help but swim around the ideas for some kind of open world rpg or something with this kind of magic pixel sandbox theme with all of these different elements of world destruction. Really reminded me of that sense of wonder my initial Minecraft experience brought me. But like, Minecraft, it is simply a technology demonstration that quickly loses it's luster without countless hour of passion fueled development given for free by fans. 

 The problem, is the gameplay loop. If you don't give your players some kind of reason to keep playing other than 'start new game", they might not. For me, this gameplay loop of just "die due to lack of experience knowledge of how the game works, and that's it, no skill points or some kind of character improvement or information/direction about the game just try again, noob" really didn't capture my enthusiasm, and that lack of motivation on top of all of the amazing possibilities a game engine like this presents, just sucked the life out of the experience that is being sold. I suppose it's worth it on sale, but for the full price, I just would need a bit more substance. I really like permadeath games but it just feels off here to not have some sort of reward for your effort.

I think you can unlock new spells somehow (I didn't understand this process), but you still have to have rely on rng to get a hold of them. 

Again, great tech demo, loved watching all the pixels burn up or explode or flow onto the ground and down chasms, nut that's about all the enjoyment I could get out of it and that was about an hour and a half.

Prepare to be spellbound and utterly captivated! Noita is not just a game; it's a thrilling adventure into the arcane and unknown. This masterpiece ingeniously intertwines the art of witchcraft with groundbreaking physics, creating an experience that's nothing short of magical. Imagine a world where every pixel is simulated, and your wand is the key to unleashing chaos and creativity in equal measure. Whether you're demolishing walls or igniting explosive barrels, Noita invites you to become the alchemist of your wildest dreams.

But brace yourselves, brave souls, for this journey is not for the timid. Picture the relentless challenge of Dark Souls fused with the enchanting world of Harry Potter, topped with a bewildering twist of unpredictability. Just when you think you've mastered its secrets, [b]Noita morphs[/b], throwing you into a whirlwind of exhilarating uncertainty. It's this unpredictable nature that transforms frustration into fascination, keeping you hooked and hungry for more.

So, for those who relish a challenge that tickles the funny bone and tests the mind, Noita is your siren call. It's not just a game; it's a bewitching odyssey that will enchant, frustrate, and amuse you in equal measure. Prepare to be ensnared in its spell, where every playthrough is a unique tale of magic, mayhem, and a bit of good-natured cursing. Noita isn't just a game you play; it's an experience that plays you!

it's too easy to get stuck on random little things.  For a game were you loose everything when you die and where every pixel is supposed to have physics it seems like you should find yourself constantly stuck on three random impervious floating grey pixels over a grey background.

Time to be a contrarian and dunk on an Overwhelmingly Positive game.

Simply put, the mechanics/material physics and the gameplay design does not gel at all, it is as if they were pulled from two different games. You have all these various materials, liquids, spells and creatures that interact with one another in spectacularly chaotic and deadly ways, yet this is a brutal roguelite where you're extremely squishy and can die in a fraction of a second with no fault of your own in a run that's already 4 hours in. The game forces to play extremely conservatively, despite having all these fun mechanics that you're heavily discouraged from participating if you want to progress.

It would be slightly more tolerable if every run felt truly different, but you always start out with the lamest (if not outright useless) possible spells, and the game is so miserly at giving you passives (most of which are detrimental trash), it's frankly baffling.

Incredible rogue-lite that's infinitely bigger than it initially lets on. Every pixel being simulated means a near unlimited amount of ways to die in horrific means but at the same time an equal amount of possibility to exploit the world and become as powerful as it's gods you once feared. Go into the game with as little information as possible for the best experience but keep in mind that at some point if you want to engage in the game's secrets you will almost be forced to look up some of the more esoteric solutions. One of the best games I've played in a matter of years, 8-9/10 depending on how I'm feeling and if I recently got killed by shooting an explosive box right next to me.

Noita is the culmination of what you as a child thought of games and their atmosphere and story. Magical and full of secrets on first glance, but later on you realize it was just your overactive imagination and the game was just a regular playstation2 game. This game however actually makes all of those idealizations into reality, you notice certain things after a while and wonder what they could mean, you can actually explore those things as well. This game is quite literally magical in both the literal and figurative sense. Telling you anymore than this would spoil too much...
