Disclaimer: I don't have the time, skill or dedication to play this game as it was intended, or to get the most out of it. I could not really enjoy it until I loaded mods to improve survival and cheat permadeath. And still there was a lot of frustration and deaths. I spent a lot of my time as a drunk wizard prone to setting myself on fire. But still I must recommend this fantastic game for packing so much good stuff: the diversity of biomes and monsters, the impressive variety of spells and modifiers with their near limitless combinations, the intriguing mysteries to discover above and below ground, and of course the amazing environment in which every non-background pixel is a physical game element, with all the tactical dangers, benefits and chaos that brings. Sure the RNG will sometimes (often?) piss you off, and your great run can come to a quick end when you get stuck on a tiny rocky pixel you didn't see, but the adventure and spell experimentation are well worth. And things can always go better on your next run ... or the next ... or the one after that.

Wandbuilding in Noita is akin to learning a new language, verbal or coding. You start off completely clueless and fuck yourself over, but each time you fuck up you learn a small nugget of information that eventually adds up to you being able to form a word or two. You learn common rules and structures, building yourself up for more complex words. You can now maybe form a small sentence a child would be capable of, but this is only the beginning of a long and rewarding journey.

Never played a game that fucks you over harder than Noita, but still keeps you coming back for more. I've been playing games daily since the early flash era, so this may mean something to people reading. Do not play if you aren't willing to play a hardcore roguelike which puts knowledge above all else. You will die, possibly hundreds of times, before you even reach or kill the final boss. And that could be considered the prologue of the game. Also has some of the most cryptic and esoteric secrets in all of gaming, with some still being actively solved to this very day. The world is huge, try going out of bounds sometimes.

Currently, you start with 2 wands. 1 with 3 magic slots and 1 with 1 magic slot. You can't move magic abilities until you're in the safe room, which wasn't safe because everything is one giant map. I was killed by a powerful undead lich in the first safe room through the portal. There are 2 portals at the bottom of the first level. Each time you respawn the world changes. Loading times are really fast when things rearrange. I've seen evidence of the last world, proving that the world just gets an overlap. The destructible environment is appealing but only for a while. You'll find wands and potions. You can discover different things.

This game has no checkpoint saves. You can save and quit, loads where you were standing before closing the game, but once you die you're back to the beginning. This is a hardcore type game. A one shot adventure. You collect gold nuggets as currency that disappear after several seconds, could be 30 seconds. The flashing of the nugget will increase before this happens.

You don't get to choose your abilities before respawning. For those confused about the recording it only saves what happened as picture animations in gif format, like those memes.

Liquids stick to you and can either give you a bit of protection or make it easier to get hurt depending on the liquid. Any liquid you get in contact with replaces any previous liquid depending on how deep you went in said liquid. You can get wet up to chest height, at least based on what shows on your robe.

Dying made it feel like I wasn't making progress. The most frustrating part was being attacked by the undead lich in the first safe room. In another instance a worm dug it's way through the stone dividing the first and second area.

As much as I enjoyed getting wands, gold and abilities I can't recommend this game yet. Not until at least safe rooms are guaranteed safe. A big help would be being allowed to choose your starting wands and abilities after discovering new abilities.

Edit:
I would like to know what the devs intentions are for this game in the future if they plan to implement more control to the players or if they don't mind file editing or don't care about mods. I want to succeed playing this game within the rules and confines of the game without "cheating".

Edit 2:
It's 2023 and the game locks up when I enter a different zone. I've also deleted everything, including the save files in AppData and reinstalled everything.

Aloha, this is my review for Noita, the game that has consumed my life lately, I don't know if I can call it game as much as a symbolic alchemical riddle for the determined. Unfortunately the uninitiated cannot be told what Noita is, you just need to experience it for yourself.

The Good: Wild, weird, wonderful sandbox; secrets; excellent pixel graphics; secrets; addictive, one more run, format; explosions; easy to learn, hard to master game play; secrets; tonnes of mods to customise your game to your tastes; secrets.

The Bad: base game mechanics are a bit unfair and punish curiosity and exploration, which leads to unfair deaths that discourage new players; thankfully, mods can change that.

The Ugly: My Name is Xagatal, and I'm a Noitaholic... [Hi Xagatal...]

It's a fantastic game when you accept that sometimes your deaths are completely out of your control for BS reasons. There's a fairly steep learning curve - use of the wiki is a must to do much of anything beyond the main path.

The game is pretty cool regardless of whether you wind up being one of the types that sinks 30 hours into it or 500+ hours. Definitely expect to use guides for trying to do most anything other than a fairly basic run. In my 50 or so hours I've only beaten the game a couple times and started trying to explore the world more thoroughly. The game is complex, very open, and very punishing. A very appealing part of the game for many. Personally I would have preferred a little more direction and maybe some options to ease difficulty for some more casual runs. The permadeath is pretty heavy given how quickly some things can kill you and how long runs can last. Honestly, even with a guide some of the things to do seemed like they're a bit too involved for me to even give it an attempt. Nevertheless, I did have a blast playing the game, and maybe someday I'll come back to it and experience a little more of the breadth the game has to offer.

Really interesting game. 

If you enjoy games like Streets Of Rogue or Magicite, you should definetly try this one.

There are two downsides though:
- The game is pretty short. I completed it recently. It does have a more difficult mode though that unlocks after completion.
- How well you do is 50% skill and 50% luck. If you are lucky and find good traits, you will increase your chances drastically.

Correction after like 100+ more hours:
- The game is absolutely not short. There are so many secrets and the map is so much larger than you'd think.
- The game is not dependent on luck. It makes a difference, but the more you learn about the game mechanics, the better wands you'll be able to build in the beginning of your run. Skill has a huge impact on how long your run goes.

You'd think Noita is simple, but it's the complete opposite. So many secrets, so much to see and do... Noita will truly test your patience and will show you death in a million different beautiful ways.

This game does not hold your hand, at all, and it is very unforgiving.
You're thrown into the world with very few clues as to what you're supposed (or able) to do, and left to fend for yourself.

You die, and a lot.  The game is very fair, but sometimes you get Noita'd for ridiculous reasons.  Falling explosive boxes, ignited by Stendari above.  Taikasauva-bearing Hiisi.  Teleporting into lava.  Surprise propane tanks and falling KK-Tankki.  Matos and Lukki spawning angry Stevari/Skoude.  Surprise Ukko.  Olematon.  Matkija.  Midas.  Poly.

As you play, it'll happen less.  You'll dodge well.  You'll know not to get ukkoskivi'd, and wow to befriend/gank Steve.  You'll find Hämis and Lukki cute.  You'll know how to build wands.  How to explore.  How to transmute.  To see the non-existent.  To heal.  To travel.

There's some permanent progress, too: unlocked spells and perks for the determined, pillars for the brave, and cosmetics for the worthy.

Despite the game's apparent simplicity... you'll find the depth of lore, the number of secrets, the interactions between creatures and materials, the sheer amount of things you are capable of doing -- once you learn how -- is just incredible. Every playthrough can unveil something new, even after thousands of them.

The world is your egg!

The issue with Noita being placed in the roguelike genre is that its unorthodox structure stands out more than its roguelike elements, thus compared to other roguelikes out there, it might invite a large number of people expecting the traditional roguelike experience, which might either be positive or negative depending the mindset you are going into it. For the uninitiated, the progression of the game can be relatively slower initially, to being overwhelmingly complex once you progress enough.

[h1]Overview[/h1]

Noita practically presents no information or narrative on what to do other than your basic instincts of going in the cave and descending until you beat it. This is merely a smokescreen that instigates you to cross it and explore its boundaries, or more accurately its lack of.

It tests and rewards your creative capabilities by playing outside of its intended structure. The boundaries of this game are intentionally presented under the guise of a traditional roadblock you normally see in games, signifying that you cannot go past those bounds, when in reality there is no limit to it, quite in the literal sense.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The game employs a myriad of spells to be found or discovered under a surprisingly complex system of combinations in which you can utilize them giving different results, whenever positive or .... disastrously negative, either for you, for the game, or for your PC's ability to comprehend your spell's power output. Even with the amount of time i've played, there's quite a large number of spell combinations that i've yet to find.

It is well optimized for having every pixel simulated through a physics engine, and i played it relatively well with my busted GTX 760 on Linux through Proton. Every environment is completely destructible, no matter what you encounter. Various liquids and environmental hazards can have chemical reactions depending what they interact with. The liquid system is deceptively complex, as much like the spells, there are numerous combinations you can experiment with. 

There are MANY secrets, and many (un)fortunately quite obscure. There are types of secrets that had community efforts to be uncovered, meaning that some methods of finding secret places or items might require the usage of a wiki. The devs however have done a better job placing more hints compared to the game's earlier builds.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]

The difficulty of this game uses your own traditional knowledge of the roguelike structure against you. It does not test your pattern recognition or your ability to brute force your way to become stronger and stronger with unlocks until completion. Its trial and error is done primarily through experimentation and exploration, where your creative freedom dictates how you can to approach or avoid an encounter, and learn new information with every death. 

There is one aspect of this game where it makes or breaks for many. It is something that everyone will experience it as they play. No matter at what point in the game you are, no matter how overpowered you become, there will always be an unfair encounter where it will end your life. It can be anything, ranging from a nuclear explosion, to a few pixels of liquid that could potentially end your entire run.

The possibilities of busting your veins from sheer frustration are limitless. It is unfair, it is random, and it is understandable why many might not enjoy the inevitable chaotic nature that for the most part can't be prevented in this game, as it creates a lack of control on the player's part that could undo hours of grinding a run, which might understandably give an unappealing experience. This constant lingering danger is however what makes it exciting for others like me. There will always be a constant uncontrollable tension present, and your end will manifest itself sooner or later, whenever from your own actions, or outside of it.

Because of that, you do have invest a fair amount of time in order to properly acclimate to the environment of the game and its dangers, just so you can delay the inevitable, or dare i say, overcome it. Runs in Noita can take hours to complete if you want to true knowledge, meaning there is a process of tediousness that you will partake due to the sheer scale of the game's playground.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Easily one of my favorite indies. It itches my sense of exploration and encourages a creative approach by offering a limitless sandbox to play in. The Finns have done a wonderful job creating an unusually creative game.

This is the game of all times, the best roguelike I've played in a while and the coolest approach to alchemy I've seen in videogame. Chockfull of secrets, optimizations, routes and endings, this game offers a great experience, to be enjoyed in depth and for a long time.

The community for Noita is helpful and friendly, YouTube is full of videos explaining how to get a grip of basic concepts, but if you want the true experience and having no help while crashing through the holy mountain, the learning curve is never ending. No matter how many hours you have at the game, something will surprise you, two runs will hardly be the same and there's always something new to learn.

Be warned, though, this game is hard. Hard to learn, hard to master and hard to control. Things will explode and kill you, enemies from unseen corners will snipe you, you are not even safe from yourself in your quest for knowledge. The wand system allows for one of the coolest - if not the coolest - way I've seen in a videogame to experiment and tinker with your powers. 

Art and music are out of this world, offering a great dive into the game's atmosphere and lore. One of the best examples of stoner rock and alternative music in videogames.

Noita is a game that caught my eye with its stunning pixel physics, especially the way fire can spread and consume everything in its path. I was curious to see how this mechanic would affect the gameplay and the exploration of the procedurally generated world. I was not disappointed.

Noita is a roguelike game where you play as a wizard who can wield various wands and spells to fight enemies and manipulate the environment. The game is challenging and unforgiving, but also rewarding and addictive. Every run is different and full of surprises, as you never know what you will find in the next biome or what kind of wand or spell you will stumble upon.

The game encourages experimentation and creativity, as you can customize your wands and spells with different modifiers and combinations. You can also interact with the world in many ways, such as digging through the terrain, setting things on fire, creating floods, or even summoning black holes. The game’s physics engine is impressive and realistic, as every pixel has its own properties and behaviors. You can see how liquids mix, how materials burn, how explosions affect the surroundings, and how enemies react to different elements.

The game is not easy, though. You will die a lot, and sometimes in very frustrating ways. You might accidentally kill yourself with your own spells, or trigger a chain reaction of destruction that you can’t escape from. You might also encounter enemies that are too powerful or too fast for you to handle, or traps that are hard to spot or avoid. The game does not explain much to you, either. You have to figure out everything by yourself, from the effects of the spells to the secrets of the world. The game does not have a tutorial or a difficulty setting, so you have to learn by trial and error.

But that’s also part of the charm of Noita. The game is full of mystery and discovery, and every run is a new adventure. You never know what you will find or what will happen next. You might discover a hidden temple, a friendly NPC, a rare spell, or a powerful artifact. You might also encounter a boss, a curse, a trap, or a deadly enemy. The game keeps you on your toes and makes you adapt to the situation. You have to use your wits and your magic to survive and progress.

Noita is a game that I bought for the fire pixel physics, but ended up loving for the whole package. It’s a game that is challenging, rewarding, and fun. It’s a game that makes you feel like a real wizard, with all the power and the danger that comes with it. It’s a game that I highly recommend to anyone who likes roguelikes, magic, and physics. Noita is a game that is worth playing.

I've only played Noita for a few hours, but it's been a blast so far (pun intended). The combination of sandbox-y physics and roguelite elements makes Noita a joy to play, even though I haven't gotten farther than a few stages in. The spell system was a bit difficult to wrap my head around -- as you have to take into account not only spells but the wands and modifiers you use with them -- but it's incredibly rewarding to find a combination which fills an area with oil. Oil? What's so special about that? This, my friend, is where the physics/simulation aspect of Noita comes into play. Since every pixel is simulated, that pool of oil we made can be lit on fire (WATCH THEM BURN MWAHAHAHA). There's an abundance of flammable materials in Noita; as a bit of a pyromaniac, I love to watch the world burn. What makes it even better is that plenty of other materials exist which you can use to vanquish your enemies (I won't get into them here because the review would be a 20 page essay). And, the physics that everything follows is excellent. If a game uses a default physics engine, it's easy to tell, which hurts immersion. That's not the case in Noita; when you punt an explosive barrel of toxic sludge across a cavern, it feels believable. Sometimes, I'll sit around and do sandbox-y experiments because it's that fun to mess around in the game engine.

Despite its fun sandbox and roguelite elements, Noita isn't a game for everyone. As a beginner (and likely later on too), you'll die. A lot. For fans of roguelites and roguelikes, this is expected; RNG is a significant factor in how long you'll survive. If you're new to the genre, temper your expectations. The game will screw you over and put you into unfair situations, kill you, and that super cool wand you just got will be gone. That's the reality of roguelites; the journey is more important than the destination.

I'm excited to see how Noita's development continues. The devs recently added mod support, which is of course excellent for the community. As Noita is an early access game, I won't give a 100% recommend yet (because the devs could abandon the game or eff it up big time), but as far as early access goes, it's a very enjoyable and promising game.

My reason for not recommending this game is simple, and due to the fact that health in the early game is a scarce, finite resource until you are several hours into the run. The value judgement the game wants you to make in each enemy encounter is to play patiently, slowly, and safely to prevent any kind of damage accruing over time. There is skill expression in the decisions you make and your knowledge of the wand system, but having to treat the smallest of encounters as if you're on 1 HP gets boring very, very quickly.

To me, the game was not "fun" until I lucked into a source of infinite healing, meaning I could engage enemies head-to-head instead of meekly peeking around corners and sniping at them from half a screen away until they were dead. Combat felt more interactive that way, and there were still threats I needed to be careful of even if I could regenerate after the battle. But infinite healing makes the game a cakewalk. A dozen hours later into the run, I was practically unkillable outside of a few edge cases. The game had turned into a glorified wand-building sandbox.

I really wanted to like this game, and I wish there was a middle ground -- maybe along the lines of a small shield that regenerates outside of combat.

One of the coolest games I have ever played. The devotion to simulated particle physics meaning that /every single is pixel is a simulated particle/, is one of the most brilliant ideas for a game I've ever heard of. 

Noita is pure chaos, you will rarely- if ever- feel like you are "in control" on your average Noita run. The game sometimes kind of decides that you're just dead now, sort of like Darkest Dungeon does, but playing conscientiously and generally being carefully will keep you alive long enough to get to the next rest area, spend half and hour building wands, only to immediately get dumpster'd in the next area.

Noita is a Finnish word meaning "witch", but also undoubtedly the best game that has come from Finland thus far and dare I say the best Roguelike game out there.

As you start the game, you wake up outside next to a mine holding 2 random wands and a potion. There's also some stones which tell you the controls, but that's as far as Noita goes in terms of helping you. Everything else? Figure it out lmao. This game is very unforgiving and frustrating, so if you cannot deal with dying over and over again because of your own stupid choices, completely random shieit and trial and error lessons, then this is not a game for you.

There's also a very unique mechanic in Noita. Every pixel is simulated, meaning that every pixel can be interacted with in a way or another. It's great, but just keep in mind that it also means that a few pixels can be all it takes to kill you.

Outside of the aforementioned simulated pixels mechanic and the classic roguelikes elements, I would say a major pull for this game is its wand building. The game features an absurdly high amount of different spells (totalling to 393), which you can combine into almost anything. You want a spell which nukes the entire level? Check. You want a spell which fills the entire screen and crashes your game? Check. You want to deal a million damage in a single shot and turn everything to dust particles? Check and it is also an achievement. The possibilities really are limitless, because the spells react in unique ways based on their order and what other spells they are combined with.

And finally let's not forget the secrets. There are a ton of them, some minor and some big. I'll be honest some of these are so obscure that I really do not expect anyone to pull these off without guide, so do not feel bad about looking these up. Also fall back on this advice if you ever feel like you've seen everything, there's bound to be something you've missed.

The spells and combinations thereof, help keep the game interesting, along with the discovery of the world and the in-game lore. Noita is incredibly smart and fun, and almost 5,000 deaths later I'm still nowhere near done playing it!

One warning though: spell effects will kill you, thus resulting in being "Noita'd", and several times I have cackled tremendously as it happened. You will be Noita'd, just accept it and have fun with it.

Noita is an [i]insanely difficult[/i] video game. Not in a "X is the Dark Souls of Y" sense. But in a seemingly random, punishing way. You will die. Again and again and again and again. And the sooner you accept that, the sooner you'll realize the beauty of it all:

[i]That's exactly what you're here for.[/i] The looming threat of having all your progress reset over one mere miscalculation creates an oppressive atmosphere comparable to horror games. Every time you find somethign new, you'll be scared. And yet... You'll carry on. Because you'll want to find out what's beyond all those obstacles. You'll want to push this game to its absolute limits. Curiosity may kill the cat, sure, but no one can deny its allure.

But you won't blindly charge through all hazards. You'll study them first. Hesitate. Plan ahead. You'll learn to respect every single pixel on your screen.

Even though Noita is simply a 2D dungeon crawler with physics akin to those powder games on the Play Store, it will burn the concept of Equivalent Exchange into your mind. You want something? [i]Anything?[/i] Then you better be ready to sacrifice a piece of yourself in return.

I'm gonna add a quick addendum in here about the system requirements. This game wants as much single thread performance as you can give it. Minimum req says "Dual Core CPU, Intel i5" listen to the i5 part not the dual core part, I'd probably say 4th gen or newer is a reasonable starting point. 

Recommended spec says "The more cores the better" which also seems wrong but better encapsulates the idea of what you want. I'm not a dev, IDK what's going on in the background, but I'm getting utilization of about 7% when the game is being pushed to the limit, out of 12 cores that would mean it's almost maxing 1. Seems to me that we would favor the most single thread performance as possible, I previously had an i9-10850k and Noita can bring that down with physics calculations, now I have a Xeon W-3235 which functionally isn't that different, so favor stronger cores on as new an architecture as possible. Barring some significant advancement in CPU technology I think having a frame rate drop during a god run is probably unavoidable (though there are now 4 gens after what I have ATOW so take that for what it's worth)

After hitting 100 hours I still haven't beaten the game and can barely make a decent wand. Still super fun and the game has a ton to offer in terms of replay value. If you haven't played much or haven't played any at all, then you should look up the Noita map. It does contain some spoilers but it gives you an idea of how massive this game actually is. This is a game that I'm sure I will never even be able to do everything and that is halfway because of RNG. The game is so much deeper than it first seems when you first start playing. Highly recommend this to anyone thinking about picking it up. 

Just buy it now or on sale. It is worth it either way.

EDIT - After 400 hours and a good amount of wins I can honestly say this is the best single player rouge like game. The only reason this doesn't get best overall single player game is that there are to many different types of games but this is my personal favorite and has been since I found it. I still dont even have a full understanding of all the wand crafting nor have I unlocked all the spells enemies or perks. Albeit I am getting pretty close but I still have a ton to figure out. The game has literal infinite replay value. So long as you can get creative and like to experiment you can make whatever kind of wand you want. I wish i could type out all the things I love about this game but the list would keep going and going and going. 

My conclusion is that more people need to play this game and give it a shot. It has much more than meets the eye if you can get past the first hours of sucking and dying over and over. The more love that this game gets the more updates and attention it will receive. It has by far the best community of any game I have ever played which is a huge bonus. Tons of people willing to help you learn and understand the mechanics and tips of the game.

One of the most creative sandbox games you'll ever play. An ocean of spells, perks, enemies and secrets to keep you engaged for hundreds of hours, and a healthy modding scene (yes, you can play as amogus or neco arc) to boot. 

The game is hard and punishing, with little to no permanent upgrades (except spell unlocks), so how much time you put into understanding the game translates into better runs in the future.

9/10, crab certified game
Look, if you like roguelikes and magic and stuff, this is for you. this was typed just shortly before getting Noita'd.

Death is natural and inevitable.
To return undeterred is divine.
Blessed are the scholars.

Even though Noita has a lot of really cool stuff in it, the game is also probably one of the most frustrating games I've played, I would put it on the same level as Darkest Dungeon where it should be fun, but it's off-key in a way that turns what should be a powerful symphony, into just a keening warble that penetrates my brain and makes me haemorrhage internally.

So you start off with some absolutely trash wand. You can't do anything about it. So you go down since you just started and you don't know anything. You wander around, progress, maybe die a little and you're thinking well that's okay, I'll get further. Maybe you do get further. But you don't really learn anything.

And by that of course I mean, you don't learn anything actually valuable. Noita is an impenetrable game and even when you do figure out what something is, it still doesn't teach you how to take advantage of it. This is a game based on secrets. It is no exaggeration to say pretty much every single aspect of the game is some sort of secret the game expects you to figure out on your own.

If you play this game in English too I am fairly certain there are deliberately misleading tooltips and so on just so the game can be that much more 'mysterious'.

Noita gets pretty quickly frustrating when you end up repeating the same couple areas over and over again. It gets really frustrating when you realize that further exploration hinges on getting the 'right' perks and the 'right' wands and spell effects. It gets downright hateful when you learn things like, the devs added new perks in an update post-release that dilute the useful perks with many many terrible ones. That the perk pool itself (or perk 'deck' maybe) is so absurdly unbalanced that you can sometimes sift through a dozen and see none you really want or that will strongly help you.

You can play for hours and not see any useful or particularly fun wands. And that's this whole game. Noita is a game where you explore, find absolutely atrocious wands with limited and terrible capacity and useless effects and spells on them, and then you can't even edit them unless you find one perk (out of like 60) that lets you change wands anywhere. So then you just keep going, hoping maybe around the next corner you'll find a new wand that isn't terrible. You don't. Instead you find some enemy that shoots at you off-screen or something like that.

And then when you die you just have to start over and repeat everything you just did all over again in pretty much the most tedious way possible. You have to sift through the first couple areas you've seen a dozen times, again. You have to make sure you don't miss any health upgrades or the potential for a useful wand or potion. And you need to do it because if you don't get at least a decent start you're not going to get far enough anywhere to get any good wands.

Even if you happen to like, get really really strong, and clear the game, well. Congratulations. You beat the game. Now what? There's absolutely no direction or anything after that so then I guess you just meander around the rest of the game, possibly find wands that are terrible, and maybe die to some random enemy type you have never seen before that does a damage type you aren't immune to so you swear at the game and stop playing for the day.

Or maybe you do what I am sure most people who reviewed this positively have done and just look up other stuff you can do on the wiki so you can just know what is even expected of you.

And that's Noita. It basically has every single roguelike problem ever and you're also expected to do like 12 hour runs that end in dismal failure while you wander around a world you don't understand and probably don't have too much interest in because nothing really makes sense and all the things in the game exist just to fight you. Or maybe you beat the game and then go "okay cool" at the totally and completely unsatisfying 'conclusion'. I guess it expects you to find some other different ending that isn't 'the ending' that most people get.

Maybe there's like another 100 hours or something you can spend meandering around the world in hopes of stumbling by random chance on things you can do that you haven't seen yet.

Or maybe it's all just a waste of your time. I'm going with that option because I am done gaslighting myself into thinking "maybe the next run, I will have fun".

This game probably has some of the best puzzles and secrets in the history of gaming. With its roots in finnish mythology, the world and creatures all play a part in the game's incredible worldbuilding. The main goal is to descend into the caves and retrieve the Sampo, a legendary artefact that has the ability to mill flour, salt and gold out of thin air. The game is very challenging, and has a unique permadeath mechanic. The game also has very customizable wands that can do everything from heal you to explode you,  summon portals, play music, summon rocks and teleport you. And did i mention that nearly every material in the game has advanced alchemical properties? You can combine different liquids or powders to create various potions including but not limited to ambrosia, berserkium, invisibilium, healthium, liquid fire, pheromone, polymorphine and concentrated mana. The game also has piss potions, good combat, and lots of content.

~700 hours later I can confirm that I still adore this game. The difficulty can be a bit frustrating, as it can be a bit too punishing when you first explore through the game, but if you can live with the feeling of a chaotic world with potentially run-ending surprises lurking behind any odd corner, this has to be the roguelike with the most player-agency I've ever had the pleasure of enjoying.
Sometimes the rng can pull a fast one on you, by simply not giving you anything you can use for progressing the game in a natural manner, but some experience and creativity can usually amend this to a certain extent. Late-game you can avenge your own deaths by declaring war on the game itself and become disgustingly powerful, yet I've found myself simply enjoying the gameplay-loop of the main path, with the odd deviation every now and then. The physics and destructibility of (as far as I know) literally anything unlucky enough to stand in your way means that you can get quite creative in how you approach traversal and combat. 
Leading up the the release and for the first few months, Nolla pushed the one update after the other (somewhere between one or two meaningful updates, not just singular changes, a week). And somewhat recently, they have implemented a few other impactful changes to both potion-mechanics and cheesy strategies. In my opinion the changes are very welcome, as most of the cheese they removed was tedious and repetitive to perform anyways.

This game can be frustrating, and I've had multiple friends question my sanity when I admit my love for this gem of a game, but if this game happens to rub you the right way, the most difficult part will be putting it down. For me this game has become a zen happy-place that requires you to think through wand-builds, what items to keep for potential rewards further down the depths, and how to maximise the utility of anything you can get your grubby hands on. For an impressive amount of hours, you will keep learning and changing your approach to this seemingly unending rabbithole from the one game-changing crumb of knowledge to the next.

I have 297 hours now, and this game is incredible in how it rewards you. When you start, it's grueling. Everything kills you, and you can't even make it half way to the bottom floor. When you begin to understand how the game's mechanics work, and how to manipulate them to your advantage, it feels like you've become a real wizard that can break the laws of physics to suit your needs. "Getting to the bottom floor" is not even your concern anymore, because you're too busy going to different dimensions or unraveling the greater mysteries of the world.

I recommend playing this game on your own to see what you can find naturally, but if you get frustrated, don't be afraid to keep the wiki open to look up things that confuse you. Also, don't shy away from mods. I downloaded a mod that changes my robe color for every run, and another which gives me a free perk at the start because it took the edge off of dying so often. It made starting a new run more exciting.

Step 1: Press new game
Step 2: find a good wand
Step 3: Explore and make the mines burn into ashes
Step 4: get over ran by creatures while you're surrounded with fire
Step 5: find a way out of that situation
Step 6: Try to make a smart play with an explosive and kill yourself by accident
Step 7: Repeat the whole process

So far, great gameplay. Lots of customizability, the different effects are dope. I'm a little confused on how the spell crafting system works, as there's not much player guidance yet. I had splitting projectiles equipped on a wand, which would duplicate TNT, but not regular bolts or black holes? Might just be a bug. It needs a long way to go with balancing issues, some enemies nearly instakill you while others seem pretty much harmless. Also, don't fire a black hole into the temple wall, it immediately ends your run, which is pretty awful in my opinion, especially for a roguelike. Especially if it happens accidentally when you're testing out skills of which you don't know what they do yet. Kinda leaves a bad taste after playing a few fun runs. I'll recommend it, but still needs a lot of work! Seriously hoping the devs will keep up development, and not drop it like its hot.

i believe that noita is probably one of the best games ever made, if you don't value your time. in order to get good enjoyment out of the game, sacrificing time is required. this starts to border on unreasonable when you need to spend hours getting out of the earlygame "jail", and a single mistake sends you back to the start. if it gets better with all the ingame knowledge acquired, this isn't known to me as i refuse to spoil myself to the game nor wish to bruteforce all the possible solutions for certain mechanics.

that time expended racks up extremely fast without either modding the game to make the conditions to learn things easier, cheating the permadeath system by backing up your save or spoiling the game experience by using the community-driven wiki. additionally, it sometimes doesn't feel like knowledge is truly power with certain bad starts. i know it's a funny roguelike trope to just get bad starts dealt by the game, but if you reach the fourth zone and get little resource, it is usually faster to restart the run unless you just want a run W instead of trying to hunt secrets.

the gameplay is fun and when something clicks or you get actionable knowledge, it is extremely satisfying - such as basic alchemy for removing toxic sludge. wand crafting, likewise, is fun - basically a mini deckbuilder within the combat system. the enemies are also quite good, with the later ones acting as a soft deck check, if you wish to explore the secrets of noita. the time spent during progression however, such as the abysmally slow earlygame, is not. you spend a high amount of time in churn. imo, noita would be significantly better as an RPG with how unforgiving the game can be. the roguelike elements, specifically permadeath; and to a lesser extent, the spell weighting system, serve to be a deliberate pain point and causes a lot of start-and-stop.

if you hold no qualms about removing tedium or degrading the game experience by looking up resources, this is a good game *framework* for the player to customize as they wish.

for context, i haven't bothered killing the final boss a single time because i've been more invested in exploring the game world. i've killed [spoiler]four of the world bosses[/spoiler] so far. i've found out [spoiler]how to empower the voiceless key[/spoiler] and found a handful of orb locations. i don't consider myself far in.

No other game consistently makes my jaw drop in reaction to its sheer absurdity the way that Noita does. Whether it's a wand that just blows up everything in a 3 screen radius, or it's dying by accidentally firing a lightning spell while underwater, the emergent systems and interactions in Noita will keep you on your toes for all of your time with this game.

The world of this game does not make you feel like you are the main character. You're not some hero out to save the world. In Noita, you are a feeble alchemist, struggling against the gods and the world around you as you venture deeper and deeper, motivated only by a lust for deeper knowledge and riches. The way the secrets in Noita are designed reinforce this feeling. They aren't spoonfed to the player, and the average player will likely miss 95% of the content that this game has to offer. This reinforces the player sentiment of exploring a world that existed before you entered it, and that will exist long after you've been burnt to a crisp for the 100th time.

This is a punishing game by all definitions of the word, but it will reward you with a neverending stream of secrets to discover and spells to master if you decide to dedicate your time to understanding its systems.

(You can also play with mods to soften the learning curve!)

Takes a bit of getting into, and feels a bit tough a lot of the time, but still a lot of fun. Fiddling with wands is interesting, and when you get the classic roguelike feeling of coming into an overpowered set up, it makes it feel like it was your ingenuity. 

Moving around and shooting and navigating the physics based world and hazards is also very satisfying and super unique.

You only really need to know 2 things about this game: 1. it does not hold your hand at all 2. it is unforgiving.

Noita is a game that throws you in on the deep end with zero guidance. If you hate feeling like you have no idea what is going on then this might not be the game for you. That being said, Noita is full of adventure and wonder. Every time you feel like you understand something the game expands on it multiple times. It does so to the point of being a little bit ridiculous. I don't think anyone could ever actually fully explore the game without looking at guides or Noita wiki. 

The lack of explanation is partially responsible for why the game is so unforgiving. Once you learn and develop methods of dealing with tough enemies or zones, the game gets a little bit more playable. Before this though, you will struggle to complete even the first area. Even when you learn to beat most enemies Noita has a level of uncontrolable chaos that will be responsible for many deaths. Because of this the game is super unforgiving. You will get whittled down with no heals and struggle to find good spells which will ultimately lead to the run ending many many times. 

While the game is rough for new players, if you choose to stick around Noita has one of the best implementations of magic in all of gaming. The wand/spell system is ingenious and unique. If you are smart enough, you'll be able to craft wands capable of nearly anything.

noita should not be a roguelike. because the game is so complex, there are far too many things you need to remember to not die, and you need to be very precise and careful. you get very emotionally invested in a run, because they're so long, and you end up dying, more often than not, not to a huge epic evil monster, but because you scrolled your mouse to equip your water flask, but accidentally equipped your electric wand for a split second, killing you instantly in the water pool you jumped into. because you got stuck in level geometry and got melee'd to death. because you got knocked into an explosive you couldn't have seen. while each run being different is usually a boon in the roguelike genre, in noita it is not, because you never really know how you're going to end up dying, either it actually be your fault, or some arbitrary, frequently buggy, randomness.

Noita is a game whose charms can take a while to shine through. I've tried and bounced off of Noita a half dozen times since I first picked it up in Early Access. I loved the look, the feel, and the per-pixel simulation, but I couldn't get into it.

Then, recently, I finally did. And it's glorious.

The key to enjoying Noita is being willing to sacrifice everything for the sake of learning and experimentation. Just picked up a wand that insta-casts Giga Black Hole? Give it a try! On your next run, you'll know how it works.

If the punishment for learning is too severe for you, though, I'd recommend checking out the Workshop mods, particularly the one that adds checkpoints between levels. The game is best enjoyed as the roguelike it was intended to be, but mods can really help you figure out the game until you're ready to try it for real.

This game is fun. At first. When you're still learning how the game plays, laughing at silly deaths (perhaps you fell in lava, or experimented with a wand) it's fun; then that fades. Yes I did get 100 hours out of this game, yes that makes the money technically worth it. But at the same time, I really wish I had that time back.

This game is a massive time sink. The biggest problem with the game (the one keeping it from perhaps being more popular than it is) is its balancing issues that make the game so rightfully frustrating. The second issue is its habit of being a dopamine feedback loop. You boot up a run, die to something you couldn't help (usually luck based nonsense like finding no wands, usable spells, or health upgrades) and then start over. You do that enough times and eventually you will roll the dice just so, so that it lands perfectly, and you get a good run. But that takes time --- a lot of time. And you know what takes even more time? Committing to a good run. Because with enough patience you can mitigate those bad odds until you have something salvageable. But that's only if you take five minutes to trek over a wasteland, a boring, dry wasteland. Plus everything else you would have to do.

The second thing holding this game back from being beautiful, is its aforementioned balancing issues. When you start you are given one damage wand, and one big boom wand. I consider the big boom wand to be balanced, as every spell it can be loaded with is helpful in some way. It's the d.p.s wand that's the problem. Now, what's preferred? A wand that can kill just about every enemy in the first layer with one hit, or one that takes maybe three? Obviously the former. But that's the range you are given. A completely unfair range that is honestly a small drop in the pond, but it just adds to the unfair role that luck has in determining how well a run goes, instead of skill. And there's more to be said about enemy damage numbers on top of this as well.

There's probably a lot more that could be said against this game, and some for it as well. For instance, the sense of exploration you get when the game is new, is rather novel and fun. But as you learn that getting the proper dice rolls to be able to even explore most of those areas is so slim, that novel feeling fades. Obviously, this game held me for 100 hours, but I honestly that was from the fact that it has such addictive gambling like qualities.

In the end, it feels like the developers spent more time making a puzzle, than an actual game.

TL;DR too much luck based stuff, too much time waste.

Amazing design for a game.  Most games that have this sort of "hardcore" type mode where a death means you start over, rely on giving you upgrades you can purchase each time you die, so that next time you can progress further.  This game however, relies on the player learning more about the world they're in.  I really like the take on discovery in this game, where you're constantly learning more about how the world works, and how you can use what is around to your advantage,  Learning how the spells interact with each other, testing the wands you create yourself, finding what perks can help with the spells you have, figuring out what liquids you want to take with you in your flasks for future use, and so much more.  There are probably plenty of people that would get frustrated with the game at the start, because it can seem very difficult, but for those who like a challenge, there is so much to discover in this game.

As quoted from the game itself
"The sacrifice of oneself to the pursuit of knowledge
Is the highest tribute to the gods."

To me, it's the type of game where I'm always wanting to learn more, and there just seems to always be even more to discover within the game.

If I had to say something negative about the game it would be that there is a few too many unpredictable deaths within the game, and they definitely could be toned down a bit.  Even after knowing what I'm going to come across, sometimes there is just nothing that can be done to avoid all the attacks without making the game tedious/boring.  Not everyone wants to tunnel/dig everywhere, but it is by far the safest method of navigation.  It simply allows the player to skip a lot of enemies they may have had to face, but I think it would have been better if the player could more reliably deal with the enemies directly.

Incredibly challenging platformer where you explore caverns and fight enemies using wands and potions found throughout the levels. Progressively gets harder as you collect gold to buy spells and customize your wands at the end of each level. Environment is completely destructible with free flowing liquids (water, acid, oil, etc.) and contains many hazards and enemies that will try and kill you. If you die, that's it. No checkpoints and extra lives are found as one of the three random abilities you can choose from at each level. I was lucky enough to get invisibility and sneak to the end only to realize you can't cheese it that way. It's fun. A boss randomly teleported me in the middle of a lava lake and I died. Use teleportation at your own risk and be sure to carry a water potion!

I currently have almost 1400 hours in this game I am sure I will hit 1600 no problem. This is one of the most intricate, hilariously frustrating, and surprisingly charmimg wizard game. 

  It has so much depth that without the community surrounding it, it would take someone potentially a decade to discover and and solve all the secrets surprises this game has to offer. Two of which have still yet to be solved with people working around the clock trying to figure them out.

  The amount of reactions/interactions between the environment, substances, elements, and downright pure wizardry you can play around with is what really hooked me into this game and brought me back so many times. The modding community continues to pump out content if you want to add something fresh but the base game is so full of content that still, to this day is being added to will give you well over hundreds of hours of play. 

  First review I've wrote in more than 12 years and I cannot recommend this game enough. Shoutout to the small team that put their heart and soul into something they love. It shows so much and it gives so much back to you as a gamer. 10/10 AAA title for $20 or less.

This game is a masterpiece. I say that in the truest, most genuine sense of the word. This is the work of people who have absolutely mastered their craft, and it shows. "Masterpiece" doesn't mean "perfect" -- but it's damn close.

Are there bugs? Yes. (Surprisingly few, though.)
Are there balance issues? Sure.
Will you get frustrated and curse the very gods when utter bullshit is thrown at you without warning? Absolutely.
Is all of this a part of the totality of the experience that makes it so compelling? You better believe it.

Not only is the gameplay excellent, but the mystery behind everything is captivating, and the technical marvel that is this game's engine is absolutely unbelievable. I still have no idea how the hell they managed to make a game capable of simulating so many millions of pixels with such ease in spite of the immense complexity of possible interactions, even with the chunk system dividing the world up into manageable blocks. And I first played on a now 11-year-old PC without any serious performance issues barring some exceptional circumstances. It's incredible.

One of the most emphatic themes of the entire game is that magic is powerful and mysterious, but also extremely [i]dangerous[/i]. Reckless use can and will quickly lead to your demise. Yet for those who do manage to successfully harness its abilities without self-destruction, it is entirely possible to become godlike -- and that's no exaggeration.

That said, it comes at a high price, and it's a difficult road to travel. I normally don't like permadeath in games, and I honestly do recommend playing -- at least at first -- with a quicksave utility since there's no native, built-in save system, which is my one and only complaint. That will allow you to learn things a bit easier and, probably, actually get through the whole main loop of the game. But I can't really say I fault the game for going the roguelike route, either, and I recommend you refrain from backing up your save once you start exploring the deeper mysteries of the world. Trust me, it really does enhance the experience. Unless, of course, your time is very limited, then by all means savescum away without shame. Whatever it takes to experience this amazing world.

There are countless [i]incredibly[/i] cryptic puzzles to solve here -- most of which I'd never have managed to figure out on my own. But thanks to folks who datamined and analyzed everything they could dig up (which the developers seem to fully encourage), it's possible to experience world-altering cosmic mayhem firsthand. You just might want to look up some guide videos unless you're the type who likes to really dig deep and experiment with very limited clues. But even once you understand [i]what[/i] to do, actually managing to do it successfully is another matter entirely.

On top of all that, there are dozens of high-quality mods to further expand and customize the experience. There's basically no reason I can think of to NOT recommend Noita to anyone who likes combat, experimentation, creativity, exploration, deep lore, extreme replay value, or serious challenge. It has everything, and does [i]all[/i] of it [i]extremely[/i] well.

Ok after 80 hours of play I must say I love this game. Its unique from most rogue like out there, with so much specs for players that really want to get completely technical with wands and spells. Finding a good modifier in this game is like a Christmas gift honestly. Understanding what the stats and the mechanics of the game has been incredible and really rewarding at times. 

The huge map and the high amount of things to do will keep you busy for ages. Mini bosses with different strategies to beat them, and even the "end" of the game is not the end. Unlike most of the rogue like games out there once you beat the final boss you finish that run. But with the proper spells you could just leave the boss arena and continue playing. This game processes a lot to the point that I just came here due to how the developer utilized pixel simulation whit liquids, smoke, and even the ground, but now I surely have found great interest in the content of this game.

I also wanted to write this review as a hail marry to express one of my discontents about the game. The enemies render view, as readding in some of the forums most of the communiity will respond to a failed run with a "You got noited" and for most of the times I will say...whelp that's noita for ya! However I do also think that some enemies can notice you without you noticing they've seen you. For some enemies that make a sound queue you'll know what to do, but for some you just see a projectile coming out of nowhere with no understanding of it. If I were to ask for one change is that some of the enemies form the earlier levels had to have to be in your field of view to shoot a projectile at you. 

Apart from this, I really recommend noita its gu gem.

I was in a safe zone when a randomly spawned worm broke something, causing the game to blame me for "angering the gods" and spawn an uber-powerful skeleton to eliminate me. Challenge is one thing, but I had absolutely no control over that outcome. Fuck that run, I guess? Might as well just kill my character at spawn to save me the trouble.

Even ignoring that blatant issue, Noita requires me to gamble wayyyy too much time on the vague hope that I'll get a good run and finally re-experience the game's incredible highs. You'll never see most of the awesome spells and cracked-out wands visible in the trailers because you'll be too busy getting stunned by random bullets, plummeting 1,000 feet, and landing on some explosive barrels that coincidentally happen to be on fire.

When Noita is good, it's REALLY good. Those moments don't come around frequently enough, though, and I just don't have the patience to dump any more hours into a bunch of junk runs before I can experience another great one.

Noita - A Brief Review by Janus/Lechonk

(25 hours played so far)

- I've been playing 25+ hrs, and I still have have no idea whats happening 95% of the time
- Physics based Roguelike make monkey brain go Hur Hur Hur
- Very wierd mysterious world that doesn't explain much, I'm avoiding Wikis because I'm stubborn
- Made by Finnish Developers, the enemies in the game have hard to pronounce Finnish names
- Avoid this game if you dislike the Finnish language. I haven't seen Lauri Markkanen so he may not be in this game
- Fire and explosions are dangerous you will learn that the hard way
- More wands in this game than Harry Potter, if that kind of thing turns you on
- A wand that shoots ricoshetting Buzzsaw blade sounds awesome...but ended very badly for me
- You'll figure the lower level enemies out, but they will still kill you more often than they should
- You can drink various liquids, which can have both positive and negative effects. I enjoy drinking the blood of my enemies
- I know I've mentioned Fire already but...take extra care around flammable and explosive things
- The enemy who looks like the devil (I call him The Arsonist) is a massive douchebag
- Don't pat the skulldoggies

Only 10 hours....in not many days. This game will kill you, give you slight hope, then rip the spine right out of that hope and feed it to you.

On a more serious note. The game-play loop is simple, but very fun. You explore randomly generated caves/caverns that each have a theme. You can levitate around (on a timer) and have pretty free movement. Your goal is to survive to the bottom of the cavern while gaining as many resources as possible (gold, wands, spells). Upon reaching the rest point, you can get new spells/wands (cost gold), mix and match the spells your wands cast (to make crazy/dangerous combos), and gain a perk for your character. Then off to the next cavern.

There is very little in the way of a tutorial or instructions, and that is a good thing. The point of the game is to explore through trial and error. What happens if I eat this? What does this spell combination do? What is that red dirt over there? What does this potion do? 

Many times, your curiosity will end in death, but the knowledge will have made you stronger. Other times your trial/curiosity will pay off in a very satisfying way.

I have only made it to level 5 (I think) and I have died countless times...many were accidental suicides when testing a new wand. Each death has been pretty unique. While I have been killed in many unfair ways (forcibly tp'd into a nest of monsters, attacked by a god, acid falling on head...etc.) I have never felt frustrated or upset by the deaths. Usually you just laugh and go again.

I've played this game for 114 hours, but this review isn't about me, rather, it's about a friend.

He was in a call trying to prove to me that nothing could go wrong while casting completely random spells. I tried convincing him he was wrong, unfortunately our hero didn't listen. His fatal flaw of hubris led him to casting a nuke, which he somehow arced at an angle that didn't kill him. This was his first warning. Following this, he cast two random spells that did literally nothing. He then proceeded to say, "one more time - just for good measure."

It was at this moment, he just so happened to roll the spell that instantly turns everything in its radius into gold. Including you.

Hubris is a fatal flaw kids don't forget that.

Very hard, but every death feels like your fault. Progression is slow, very slow, but each new progression feels amazing. 10/10, would recommend.

Yes, I have nearly 50 hours in this game. But _many_ runs tend to end due to circumstances outside of the player's control, such as enemies being able to one-shot you from outside of the screen with projectiles or even large explosions that move faster than you can be expected to see.

Runs can be fun, especially when you are ridiculously lucky. The wand-building mechanic is deep and can lead to interesting gameplay, but it's hard for me to get into runs when I have to accept the high possibility that my performance will likely not affect my chance of reaching the end of the game.

Due to a lot of the difficulty being out of the players control, as well as runs varying greatly in length, I can't recommend this game to non-masochists.

ABOUT THIS GAME
Noita is a magical action roguelite set in a world where every pixel is physically simulated. Fight, explore, melt, burn, freeze and evaporate your way through the procedurally generated world using spells you've created yourself. Explore a variety of environments ranging from coal mines to freezing wastelands while delving deeper in search for unknown mysteries.


Pixel-based physics: Every pixel in the world is simulated. Burn, explode or melt anything. Swim in the blood of your foes! Enter a simulated world that is more interactive than anything you've seen before.

Your own magic: Combine spells to create your own magic as you delve deeper into the caverns. Use magic to crush your enemies and manipulate the world around you.

Procedurally generated world: Explore a unique world every time you play. Discover new environments as you adventure deeper.



Action roguelite: Death is permanent and always a looming threat. When you die, don’t despair, use what you’ve learned to get further on your next adventure.

Noita is being developed by Nolla Games, a company set up by 3 indie developers, all of whom have worked on their own projects in the past.

The three gents in question are:

Petri Purho
Petri is best known as the creator of Crayon Physics Deluxe. In his youth he also made a lot tiny freeware games. He has also made a bunch of board games, but he hasn't told about it to anyone. So please keep it a secret.

Olli Harjola
Olli is known for the award-winning, mind-bending sci-fi puzzler The Swapper. Besides indie games, he also dabbles in music, live visuals and making programming languages.

Arvi Teikari
Arvi is also known as Hempuli. Over the years he has released a lot of tiny experimental games, so many in fact that he is unaware of all of them. One of the games he remembers making is Baba Is You.

If you like Roguelikes with infinite worldgen, uncountable unlockable items and amazing artstyle? Well boy o' boy, have you stumbled along the right game! Noita, a game where you delve into the depths, find wands, create spells, and kill enemies as you make your way floor by floor to the final boss. Now that you've beaten said "Final Boss", congrats! You're done with the tutorial XD. I've only had noita for about a week, but I've already sunk over 80 hours into the game, there's so much to explore and do, so many different options for what kind of run and how to start it, and its not even that incredibly punishing for a roguelike, while still keeping the same core elements that make it fun and rewarding in the end. In the last week, Noita went from being in my wishlist to replacing LoZ : A Link to The Past as my number one game, something that hasnt changed in over 14 years. 10/10, will be easily playing this my whole life.

Next step ahead can be totally fatal.

In this game, You will get down and dirty.Either You like it or not.
Many fluids of different sort will ooze on your PIXELISED unfortunate Mage hero.
Oh poor him, he will suffer terrible fate in repetitive loop if you buy this game, but I assure you, you will ask for more.
So sit down, pop a soda or a beer, load the game and relax, 
Be patient, that is the key to survive in this game!!
Let the destruction burn ahead and create new path before going forward and die in the heat of PIXELS destruction.

with recipe you experiment on like a idiotic alchemist would surely do: wrong ingredients in the wrong hands!

Show and don't tell.
This game has a story, but that story is only revealed over many learned lessons, in a vibrant and mysterious world
that you are completely free to explore (and die in). [b]Rarely does a game reward pushing the envelope as much as this game does[/b], and is always prepared to deliver in spades new possibilities (instant death) to those who embrace curiosity.

Noita perpetually finds ways to subvert and exceed what it has conditioned you to expect. Full of Challenging trials, in a world always bigger than it seems, punctuated by the inherent slapstick comedy of the emergent dangers you will find within it. the roguelike tenseness only escalates as you learn more about the game.

This game is a good buy for those who like a potentially challenging experience, or who like the idea of being a mysterious magical entity, anyone who likes exploding pixels, and anyone who might like a good story about greed and the folly of power. 

This game does offer you the classic roguelike experience, but doesn't insist upon a solid endpoint or goal in the same way a roguelike usually would. [b]people looking for that experience might not find it here[/b], in the same way you might in Slay the spire or Hades. This game offers something slightly different, a choice, that will become more and more apparent as you spend time in the game.

Noita is a roguelike with simulated pixels that all react with each other, and learning all these reactions can give you a lot of power, including potion mixing and being able to eat every pixel you see. Another big part of the game is building your own spells out of spell components and wands you find along the way, this can make some very broken or very funny spells or even just end your run.

The game is also huger than it looks, with the starting dungeon only being like 25% of the actual game. There is many endings and some of them aren't possible without travelling to parallel worlds!

I love this game though and if you like games like Nethack, Rogue or Zorbus, then you will like this game!

EDIT: Just chiming in at 212~ hours to say that I still stand by everything I'm saying here even if I continue to play it. Call it sunk cost fallacy or whatever, idk.

---

Noita...is [i]evil[/i]. It sounds hyperbolic, it sounds like an exaggeration, but there truly isn't a better word for it. This game is [i]filled[/i] with malice. It does not respect your time, and it does not respect you. It inverts typical game design in such a way that it deliberately and purposely punishes you for just being a normal person.

You are punished for anything and everything, constantly. And when I say punished I don't mean the "oh no I lost some HP or this set me back a little". No. When I say punish, I mean that your run is over. It's done. 1 Hour in? Or 2? Perhaps 6? It doesn't care. It's gone. Punishment in Noita is [i][u]death[/u][/i].

Early on, the biggest threat you will face isn't the enemies, or the bosses, or the bad RNG, or even the traps. It's you. And I'm not strictly talking about skill issues here.

No. I'm talking about your desire to learn. Your desire to explore. Your desire to optimize. Your defenses. Your offenses. Your strategies, and your tactics. The developers have designed this game in such a way that if you do not look anything up and you play entirely blind, you die. And then you die again. And again. By doing this they can expand what is essentially a 20~ hour game into several hundred, possibly over a thousand.

You'll die from looting chests. You'll die from using new wands you find. You'll die for fighting new enemies. You'll die for trying new spells. You'll die from mixing spells in new ways. You'll die from unexplained wand mechanics. You'll die from exploring new areas. You'll die from your defensive perks. You'll die from your offensive perks. You'll die from stepping on a [b][u]SINGLE PIXEL[/u][/b] (not an exaggeration).

The joy of discovery is a concept I love in games. I love tinkering and trying to figure out how things work, and the payoff that one receives when it finally clicks. I really don't like having to look stuff up or follow guides because it takes away that ever so sweet "joy of discovery". However, Noita [u]despises[/u] the joy of discovery. No, it wants you to feel the joy of discovering its fist shoved up your ass.

When you die in Noita, it is [i]always[/i] your fault, but it [b][u]NEVER[/u][/b] feels fair. After your death you'll (hopefully but not guaranteed) know how not to die the next time, but it just wasted 1-3 hours of your life to teach you that [i]singular[/i] mechanic to avoid.

---

Dying isn't a big deal though, right? I mean, that's what you do in roguelikes. You die and try again. But there's a lot of very monotonous gameplay in the first hour of Noita. You're exploring with very slow movement speed praying to god that you find some useful resources without losing too much of your own, and this takes [i]time[/i].

With how many hours a single save can take up, It just doesn't seem fair to demand [i]complete[/i] knowledge and [b]perfect[/b] play the entire game. But it [i]does[/i].

This game is [b]evil[/b], and it [b][i]hates[/i][/b] you.

And what is your reward, after you put in the time, make the mistakes, and gain the experience and skill necessary to complete the game? Less of a game.

You then do to enemies what they did to you. Cathartic in some ways, yes, but then a new problem emerges. All challenge is removed. All difficulty is removed. You explore and explore and you steamroll everything without even being able to see what you are destroying. Then you look up what you're supposed to do next and go through the motions like a robot.

Quite frankly, It's boring. Some people like that sort of thing, but not me. Noita made me suffer for 60+ hours so that I could become a god and I don't find the god gameplay very interesting. Bosses either oneshot me, or I oneshot them. I've killed like 7 bosses and I don't even know what they do because the only way to make it to them alive was to become an unkillable god. How is that interesting...?

If any of this sounded good to you, then well, power to you friend. But it isn't for me. This was a waste of my time, and a waste of my money.

Noita is a very difficult 2D roguelike. Its two main defining features, except for its roguelike elements and serious difficulty, are its unique systems - the wand system and the game engine in which every pixel is simulated and reacts to the other pixels on the screen.
Both of these systems are highly complex and fun to play around with.

I would recommend this game to those seeking a challenge, or who want to see truly exceptional and unique mechanics. Otherwise, this game may be too frustrating or niche to tickle your fancy.

I think Noita is an incredibly unique idea as a game and I love the premise and concepts presented, but it requires too much effort to understand and be successful at this game. I think if you have a lot of spare time on your hands, love to nerd out on lore, puzzles, love to push the limits of your computer to create the best wand possible, then Noita's for you. If you don't feel like you want to invest hours and hours to finally be able to crack the game's secrets and enjoy yourself, might not be for you. It just isn't for me.

100% recommend this game to anyone who has the patience or skill to play it. I only say this because you die... A LOT and progress is reset every time. I really like this game because it has a very high skill ceiling and allows for creative game-play due to the manipulable world. Very interesting and unique mechanics.

The vision behind Noita is great and most of the game's aspects are executed very well. The pixel simulation and variety of ways to die contribute to the chaotic nature of the game, and the wand customization has a good base. However, the poorly implemented parts ruin the gameplay.

The idea behind the customizable wands is well thought out, but most of the wands and spells you can find in the game are garbage. Until you find enough chainsaw spells to make a machine gun wand or get an extremely lucky god combo spells, your best wand will be mediocre at best. The same goes for the perks in the holy mountains, half of which are outright detrimental to the player. 

This wouldn't be a big deal if it weren't for the difficulty of the game. More often than not, deaths in Noita are unfair e.g off screen enemies one-shotting you, explosives being completely obscured by dead bodies, enemies angering the gods by destroying the holy mountain, etc. The only way you are going to have a good run is if you get an insane spell/perk combo. The common cope by Noita players is to "just be cautious" while playing, but that isn't fun, and it goes against the fast-paced and chaotic intent behind the game.

The devs could improve the game dramatically if they made a few minor changes.

This game is a special kind of hell. 10/10. Play mostly blind but get some puzzle assistance from the community, since they're a "little" esoteric. I have spent a truly ridiculous amount of time playing noita, and it seamlessly transitions from a game about slapping spells together to see what they do to Stressed Eldritch Horror Simulator. I cannot recommend it for everyone, but if you played Minecraft or Terraria and wished it made you suffer more, then you'll probably love it.

But seriously, this game is fun. It does require a lot of trial and error, and studying. If you like terraria, or games where you can become a god over time, I would recommend it.

Finnish wizard simulator

Advantages: Rich magical systems (various spells and different combinations), massive maps (even bigger than you imagine, remember to walk up, down, left, right, dig and fly), excellent physical systems (the interaction between various elements inside is great), extremely exploratory, and absolutely high-quality works.

Disadvantages: The cost of learning time is too high, and every attempt at new magic is highly likely to lead to death. Death in the game of rogue-like means a complete end, and everything previously done needs to be redone. Not very suitable for players with limited time and high daily life pressure.
-----------------------------------------------
-----------------------------------------------
优点：丰富的魔法系统(各种魔法和不同的组合方式)，庞大的地图(大到超乎你的想象，记得往上下左右都走走挖挖飞飞)，优秀的物理系统(里面的各种元素之间的交互非常的赞)，极高的探索性，绝对的优质作品。

缺点：学习时间成本过高，每一次尝试新魔法都极有可能导致死亡，rogue-like游戏里的死亡就意味着彻底地结束，之前所做的一切都要重新来过。不是很适合时间不是很充足且平时生活压力比较大的玩家群体。

Noita, one of the best games I've ever played. It is basically a 3 in 1. 

First, it has the classic kill everything that moves style. Absolute decimation, leaving only carnage in your wake as you travel further. 

Second, it has so much lore that any lore-loving gamer will find tons to explore in the world, riddled with ancient symbols and references to long-lost languages. 

Third, the "everything is simulated" effect is probably among the coolest simulators of physical properties I've seen so far, with countless reactions taking place when mixing all the powdered and liquid substances. 

If you want to get Noita, I totally recommend it, 100%. 
Be prepared to die... A Looooooooot though. Classic Noita. 
Oh and also, the Unexpected always happens here.

First of all, this game is awesome. It's a chaotic, extremely difficult roguelike that's very unique. Fiddling with wands to create the ultimate weapon of destruction is a blast (often literally). 

And at the same time, the thing that makes this game very unique, which is the chaos and randomness, also is one of the bigger downsides. The amount of unfair deaths is uncountable. Enemies can one-hit you with powerful wands they picked up, you can be transformed into a sheep and made into kebab a second later, get teleported into a deathpit of very angry foes, get blown up by a random chain reaction of explosions and so on.

Enemies deal a great amount of damage, while heals are sparse. The amount of randomness means most runs end due to being unlucky. Most spells are to dangerous to equip onto your wands, leaving you using mostly the same safe, low damage dealing spells. 

Beating the main game/boss can be done in a reasonable time and feels enjoyable. If you try beating any other boss or try to uncover secrets the game is down right way to punishing. I died multiple times after hours of gameplay in the same run to something stupid, just to have to do the same thing again. These secrets are super cryptic, unfairly hard, time consuming and unrewarding. Some items and locations don't even have a purpose for any secret/story making it ever more confusing. 

I would like to see a Noita 2 where chasing secrets doesn't feel like torture. Besides that I have had a blast playing this game so far and would gladly pick-up a sequel.
