One of the most fun true rogue-likes I've played, you're a wizard who can fly and shoot magic and who doesn't want that.
It's also very hard and there are so many secrets all through the game.

-The variety of spells is insane - there are bouncing balls, fireballs, magic missiles, thunder clouds, electric fields, black holes and on top of all the spells there are modifiers which can change different aspects of the spells. As well as the spells, every wand is unique; they have different mana capacities, recharge rates, spell slots, cast delays, accuracy, and you can edit your spell sets between levels.
The combinations you can get can be massively over powered, simply ridiculous and some kill you instantly, but all are fun and interesting.

-Every pixel in the game is simulated; sand and other fine materials will fall, liquids will flow, wood will catch fire, metal and liquid will become electrified and that's just some of the basic interactions. 
Acid will eat through any material and turn it into gas, oil and whiskey will ignite instantly, most liquids will evaporate if there is fire on them, oil will float on water and blood will sink etc.

-90% of what happens at any moment will happen without you even seeing it because enemies of different factions are constantly fighting each other, causing fires and explosions, bleeding different liquids like blood, slime, acid, toxic sludge - sometimes you walk into a level to find half the terrain destroyed before you even get there.
Some enemies can even pick up wands and use them to cast whatever spell is on it.

I've been playing this game since early access and over the years it has become my most favorite game of all time (not exaggerating).  Even after over 1,000 hours, I still thoroughly enjoy playing this game.  My path to playing this game started with Minecraft, and from Minecraft jumped to Terraria.  From there I thought Noita looked like Terraria.  It is not like Terraria.  I struggled at first because Noita is a very unforgiving and challenging game and it took some time to learn how to create and use the wands.  This game has a tremendous amount of depth (both literally and figuratively) and replay value.  For those who are struggling at this game, I would recommend installing some game mods that make the game a bit easier (such as Cheat GUI and Spells Lab).  Once you have become a bit more comfortable with the game, you can turn the mods off and start playing for real.

Indie Rogue-(likes|lites) have proliferated in the last decade, but I promise this is one that whose absolutely fresh and compelling premise elevates it in the field. Noita is truly a unique phenomenon, like nothing else! While Nolla as a studio was a yet-unpublished entity at the time of Noita's release, the constituent developers are a veritable pantheon of current-gen indie scions, all of whom have some great work under their belts: Baba Is You, Environmental Station Α, Crayon Physics Deluxe, Legend Of Grimrock; not to mention a whole slew of interesting game-jam-level Itch-dot-i-o fare.

Truly, this is a Magnum Opus and should be considered a Great Cultural Work of both Finland and indie game development at large. And while a positive:negative ratio currently hovering around 7:1 means I can't really claim it's "underrated", it does feel like it's achieved far less wide-spread adoration than it should have.

I assume those 1/8 who voted negative either found it "too hard", or that their machine couldn't quite meet the admittedly strenuous performance requirements. Both of which are understandable. Like many RL "get to the bottom of the world" games, the breakthroughs required to find a winning strategy can seem frustratingly opaque. Without some gauge — internal or in-game — charting real progress, it's not hard to imagine that its utterly unforgiving ethos could leave hopeless those players to whom Noita has not made obvious its innumerable contrasting joys.

On the latter charge of poor performance, the requirements for good FPS must seem completely absurd given the visuals and seemingly-straightforward gameplay, right up until that moment where the full, awe-inspiring scope of the simulation dawns on you. After that, it seems more like a miracle that the game runs at all. And while it may seem a small comfort to those whose gaming setup lacks the power to deliver a playable experience, I feel compelled to mention it: despite seemingly-reasonable assumptions otherwise, the demands of this software are justified. The situation is diametrically opposed to that normally encountered with sluggish indies, where an inexperience or uninspired developer simply fails to use basic optimizations and best practices. This game needs a beefy rig because it's doing something monumental.

Preemptive apologies aside, thankfully, the actual merits of the game itself are far more numerous:

I do feel that uncovering some of this stuff on one's own is an integral part of the joy here, so I'll be brief: The moment-to-moment action is incredibly challenging, yet feels natural to master. The wand-building is deeply engaging in the very same way: the thrill of discovering new spells and interesting ways to combine them through experimentation and exploration provided a compelling meta-game that quickly overshadowed the goal of completing individual "runs". Lastly, the whole game is jam-packed with secrets and meta-secrets, some for powerups, some for lore, many for both. In fact, the last time I checked, there is still another ARG-style puzzle hidden in the game which has a community dedicated to solving it — joined by fans, to be sure, but also counting cryptographers, engineers and lore-heads among their ranks. This sort of thing doesn't really appeal to me personally, but I truly respect the level of dedication implied by both implementating and maintenaning such an impenetrable mystery just for fun. It really drives home the passion and creative whimsy of the developers.

on matters of taste: I find the pixelated late-DOS-era-pc-game-ish visuals to be both pleasing and functional. In a weird way, it honestly evokes vibes reminiscent of Lemmings or Cannon Fodder, of all things. And yet, in the three decades that have passed since that era, computing power has surged beyond anyone's wildest imagination. Thankfully, Nolla is not content with the simple retro baseline, and leverages the margin in those orders of magnitude to furnish and render a massively complex, large scale simulation, decorated by no shortage of awesome effects and interactions.

The setting concerns the journey of a "Noita" (finnish for witch/sorcerer, apparently) to uncover the secrets of alchemy foretold in legend, and manifests as a loose blend of sci-fi and fantasy, colored through a filter of Suomenusko creation myths and the writings of late medeival Hermetic Alchemists. Very fucking cool, IMO.

So too does the soundtrack rise to the occasion: Droning psych-rock which fits perfectly as ambiance for a descent into a bottomless cavern beneath a mystical mountain; nor does it ever lack heaviness or bombast when moments of intensity call for it, all the while absolutely slapping my ass raw. Seriously 10/10 music.

The modding "scene" is also worth mentioning: there are a wide variety of well-constructed mods, which alter, enhance or completely rebuild the whole game. It also incredibly easy to get into creating mods, if you're inclined toward that sort of thing.

While I clearly enjoy the game in its own right, I can't help but recognize the brilliance of the overall theme; how the broad tropes of Alchemy and Arcana — i.e. seeking forbidden knowledge in pursuit of limitless power — are reflected so purely in the gameplay itself.

It's at first simple and wholly diegetic. I've already mentioned the RL aspect, so hopefully this doesn't count as a spoiler, but it turns out that simply finishing a run doesn't really translate to "beating the game"... Countless hopeful Noita will perish before their journey is complete, to be sure, but those who reach the goal they were given will revel in their victory for but a moment before reaping its fruits... Of course, the prize awaiting them at the bottom is precisely the same as that awarded to those who fail mere steps into the mountain: the swift and inevitable punishment due to all who suffer the hubris endemic to mankind. Here is your high score, fool! Better luck next run!

No, if one wishes to truly ascend, it is not enough to simply follow the legends. The rules of reality do not permit limitless power, and so to achieve it one must break those rules and defy that reality, forging a NEW path and uncovering NEW mastery. Only then can the "Ludo-Narrative Synchronicity" really shine: when the sentence for those guilty of hubris is delivered not as a simply matter of course at the end of a run, but by the seeker's own hand. Digging too deeply and being dashed on the lower stories of Hell itself. Attempting to rewrite the heavens only to be swallowed by a burning star. Creating a wand so unimaginably powerful that the physics calculations required to simulate it explode astronomically, leaving you imprisoned for eternity in the exact moment of its first firing.

You'll have to take my word for it: this goes far, far beyond the level of "you have to do a couple extra tasks to get the 'real' ending" type stuff. No, these are moments of TRUE Alchemy, experienced by an actual Alchemist, and not merely the actions of one playing a game about alchemy.

In conclusion: is Noita a perfect game? Yes. Of course, asking whether some work of art or artifice is perfect is really a meaningless question in the grand scheme of things. And so, I choose to say that it is, because I really like it a lot, and think you should play it.

If you’re expecting this game to merely be as challenging and unfair as Bloodborne’s cursed chalice dungeons, or GTA’s ambulance missions, then you’re in for a rough time.

Technically, this game is incredible.  Measured in enjoyment/frustration, it’s painful.  Maybe if you have Finnish Sisu - by which I mean both incredible stubbornness, and a masochistic streak - it keeps being fun.

For the rest of us chumps who made the mistake of buying it, we have a choice: either give up, and accept we have no skill, or accept we have no life, and keep trying to beat the “tutorial”.
Blow shit, freeze, cast spells, find perks, explore, try not to die. Good luck with the last part.

This game has such in-depth secrets beyond any other game I've ever played, and undoubtedly will ever play. The wand mechanics are vast and intriguing, the enemies unique, and the endless hunt for that next achievement pillar challenge. I HIGHLY recommend this game, but only for those who hunger for a true challenge and a thirst for true knowledge. As is Above, so is Below.

Elegantly simple, yet strikingly deep physics. Every pixel is physically simulated and interactive (and most can kill you somehow).
Wand building is dauntingly complex, but when you find a setup that works well, it works *really* well. This lends to the game's variety, while simultaneously providing a deep channel for skill expression.
Combat is simple, but highly challenging for the impatient or uninformed. Finding new and unexpected ways to die is part of the learning experience, and due to the unfathomably large problem space this game sits in, it never truly ends.
If you love solving puzzles, and unraveling lore, this game will likely keep you busy for longer than you'll care to solve it.

Noita is not only a excellent game, it's an exemplary showcase of what the beautifully designed Falling Everything engine has to offer.

Noita - Descent into madness

If you weren't schizophrenic before, you will be now.
Step in lava? Die. Step in acid? Die. Step in water? That wasn't water. Die. Oh look, a new spell, lets see what it does! Die. Stand still for a half second? Die. Move around too much? Die. BREATH? The audacity. Die.

Like many, I swear off this game every now and then after something absurdly unforgiving occurs and ruins a good run in it's infancy. But... I always seem to come back because there's no other game out there that scratches this particular itch remotely as well. 

Terraria is the sandbox where you create things. Noita is the sandbox where you destroy things.

Noita is a game that will make you laugh, cry, and curse in equal measure. It’s a game that will test your patience, your creativity, and your sanity. It’s a game that will reward you with spectacular moments of magic and mayhem, and punish you with sudden and brutal deaths. It’s a game that will make you wonder why you keep playing it, and then make you realize that you can’t stop.

Noita is a roguelike where every pixel is simulated, meaning that everything in the game world can be affected by your actions and the environment. You play as a wizard who descends into a procedurally generated dungeon, armed with a variety of wands and spells that you can customize and combine in countless ways. You can set fire to wooden structures, freeze enemies with ice bolts, create black holes that suck in everything around them, or summon rain clouds to wash away toxic sludge. The possibilities are endless, and so are the ways you can die.

Noita is not a game for the faint of heart. It’s a game that will challenge you with its difficulty, its randomness, and its lack of explanation. You will die a lot, and often in ways that seem unfair or unavoidable. You will encounter enemies that can kill you in one hit, traps that can trigger without warning, and spells that can backfire spectacularly. You will also discover secrets that can change the course of your run, items that can grant you powerful abilities, and synergies that can make you feel like a god. You will never know what to expect, and that’s part of the fun. 

Noita is a game that will make you feel a range of emotions, from frustration to exhilaration, from despair to joy. It’s a game that will make you appreciate its beauty, its complexity, and its creativity. It’s a game that will make you want to share your stories, your discoveries, and your failures with others. It’s a game that will make you love it and hate it at the same time.

Noita is a game that I absolutely recommend to anyone who enjoys roguelikes, physics-based games, or just experimenting with crazy magic. It’s a game that has been in development for seven years by a small team of indie developers, and it shows in the amount of detail and polish that has gone into it. It’s a game that has received overwhelmingly positive reviews from critics and players alike, and it deserves all the praise it gets.

Noita is a game that I can’t get enough of, even though it makes me want to smash my keyboard sometimes. It’s a game that I can’t wait to play again, even though I know it will probably kill me in the most ridiculous way possible. It’s a game that I can’t help but love, even though it hates me so much.

Noita is a game that you should definitely try for yourself, if you dare.

If you like the idea of well thought out game mechanics that logically and dynamically interact with you, your enemies, and the world around you, then this game is for you. Learning the systems and how they interact with each other is CRAZY satisfying and rewarding.

This game is supposed to be difficult, and I love that. As you play more, you realize that taking damage is basically the one thing you should absolutely avoid at all costs. The more damage you take, the less ground you can cover before needing to get to a safe zone, the less chance you have of finding better equipment (necessary) or gaining enough money to buy said better equipment. It really makes you value thinking methodically and considering risk vs gain. 

However, there are 2 things that fundamentally ruin the aforementioned concept:

1. Single pixels of lava/fire/poison doing damage to you. It's dumb. I could barely tell there was an orange dot of lava there because it's literally a single pixel surround by tons of other pixels with different colors and lighting effects. That's dumb. Make it like 3 pixels minimum to cause damage and the game stays the same without being... dumb.

2. Getting shot by enemies off screen. Difficulty, I get it. But again, that's dumb. People will say "just adapt" or "don't take risks". If I'm getting attacked by things that are IMPOSSIBLE FOR ME TO BE AWARE OF, that's a bad mechanic. There's no other way about it. If you genuinely think that's fine, you're literally drowning in copium. 

Regardless, buy the game. It's insanely sick and the devs really deserve to be recognized for it. Probably the coolest game I've played in a long time.


**DEVS: disallow single pixel environmental damage (lava/toxic/etc) and at a MINIMUM, reduce the amount of enemies that can fire at you off screen to only the ones that laser target (AKA the ones that actually give you a warning that they're shooting at you off screen.)**

Noita is grossly mislabeled as a game, it is not a game its a way of life. Genuinely one of the most challenging and deep games I have ever played. The "main game" doesn't begin to scratch the surface of what the game has to offer, for example.

The game plays similar to a rougelike, however the materials gained from run to run is nonexistent unless certain conditions are met. The main thing you gain from run to run is knowledge and experience, as pretentious as that may sound.

This game has a particular ability to scratch my autism, because I am fascinated by the ancient science of alchemy, and this game simulates that both in its physical world and in its wand construction. Substances interact with the environment in unique ways, and this fact can be a strength you can harness just as easily as it can kill you, and the same goes for wand-making.

Many deaths will be the result of a calculated risk- will this particular set of spells backfire? Many deaths will also by the result of hubris, of striking forward when it would be better to draw back.

I really cannot praise the depth of this game enough, there are a near-infinite number of ways to make a wand or to achieve your goals.

One drawback that I cannot directly fault the game for is that it feels very necessary to have a wiki open when playing, to reference what certain things do or if this or that perk is worthwhile. This detracts from the experience, but it is mainly due to the fact that access to an all-encompassing wiki is just a click and a keystroke away.

All-in-all I would really consider this one of the best games I have ever played, aggravating as it may be at times. It is just as much a game as it is a science experiment, in seeing how things work or how they don't.

Noita can be serenely tranquil. Noita can be utter chaos. Minutes of routine exploration can quickly crescendo into fighting for your life against your enemies and the environment. One minute you’re struggling to take down one enemy with your nerf gun-like wand and the next you find a wand that melts everything in your path. You enter one level and cleanly explore every nook and cranny leaving safely on your own terms.  The next level you can’t seem to not catch on fire, at every turn you’re stepping in toxic slime, and water is nowhere in sight so you must use the blood of your enemies to extinguish the flames and wash away the toxins. You have to rush to the end of the level because you can’t afford another misstep, but as a consequence leave most of the level unexplored.

This is the dichotomy of Noita. When you combine that perfect wand build, a set of great perks, and excellent game knowledge you can cruise through the chaos and feel like a true battle mage. The majority of the time and especially early on when learning the game, you’ll feel like a conjuror of cheap tricks and rinky-dink spells. But that’s ok, Noita excels in the chaos and the more uncontrolled the better.

It's tough for me to give this game a thumbs down. I really do think it's well made, and if I could leave a "maybe" recommendation I would, but this is Steam, so I can't.

Noita has a lot of great things going for it: gorgeous pixel-style graphics, tight controls, and great enemy design. Plus, it just [i]looks cool[/i]. Just look at the featured screenshots! It takes the rougelike fundamental of permadeath and doesn't toy with it. In fact, it gets pretty much everything right about what a rougelike should be.

My one [b]major, glaring issue[/b] with Noita is that, after seven hours of playing the game, I was still barely making it past the first level. It took about an hour or two to become familiar with basic mechanics like saturation, being on fire, acid, etc. I learned enemy attack patterns and generally understood what wands I wanted to keep and what spells worked for my playstyle. But beyond that, there was extremely little I could learn to improve my chances of long-term survival.

I'm not asking for rogue[b]lite[/b] features such as permanent progression. I'm asking for the game to reward me for learning from my mistakes. Yes, I know this is a "Difficult" game and that I should be expected to die a lot in a roguelike; I'm not new to the genre. But my deaths seemed downright unfair. Plan and react as best I could, death would find its way to me in the most ridiculous ways, often in a way I couldn't possibly have seen coming.

The smaller issue I have with Noita is that the variety of pickups is [i]too[/i] great. Too many combinations of wands and stats/spells are useless or downright lethal to you as the player. If wands cost less to buy or were more plentiful as pickups then this wouldn't be as big of an issue. But as uncommon as they are, I found myself passing up most of them.

In the end, I had to put Noita down. A more persistent, enthralled player will recommend this game (and they do! look at that review score). But if any of what I wrote above matters to you, I recommend you look for a different roguelike to get your fix.

I watched the GDC talk and I just had to buy it. Outwardly it may look like Terraria, but it's a roguelike alright. You got your potions, your spells and after every area you can buy new wands, spells and get a perk. Go down the dungeon and kill the boss. Simple enough ?

Now this is just a pet peeve of mine as to what emergence means. This game does have emergence but because it's based on how real world solids, gas and liquids would interact, it's not emergent in the sense that the base rules of the game interacting with each other creates an entirely new mechanic that even the devs wouldn't anticipate.

It's emergent because i.e : the dynamite guy just decided to throw a dynamite and it just happened that there was an oil lamp there in an entirely wooden area so the dynamite guy blew up half the level, putting everything on fire, while you were walking somewhere else.

But that's a good thing, because as much as there are seemingly random things happening at times, the interactions make sense and as such you can be clever in how to approach stage hazards. (or miserably die and do it again)

Personally, I think this game is amazing. There is so much depth and content to this game, it is easy to see that the devs cared about this. Even 80+ hours in, I am still discovering new things. 

However, this game is quite challenging. The learning curve felt steep at first, however I began to learn, improving my run each time I would die. I began to get familiar and found spells I preferred over others.  The game allows you to tailor your style to whatever you like, whether that is slow and hard-hitting, or quick and rapid-fire. Not to even mention the spells that involve triggers and timers.

Overall, one of my favorite games in recent memory, and I would highly suggest trying it out.

TLDR: Vanilla Noita is unbalanced and rewards monotony; modded Noita is a slice of heaven that found its way onto Steam.

In its current state, I cannot recommend anyone who values their time to play vanilla Noita. The emergent difficulty of this game is placed far too much into RNGesus' hands. Mastering the mechanics of this game really only takes a couple dozen hours, and I found this game far quicker to learn than most other rogue-likes. But in this game, mastering the mechanics will realistically only help in understanding how to beat the game. It is only once in a blue moon that the player is offered a decent enough arsenal to delve far enough to beat the game. Most of your deaths will occur during the first four floors, as you will often find yourself lacking the firepower necessary to blast through the hordes of hiisi. The game only really opens up on the fifth floor, offering bounds of extra life, and suitable weapons. However, getting to this point often requires the player to be meticulous, exploring every nook and cranny of each prior floor in order to optimize wand builds. This all has to be done while paying extreme attention to detail, as deadly situations are often hidden in plain sight and require immediate action to avoid. This type of playstyle just isn't rewarding to me, and after though hundreds of deaths with so few victories my enthusiasm for how unique and intricate this game is has whittled away. I strongly discourage anyone who wants to play the vanilla game to continue after their first victory.

Despite the game's inherent and obvious flaws, the devs are incredibly based and decided to include native mod support. There are dozens of mods that re-balance the game into a far more suitable experience for casual play. Loads of these mods are also of extremely high quality, and fit so naturally into the environment it becomes difficult to revert back to vanilla. I highly recommend the modded experience to everyone who is interested in this game; it fixes nearly every issue this game has while introducing so many unique experiences that we would have never gotten without. The modded experience is a 10/10.

P.S. The secrets in this game aren't too hard to get once you have gotten a decent arsenal. Finding them on your own will take probably 30 extra hours from my experience, but if your are struggling to find them I would recommend you join the official discord server and ask people for hints. https://discord.gg/noita
The greatest game to never have a tutorial. Also the worst game to never have a tutorial. You learn the hard way, and if that's not for you don't play this game.

How many seeds are too many seeds? When randomness becomes a gimmick? If the price was half, then the game would be justifiable. But when you're paying for an algorithm instead of handcrafted love and attention to every level, then I cannot recommend.

Noita is an amazing game, although complex. Expect a large learning curve when starting, but I assure you it is worth it. If you don't care about spoilers, use videos/guides to help you understand the game. Enjoy! :)

What else can I say about a game where the overall player reviews are overwhelmingly positive? 
Well, for starters, this game is unforgiving in a way that you'll only understand by playing it.
It's Roguelike, so by it's nature, it will kill you... A LOT! 
It has the nostalgia of an old school game (If you know, you know), but with superb physics built in, and everything  (YES EVERYTHING), even down to the last little pixel is destructible in one way or the other. 
The game doesn't hold your hand... You start, and you figure it out as you play. 
The controls are simple, and the objectives are easy to figure out... If you're one of those die hard gamers that thinks they're better than everyone else... please do be my guest.. I like to see people be humbled by entertainment...
The "unlockables" in this game are MANY, and the combinations of wands and spells are insane. This game will challenge you, run, after run, after run, and it doesn't get stale. 
IF you're easily frustrated, perhaps it's not the game for you... Or perhaps it is, and it's an opportunity to quell that rage and frustration you harbour, because it will break you... at some point... unless you're weakling and run from a good fight. 
The only thing I can leave you with, is this... 
Buy it, try it, OWN it... It really is a must have for any serious game collector, and is definitely one of my top favourite games to play casually in between more demanding games, it's one where if you have only 5 minutes to spare, this game can do that... or, you know... consume your entire afternoon with run after run.
I highly recommend this excellent game!

finally beat it after 200 hours 10/10

The potential for creativity, exploration, and experimentation that Noita has is unmatched by other video games.  I love finding new ways to manipulate and destroy the environment, experimenting with new spells and wands, and having those "Aha!" moments that change how I think about, and make me better at, Noita.

IMO, there are two main downsides to Noita:
1. There are some areas of the game and some wand configurations that are very CPU intensive, and when you come across those areas and/or use those wands, your frame rate will drop significantly.  I certainly noticed this on my Steam Deck, but this also happens to Twitch streamers with more powerful setups.
2. You'll occasionally die due to a stray pixel that blocks your path, a pixel which you couldn't see at first because its color nearly matches the background.

All in all, the downsides only slightly detract from a utterly fantastic game.

I was hooked the very first time I set fire to something.  Which then caused a chain reaction of explosions, dunking into burning oil, falling, and electricity that killed me in the space of two hilarious seconds.  This is a must have game for a hundred reasons.  Minor one of which is:  after only 60 hours of playing...I have skilled up immensely and now chain kill bad guys with fire.  With freezing gas.  Knocking off huge chunks of ice to drop on them.  And still being killed after setting fire to things.

Still reading/undecided?  Don't let the graphics stop you/  If you play fantasy games and have decent arcade reflexes, this is a must have title.  In fact the graphics and game engine must be experienced to be believed how good the visuals actually are.  The videos don't do justice, this has be experienced live.

This game is the dungeon delving BOMB because of the complex weapon building.  Every single weapon is a batch of removable components for whatever weapon I want to build.  If I can survive to the end of the level to actually be able to assemble a better weapon with them.  Or hey I didn't realize how powerful and strange the weapon I just picked up is.  Sure ok let's just try out one shot, just for fun.  Cool, look at these massive sawblades it fired, as tall as me and twice as wide.  See how they sliced through that enemy, and now slow to a stop, have reversed course, are accelerating.  Back at me...OH SH!!  

New game and lesson learned.  The lesson being:  THIS TIME I want to figure out how to USE the big sawblade, there MUST be an spell/item/perk combo in this game somewhere.  Let me check out the wiki site, or the excellent guides folks like cyberspacegamers have written.

Maybe it is the excellent procedural levels that are always different and waiting for me to explore.  Secrets, surprises, and death everywhere.  Or maybe it is glorious difficulty balance where situational awareness, quick reflexes, and how to best manage the weapons I have, are all equally important.  Maybe it's the immense variety of bad guys that manage to kill me even though I think I know how to fight them.

Certainly, though, every other roguelike or action/arcade game has helped to skill up to play this one.  Warm it up, warrior, stop reading and buy this asap!

I think this is the first game I actually recommend, despite the many unfair things that can kill you.
To me, when a game does not warn properly, is unrealistic, and applies the maximum penalty afterwards, is a sign to instantly uninstall it.
This game, however, somehow makes me enjoy it as I hadn't done with any other game.

I think I already lost count of the many times I was peacefully moving around, with no apparent sign of danger, and that I instantly died a second later (I think the trailer already showcases that pretty much). And the thing is that you might not repeat that death again (because it does hurt to lose your progress, and quite a good run sometimes), but there are still just so many other ways that you might explode at that very moment.

The rest of the game is just a combination of polished details and game design... I mean, you can see after a couple minutes of time, that the whole world can be interacted with, and each thing is original and well implemented.

To me it's almost a 10/10, and my biggest complaint is about performance, as after a few minutes, the game starts to slow down. Fortunately re-opening seems to solve it, and it is so fast opening, that it isn't truly bothersome.
I should add that I do play with a couple QoL mods.
It can make you rage. But you will play it again no matter what.

This game does not know what it wants to be.

[h1]An Identity Crisis[/h1]
At its core, it tries to be a Roguelike game full of interesting and wacky interactions. You go through stages, go further down, get stronger, kill the boss. Simple. There are A LOT of ways in which you can unfairly die in this game, ranging from stunlocks to death, offscreen projectiles, invisible enemies/pixels, BS interactions literally teleporting acid onto your face, you name it.

But all of that is fine because you only lose like 30 minutes of playtime, right?

Wrong, because this is where the other half of the game rears its ugly head. The exploration. The quests. The "secrets". Basically, anything off the beaten path. And this game has A LOT of it. That sounds fun at first, but then you realize that going through these "sidequests" takes several hours, and at that point all it takes is a single purple pixel or a worm digging through a mountain to end the last several hours. The player's time is not valued.

Did I mention that the game features instant-death liquids that were put in to "balance" the lategame areas? Over there, it doesn't matter how well you strategize your build and your wands. You get hit by a single pixel of the stuff, you're dead instantly. Goodbye the last 6 hours of your life! Wait come back, why aren't you having fun yet?!

[h1]The pearls in the sand[/h1]
Balancing is poor. The vast majority of wands, spells and perks in this game suck really hard. They suck. They are literally just filler to pad out the content. COMPLETELY useless dogs**t. We're talking about limited-use spells, useless or detrimental perks, shuffle wands, or spells that just kill you. Then there are other perks that are basically just mandatory in order to play the game in a fun way, like Tinkering with wands anywhere.

Wand tinkering and experimentation is not rewarded and will most likely lead to wasting your time, your limited spells or even leading to your demise. In order to play this game correctly, you basically have to wiki what works and what doesn't. Same goes for the secrets, they are super obtuse and almost impossible to figure out on your own.

[h1]Dying is not your fault way too often[/h1]
There are SO MANY ways for things to go south outside of your control, much like Spelunky 2. A worm dug through the temple? Sorry bud that's your own fault, prepare to die. Offscreen sniper hit you? Tough luck. Better hope you weren't flying over a hazardous liquid or a high fall because if so, you are now dead because you're stunned out of flying. Enemy picked up a nuke wand? You're instantly dead now.

[h1]Metagaming is mandatory[/h1]
To play this game and have a consistent shot at not just beating the final boss but also doing some of the other side-content, you basically have to exploit the hell out of the game. Essentially, you have to make it so you can play the least amount of the game possible. This involves infinite Nolla teleport wands to explore areas and fight enemies the LEAST, black holing through the map to skip the most amount of the game as humanly possible, and doing other tedious stuff like teleporting past the invisible trigger that destroys the temple when you leave. Did I mention the temple is the only place you can tinker with wands by default?

[h1]Mods?[/h1]
But wait, there's mods! There's mods that respawn you at checkpoints, mods that give you perks like Tinker Anywhere at spawn, mods that give you a more reliable non-shuffle wand to start out with... BUUUUT you can't unlock anything when playing with mods. At all. Nothing. Not just no achievements, but no unlocks period. None of the good spells, none of the mandatory modifiers like Omega or Sigma.


In a nutshell, this game suffers from a massive identity crisis. It does not know whether it wants to be an instadeath roguelike or an exploration-focused game where you set up the world for a payoff. The end result is repeatedly wasting hours of your life. Not fun.

This game is fundamentally broken and I don't think any single change can really fix it. Checkpoints would just be a lame bandaid. I think the biggest sticking point is how unbalanced the perks are. When the best strategy is resetting until the 1st temple has a usable perk, something is wrong.

I changed my review from a thumbs up to a thumbs down. This game was fun for a once-through... if you can even make it so far.

Should you buy this game? Sure. Buy it on sale. It's unique. it's fun at first. But for longevity, forget it. This game will turn a lover into a hater.

But now, I loathe this game. If there was a sub-category for the rough-like genre, it would be something along the lines of hardcore. Either monsters will kill you, the environment, or yourself. This surely can be expected and I knew that the game would be tough, but there are many factors beyond skill that affect whether you succeed or not.  

Although the mechanics are very simple and straightforward, there is still a durable learning curve to work through. And even as you progress through the learning curve, the game doesn't necessarily become easier to play. RNG is a real factor here and it could effect the quality of the wands you find (sometimes you find nothing). RNG also comes into play as far as being blind-sided by environmental catastrophes or monsters appear suddenly.

What really turned me off, was the RNG. out of 20 games, I would find myself with some luck. Maybe I would find more hearts than usual. Maybe I would find a wand within the first few levels that wasn't sh*tty to all hell. But when things would be going really well... BAM! I'm dead. I'm dead by something or anything.

This game has a tendency to take away any awesome feelings of achievement, consume them, and then vomit those feeling all over you. All within a blink of an eye.

So nope. I'm good. I beat the boss once. 1 out of 10 people right now can say they did the same. And should I mention... the final boss was the easiest part of the game. I thought there would be something wild about the boss and I should be lucky to stand a chance, but nope. I farted and it died.

I recently completed a run of Noita for the first time without any mods at all. My goal was to complete a run without mods before I could mod at all. After finally doing it at nearly 80 hours played, I believe I'm qualified to talk about the game.

Let's begin with this: Noita is a super unforgiving, completely unfair game. I would have beaten this game 15 hours ago on a crazy good run with a godlike wand, but I died to something that was completely unfair. It happens. There's no way to prevent it. You have to be willing to let the losses go and move forward with the next game, even though you're starting completely from scratch. It's tough, and it made me ragequit for a few days sometimes when I lost after building a very powerful wand. Be prepared for that.

Noita is a game where you have to be willing to take time to learn. I didn't get very far in Noita until I started paying more attention to formations and being more cautious when exploring so as not to get caught in large groups of enemies. It took me around 20 hours just to get past the 2nd biome in good enough shape to progress in the others. And then it took another 20 to make it to the 4th biome period. You will need to spend time learning how spells work, how wands interact with spells, how certain perks affect your character, etc.

There is so much for you to learn and experiment with in the game. (Slight spoiler warning) You have trigger spells, timers, double, triple, quadruple cast, spell modifiers, always casts on a wand, etc. I spent many hours in this game tinkering with wand setups. You can easily spend a long time in a single run trying to build your wand to be exactly what you like. There's a world of possibilities in Noita for wands and spells, and it's one of the main draws of the game.

I'll list out the various pros and cons in a short list for those interested.

Pros:
+ In-Depth, complex, and customizable magic system
+ Mostly satisfying rewards for exploration
+ Individual pixel simulation creates a large amount of interesting things to do with physics
+ Large amounts of optional content
+ Mod-friendly
+ Procedural generation means that no 2 runs will ever be alike

Cons:
- Insane learning curve
- Some deaths are unfair, and some unavoidable
- RNG can make or break runs
- Wand and spell mechanics are not clearly explained and must be learned via a wiki or YouTube videos
- Losing great runs can cause ragequits

Overall, Noita is an excellent game that can provide hours of enjoyment. It is not easy, will require effort and work to learn, and will take many hours to conquer. But once you do, you'll realize just how satisfying this game is to play.

This is a timeless gem.

It's fun on paper and very interesting seeing those old "powder games" being used for something like this, but it can be extremely frustrating to actually play and experiment in a way that isn't just met with early restarts or sighing in annoyance because of what you constantly have to deal with without actually knowing whats the best to do. It especially doesn't help that the beginning of the game is pretty boring/stale and reliant on the sand boxy start that just doesn't provide any consistency at all—praise be to the modding community though. Overall though, it just feels like a massive hit or miss and a massive time sink if you want to try as it's not really a typical roguelike game.

There are definitely some neat little secrets and interactions the more you play, but the base game is a bit hard to ignore. I might play this game here and there since it is decent for a past time, but man, it just feels like this game could have been more fun than trying to make it an overly ruthless trial and error. It might click one day, but it just barely gives me a reason to continue playing instead of just searching up everything.

My favorite game. Period.
It's got the most satisfying/fun environmental interactions I've ever seen in a game. It has a treasure trove of secrets that feel rewarding to find and conquer, with some secrets yet to even be solved by the community.
It rewards those who are creative in their approach to things, with your potential being basically infinite.
The game is beautifully mysterious, with a soundtrack that is just... so damn atmospheric.
The game's hard as hell, too, with some deaths being so absurd that it's just funny.

Now, despite all this praise... I give a warning. If you wish to persist, and crack open this game for all its worth, you MUST have a strong will. Knowledge IS power in this game. Every death will give you new knowledge. Focus on the knowledge, not the loss. Don't be afraid to check the wiki, or to ask the community. The knowledge this game's community gains is a group effort. You WILL die in this game 99% of the time. Accept it. Ride the wave. Have fun in the moment.
Best of luck, Knower to Be.

This is basically a better version of the powder toy with an actual well built game with good lore, mechanics, and discoveries slapped on top.

Probably the most accurate experience of being a wizard ever, madness included!

As with any wizardry, knowledge is power, and Noita is no different. The pixel based physics of the game come with their own rules and laws and mastering them is the key to success. Being a wizard requires lots of experiments to gain insight and the currency here is death. For instance berserkium is a great time until you fire off your first bomb and half the screen is gone, you included! 

The environment is only half the battle though, your wand is your greatest asset(and sometimes your worst). Like any respectable wizard you need to be able to cast spells, and oh boy can you! There are hundreds of spells and you can do some absolutely insane stuff with them. Knowing how to build your wand is one of the most important parts of being a wizard though, and a lot of that knowledge, like everything else in Noita, will come from a death. Firing dynamite and a spark bolt at the same time might seem like a good idea until the spark bolt explodes the dynamite point blank. It goes both ways though, one of my favorite wand designs takes a rather innocuous summon rock spell that is largely useless by itself, but by giving it accelerating homing will accelerate at mach 11 towards any enemy and smash them to death(unless they have melee immunity). There are all sort of modifier spell too that allow for some truly crazy builds,

Wizards need secrets to uncover and solve and Noita has them in spades. You'll almost certainly need the wiki for them, but there's all sorts of crazy bosses to discover and fight, orbs to collect, parallel worlds to plunder, and even more ridiculous feats of wizardry to preform!

I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who is into difficult 2D games, but also anyone who is interested in slowly amassing game knowledge until you can manipulate the world to your advantage. It takes some work to become a powerful wizard after all!

Wow this game is so much better than I expected it to be. There's a lot of critical thinking and decision making with wands and perks -- scrounging together a functional build is extremely challenging but outstandingly rewarding when the brilliant interactions in the game's engine manifest themselves in your favor. I like playing with mods as the beginning becomes arduous and slow if you are a careful player. 58 hours in and I've not begun to approach a large chunk of what this game has to offer. There's an impressive attention to mystery, symbolism, and unique Noita aesthetic strewn across Noita's world that keeps me enchanted every step of the way. There's seamless dynamic soundtracking that emotionally intices me as I play -- the sway of tension, embroidered by crushing difficulty, and brought to life by dark, magical flourish crafts an otherworldly, enthralling experience. 10/10 would reccommend.

Many reviews focus on how "hard" the game is, but what they fail to convey is just how unrewarding the moment to moment gameplay is. The first hours of a run are an absolute slog, consisting of inching forward hoping to pick off enemies as they come on screen and praying to find a wand that makes the run interesting, which in the vast majority of runs never happens. The game explains nothing and expects you to put in the time and effort to figure things out on your own, but in doing so you will quickly realize that most spells and perks you come across are complete garbage, and that building overpowered wands relies on obscure interactions between a handful of spells. But here's the problem: even after you figured out all the interactions, and you've got your hands on the most overpowered wand imaginable: the game is still not fun to play. The combat STILL feels slow, boring and unfair. So what's left?

Noita has all the makings of an amazing game, but it fails to deliver on almost all fronts. I enjoyed my first few hours, but now that I understand how little the game provides for the time and effort you put in, I regret buying it.

After 600 hours, I still feel like I'm trash at this game, I know some stuff, I've killed the bosses, done some quests, but that doesn't take away from the fact that sometimes, you die like a little b!#ch

Look. The game has the opportunity for a lot of fun, and has a lot of synergies that are exceptional and thought provoking. Where it struggles, or rather I should say, where it has completely failed, is in making a game where failure is as engaging, recoverable from, and acceptable games where being punishingly difficult is part of the appeal.

[b] Noita's gameplay loop has too many variables, too little communication, and too little consistency for it to succeed at its goal. [/b] This is all the more frustrating because it is *so close* to being a great game. The wand mechanics are simply too varied, the spells too random, for every wand you can successfully build on you might see a hundred that are entirely useless. For every spell that is the successful basis for a good build, you'll see a dozen that will only hinder your progress. This is to say nothing of the time sink in order to determine if a run will be successful. [b] A good roguelike may punish you for getting cocky, but few then force you to go back to what amounts to baby's first fantasy game for 10-20 plus minutes, gathering materials, dodging exceptionally low health (but high damage) enemies just to take another crack at the difficult levels. [/b]

It is poorly optimized, leading to extreme latency spikes in routine gameplay (this PC was built in 2021 and upgraded in 2022). In a game that delights in punishing you for a slight misstep, this usually means that you *will* die when the frames drop. 

tl;dr: Don't buy this game. It is poorly optimized, suffers from an extremely poorly designed difficulty ramp, and has too many variables to be anything more than a slot machine that takes 20 minutes to pull. I would refund it if I could.

There are several tiers to "beating" this game; each is more elaborate to complete. You can travel down the Holy Mountain(s) and beat the boss for the most basic and worst ending. There's a better ending in which you travel around the world to collect 11 Orbs too. 

I just finished the ending that requires collecting 33 orbs, and it was extremely taxing to complete. I have attempted this challenge several times, and this final time kinda killed what interest I had left in the game. Shortly after collecting my 32nd Orb, I hopped into a Holy Mountain portal in one of the parallel worlds. Normally, this returns you to the base world's Holy Mountain, but instead.... the game crashed to desktop. Not quite the scare I wanted after spending an inordinate amount of time on this challenge. Fortunately, the game had a backup available when I relaunched it. I grabbed the final Orb, completed the Work a the Mountain Altar, and all was right with the world.

Noita. Single pixels hold life and death in the balance as much as they hold one's impression of the game.

There is treasure to be found, power and secrets, but you will be cheated. Speaking plainly the game is quite frustrating, so very many deaths are just "Oh. Okay. Guess I start again then", but it is also quite addictive. Theoretically the structure is fairly simple: you want to reach the bottom of the dungeon and beat the boss. You explore each floor as much as you can for loot and move on when you either finish exploring or can explore no longer.

However throughout most of my playtime I was bogged down by the hints of more. There is a wealth of exploration to be found on the surface or outside the regular bounds. Which way should I actually go, maybe there's something to be found there. To be fair, there is, but it's not important. Not.. important enough to worry about. If you can't make it to the bottom of the dungeon, you probably don't need to worry about trying to get through the dangers that await there either.

After using a few mods to clear the game and explore more freely, I find it easier to try play and enjoy the game as is. Though I would still take XCOM or Dorf Fort over some of the 'fun' offered, and many of the faults are still inherent to the design of Noita, they grate less when the rules are laid out. So in general I will say many will not enjoy their time with this, but there is a fair amount that garners interest too if it happens to be your forte.

Noita is hands down one of the most entertaining games I have ever played - of any genre.

If you're familiar with the "Powder" toy, this game will bring back all sorts of good memories, as the "Falling Everything" engine that was created for the game is essentially that Powder toy. Add in randomly generated biomes, wands, spells, and treasure, and you've got the essentials of Noita. As a roguelike (roguelike-lite-likelite???), Noita will punish you for every mistake, and because of the game's engine, you'll become paranoid enough to inspect every pixel closely.

Wands and spellcasting are incredibly well ironed out, and the devs have essentially given the okay to try to break as much as possible in game. As a result, there are some absolutely mind blowing builds that the community has come up with. Then if you become bored with the hundreds of spells already in the game, Noita allows modding - an almost infinitely customizable game becomes literally infinitely customizable in this way.

There are hundreds of hours worth of things to do - such that the "main path" as it is called is less than 10% of the game. I won't go into secrets here as discovering them is part of the experience.

Fantastic game. Experiment with programmable weapons in a procedurally-generated, fully-distructable sandbox. I enjoy playing this game while listening to podcasts in a room with all the lights out.

Noita encapsulates the essence of pure rouge-like. The world has incredible depth, and is brimming with secrets and easter eggs, but it is also brutally hard, and with each perma-death the player gains more knowledge, etc.. The game's most striking aspect comes from its truly unique wand creation mechanic, which is set at the center of its gameplay. Wand-creation tasks the player with combining together multiple spells to create the larger effect of their wands. As your knowledge of the world and its mechanics grow, so does your spell-crafting competancy. The types of things people can make with these wands are absurd. I've seen wands that can destroy the entire screen, deal infinite damage, teleport across parallel words, or even instantly complete the game (no joke). All this only serves to illustrate that Noita's wand-building fosters creativity and ingenuity in a very unique way. The player is no-longer just confined to fireballs and lazers. Want to create a wand that shoots 4 homing boulders each of which explodes into buzzsaws? Noita has you covered. Combined with nuanced physics and alchemy engines, Noita achieves the ultimate wizard sandbox, and is a truly fun game.

To preface before you begin this journey, I implore you to try your very best to not look up anything that you can for this game. The essence of discovery in this game is unparalleled, and is a far and refreshing shot from the hand holding tutorials that every triple A title wants to hold your hand through these days. I don't think any other game encapsulates the potential of what 'magic' can be better than this one. At the time of this review, Hogwarts legacy came out not too long ago and I don't have any doubts that that game showcases a fantastic interpretation of a magical world, but the gameplay of being magical pales in comparison to Noita by far. When you discover a unique way of becoming powerful each run, there's nothing else like it. It might take you a while to get there, and the journey will be brutal without question. Noita WILL punish what you do and do not know about its world, inhabitants, and mechanics. Each death, as frustrating as it may be at times, will teach you something valuable to keep you alive just a little bit longer each time. Without looking anything up, it took me roughly 133 hours to beat the game, but that does not mean I completed everything. Far from it, there are secrets abound and stumbling upon them is always fantastic as each that you find each time gives you just a sliver into the world that Noita offers. There's so much more that I can say about this game but I'm currently freeballing this review and I will come back to update it over time. But the only thing that you need to know is:

It is by far the best magic game I've ever had the pleasure and at times, dismay, of playing. But it's fucking worth it.

This game is too difficult.
But not in a legit way. It's totally unfair and brutal.
I can accept that the game does not explain anything to you like Dark Souls, but the rest is unfun at all. I like hardcore games, but when they come with a calculated difficult. The difficult of this game is totally artificial. Enemies hit you out of the screen, and you can do nothing; there are tons of environmental damages impossible to dodge at all; the lack of health resources and the possibility to empower yourself in very little way obligate you to search for exploits via the web, some of which are very tricky to bypass this crazy system. Why do that? Just give us more resources and stop.
Actually, 90% of the game is spent on the first 3 layers. If you don't get lucky enough to bypass harshly designed gameplay, you simply can not advance, even if you are the most skilled player in the world.
Give us the possibility to craft wands everywhere, or at least to manipulate spells found on new wands by default, and add a consistent system to gain health.

Noita is a simulational sandbox where every pixel is given some level of physics based on the matter its made of and designed to realistically interact with the other pixels around it. Based on the little I've seen from others talking about the game I understand that there's a whole nest of secrets beneath the surface, but damn if I could get anywhere with it.

The simulational aspect is a technical feat, no doubt about it, but I just couldn't find a hook to keep me exploring. The starting areas were pretty bland and despite the novel ways you can interact with the world it ends up being more an exploration of all the ways you can get yourself killed.

For the right person this is a very engaging and deep sandbox but for me it was just a bunch of uninteresting pit falls I couldn't compel myself to try and work past. A great tech demo but not a very engaging game.

Noita throws you into a world simulated down to the last pixel, a world which will brutally murder you over and over again. However, the game is so much fun you probably won't care.

A perma death rogue-lite perhaps best described as Terraria meets Spelunky with a sadistic difficulty level even the Souls series would be proud of. 
The rogue-lite element is awesome but this game has so much more to offer then you first would suspect a has a real clever design that is also somewhat wild. 
Also, which i did not expect to be so immersive, the lore is actually very good as well and has some nice hidden stuff for those who like to go into the true depths of this game.
A wonderful mysterious fantasy world with over-the-top alchemy mechanics that will have you in stitches while you are fearing for your very life in the same moment. 
Nolla Games has created a true masterpiece that will keep me busy for years to come without a doubt.

EDIT: Currently on my first real OP run, unlocking new levels of awesome every new area i encounter :) 
i highly recommend looking for helpful mods in the Steam workshop as they can make your life a lot easier while not being detrimental to the game. Also...... poor computer ... do not let the pixel style fool you into that this game does not need serious computing power when the wand combo gets....chaotic :P

This game isn't easy, but rewards your time with vast, mysterious areas and bosses, wand building that requires many hours of trial and error to even get a basic understanding of it and many, many (mostly self-inflicted) deaths. But the more time you invest, the clearer it all gets and the more fun it'll make as your builds get better and better.

The only thing I miss: being able to do more than one run in parallel. Once you started a long run it would still be nice to warm up to a new game instead of just going straight back in. You can do this manually by copying the save game folder, do your warm up run and copy the folder back, but this feels like something that the game should offer on its own. Not sure why no save slots exist.

Risk of Rain, Terraria, Binding of Isaac. These games all have some core elements that I have really enjoyed, and Noita has a lot of the greatness from those games. It is definitely more hardcore on a difficulty side, but the game offers you ingredients and once you understand how to build a recipe you can cook up some awesome combinations.

One major downside to the game is it doesn't really walk you through the mechanics. I'd recommend before giving up on the game, go look for a tips for beginners video or something. DunkorSlam is a great content creator for the game and a lot of his videos helped me get over the initial learning curve so I could enjoy the game.

But that's okay. You might do better next time, or you might not.

Build. Die. Repeat... 
Build up a sweet wand arsenal, full of some weird and truly spectacular spells. Die while being polymorphed as a flying sheep, a falling rock? Maybe your own wand? Drowned? Or to some random chain reaction explosion from mobs fighting 2 floors below...Repeat till you rage quit and reopen the game 10min later after you laugh at the pain like some sadist...

Imagine playing a tough-as-nails roguelike tens or even hundreds of times until you finally win a run, and then you realize that "winning a run" is maybe 15% of the content available to you and there are hundreds of secrets and quests you haven't even scratched the surface of. 

Noita is that.

There is the layer of game that is perfectly enjoyable and fulfilling and fun that is "go into the mountain, progress through levels, beat the final boss". You can do that for many tens of hours.

The other layers are all incredibly arcane and obscure objectives, places, and events that may or may not require your build to basically be Eldritch God-tier and require 5+ hour runs to complete.

If it turns you off to know that a huge portion of the game is nearly impossible to engage in as a casual player, maybe stay away. But do know that even the main gameplay loop is intensely fun and challenging and rewarding.

And then a pixel of acid instakills you.

this game is really fun, but dear fucking god is it ruthless, i doubt you will get past the second floor for your first few runs. the physics engine is my favorite part, it has very few flaws and i find new and interesting aspects about it every time i launch the game, i learned that even stationary objects id normal assume to have zero mechanics and just be a solid block of object actually have things like wheels that spin, on its own it sounds boring but there are so many of these little details that make it super cool.

ive loved just burning wooden structures to watch the embers fall and for the structure to break down, but after you destroy every explosive and set the map on fire it dose encounter some frame-rate issues, the same goes for gases. the only issues ive found are that materials like ice that break and fall down after breaking can occasionally not follow those rules and stay stationary after breaking, even when completely suspended in the air, also the bounce mechanic is a little to unpredictable, sometime if i shot at an angle smaller than 90 degrees itll just bounce right back at me, which makes no damn sense, but i think that's limited to just the bouncy ball spell or whatever its called.

the biggest feature being the wands is more intriguing then you are led to believe upon first launching the game, you have very little to work with at the start but eventually you build up a good catalog of spells to play with, but finding spells isn't the only exploitative aspect, take your time and just walk around the levels, there's stuff in every corner.

Noita is one of those games that wants you to sink more time into it than you realize. Looking through videos on YouTube shows just how insane some of the things in this game are. There's a whole alchemy system, quests, a new game plus (if I'm looking at it correctly), and a lot of unique interactions between things. The game is basically done with development at the time of writing this, with a few patches coming out to fix some issues as of recent, though there is a dedicated modding scene for people who want a little more in this massive game.

It took me multiple attempts over years to get into Noita. After hearing multiple times that the game is amazing, I would try it, hate it, die, and give up.

So why the positive review?

Noita is a game about knowledge, and once you get over that initial difficulty bump to playing the game, it's incredibly fun. It's a game that gives you far more tools than you could ever need, but doesn't tell you how to use any of them. It's full of secrets, refuses to elaborate, and hides dozens of ideas in plain sight. I write this review after finally beating the game for the first time, after over 100 attempts, and I beat the final boss of the game using pollen. I have yet to play another game where you beat the last boss using an allergy, and I don't expect to see it again any time soon.

Noita is a tough game. Noita's job is to tell you that you died. Your job is to figure out how to not.

And then die anyways.

This game is not for everyone.
While I have spent at time of writing, 200 hours on this game, I would point out that there are aspects of this game that I have obviously enjoyed, as I'd hope to be the case for anybody that has spent a little over a whole week of their life playing. I don't want people to be necessarily discouraged from playing this game by my review, but I want people to know what exactly they are getting themselves into beforehand. The issues I have will be listed in three parts, in this order. The games difficulty, the time the game demands out of your life, and the obtuse secrets involved. But first, a "short" rundown of my experiences before hand. 
I had my first clear after getting about 70 hours of experience into the game. I think I cleared with 6 or 7 orbs. At the point of the map that I'd explored (And regrettably my rapid fire wand was also my drill wand), I had to reset the game several times due to performance issues. On later runs I learned that this could be offset by not making a luminous drill wand also shoot ranged bouncy projectiles, While playing, the game seems to encourage teleporting in/out of holy mountains or drilling your way out of them so that you can come back later to edit your wands. This means a ton of backtracking, which I quickly got accustomed to. After my first clear I decided to install some mods that would save me time, such as more storage space for spells and items, as well as a free tinker with mods anywhere perk at the start of the run. I understand that this might seem like cheating to some players, and I admit that aspects of this can at times feel a bit scummy, but ultimately, this level of cheating matters little in this game. With how fragile the character is, it doesn't matter if you're carrying around 5 tablets and 13 potions, they aint gonna help ya. Tinkering with wands anywhere exists in the game, and generally feels like a better way to play, as you wouldn't need to spend as much time backtracking already explored areas. This perk helps speed things up, but if you can't find good wands or spells, it aint gonna help you either. Around 100 hours in, On a really successful and long run I picked up what I thought was going to be a spell and it was an "elemental essence". This started exploding things around me, and I nearly died. I turned off the game and installed another mod that would allow me to remove perks. For a long while I'd only used it the once, but never actually removed the mod. Later I realized that using this mod would allow the gambling perk to generate infinite perks. I did so once to see how op I could get. Didn't matter cause I got polymorphed and instantly died. To exemplify my point about cheating, while it doesn't FEEL good to do, the game doesn't care and will still destroy you. My max orb count is 21, and during that run I had started with every perk I could have wanted. I'd built god wands and had climbed a secret area twice for some special wands. Spent 7 hours doing this. I just wanted to see what a max orb boss would have looked like to fight, to see if I could make a wand that could beat him without looking online. Didn't get the chance. Polymorph and cheating aside, let's talk about the main issues I have, starting with that difficulty.
1. Difficulty.
I think that this is self evident by the fact that the game has weeded out half of the players before they were even able to get to the third "stage". Everything can and will kill you. You try to fire a wand you pick up, and the spells are in the wrong order or configuration. You're dead. You step on the wrong pixel, you're on fire. Spell bounces and hits a crate of explosives? Run over. Sometimes. While experience can solve these problems, sometimes things you can't explain or had no chance to deal with will end your run. Try to fire a wand that you know to be a safe wand (At a distance), but there is a single pixel that you couldn't see against the dark background that your projectile hit and you explode on the spot. Getting hit by enemy projectiles that spawn off screen. Or when an enemy unit picks up a wand that has an earthquake or nuke spell in it and fires it once. These is nothing that can be done about some of these potentially game ending events.
2. Time investment.
This game doesn't care about your time. I understand that rogue-like games have permadeath and are supposed to be difficult. But the sheer volume of content needed to actually "complete" the game takes so much time that you'd have to be a monster to do it in one sitting, which from what I can tell, most rogue-likes are made for. The fact that you can lose everything after playing one file for over 7 hours is one of the most punishing things you can experience from a video game. If you just want to get to the bottom and clear the boss, this aint a huge issue, but if you actually want to explore the bulk of the content this game offers, you need to be fully ready to spend nearly a whole 24 hour day of your life on a single run. Some streamers that I have watched have taken 18+ hours (and i'd argue that they are experts at this game) to get the secret content behind this investment wall.
3. Speaking of secrets.
You won't complete any bonus content in this game without looking parts of it up. You may come across notes on the wall in an area of the game, and wonder about it. But you'd be suicidal to actually willingly explore the area the "key" is in without a purpose to go there. I don't know if this was a glitch but when I finally obtained the musical notes, I went back to that wall and the notes were gone. I didn't think i'd have to write them down. Other secrets are just as obtuse. I don't want to spoil anything, just in case what I've mentioned so far seems like a great CBT time, but there is a sequence of events involving statues that I thought were just decorations until I saw somebody kick one.
While I respect difficulty in videogames, considering that I've played vanilla and modded Minecraft on Hardcore several times in the past, these traits tied together like they are in this game leads to a feeling that is generally more punishing than rewarding. There are several things I think you must ask yourself before you ready yourself to sit down and play this game. "Do I have a reaction time good enough to dodge projectiles fired from off screen?", "Am I smart enough or willing to learn the spell wrapping and speed augmenting wand building mechanics?", "Am I willing to let multiple hours of my life blink away instantly?", "Am I generally a lucky person?" If any of those are a no, you might not have a good time with this game.
If you read my whole review, thank you. I don't mean to shit on this game, but I don't know if I have much will to keep at it at this point. I must commend the designers for making something that I got 200+ hours of "playtime" out of. Was it "enjoyment"? Some of it. Sure. Maybe most. But it's bittersweet.
UPDATE:
I have put in an additional 400 hours of playtime. I have just now collected the final achievement. I stand fully by everything I previously wrote.

It's slightly better than many other random number generator pixel trash games, but it's full of despicable, annoying and artificial gameplay mechanics that are literally there solely to unfairly increase playtime to mind boggling levels, before even having the CHANCE to complete the game.
Number one mechanic? Health can solely and only be replenished during level transitions (except for a ridiculous perk that probably spawns once every 300 runs)
To win the game you basically must travel 500 meters downwards in randomly generated caves. The problem is, after "each 100" meters, with each health replenishment, basically, difficulty increases, and enemies deal progressively higher damage, while your damage relies entirely and absolutely on the items you find. And guess what: the more you unlock, the lower the chances for the actually useful perks and weapons. Exactly: I was closer to ending the game in the first two hours, than what I was in the following 30.
You might be drawn by the pixel animations and smoke and fire dynamics, but it's not worth it. I would never have purchased this **** if I had played a demo first.
Needless to say, with mods it becomes playable and even enjoyable, but the game is not worth it otherwise. It's RNG rubbish to the maximum possible extent, and It's mind boggling that there's not a single honest review for it.

Having enemies that drop out of nowhere; cock their shotgun while falling in the air, then land next to you and basically instant kill you isn't really fun. You could argue, git gud; just shoot him out of the air while he's falling. In the second you have to register what's even happening before you die. Sure it's possible to deal with; but a game that requires that amount of attention is just draining to me personally. It's more like a jump scare than anything else. I don't want to be on edge the entire time I'm playing the game but you pretty much have to be. If that's what you want then this could be fun for you. I wasn't really looking for horror experience but that's basically the best this game has to offer. I also think  many combinations of wands are more dangerous to you then to your enemies. It kinda makes a lot of the choices just straight up bad. Which is kinda lame. It's not horrible game by any means, but it's not for me and I wouldn't recommend it to people with similar tastes.

I return to Noita over and over. I consume it in small doses but, over the long term, I never seem to tire of it. There's something, well, magical about it. The game crackles with ideas and is shot through with a profound sense of playfulness and fun.

I get the sense the designers, programmers, musicians, and everybody involved just got to *play* while they were making it, as though the development process for those who were working on it was at least as much a sandbox as the final game is for players.

I think it's going to stand the test of time and age very well. I can see myself continuing to play it for many years.

Very fun and infinitely replayable, Devs and content creators are still working with and on this game and was last updated this year. At first it is very tough to get through but once you do all of the suffering pays off with your first win.

Genuinely challenging for the first couple dozen runs but after you get the hang of it, get some progress, slow down a bit, and learn from each mistake this game has quickly become a favorite. It's just one of those games I can have a run that lets me tear through enemy after enemy, not even batting an eye as to my health or the dangers of the world to the next run struggling within the first area because I let a single orange pixel catch me off guard.
 
There is so much this game has to offer, from understanding the wand building mechanics, learning the world layout, messing with alchemy, discovering secrets, to completing quests without any direction or objective through sheer intuition (and maybe a lot of help from the wiki and community). You could easily push this game into the hundreds of hours, if not thousands, if you want to 100% it. It might even get you really thinking about what is actually possible in this game, how you can go from such a simple starting point and get to world ending god status over the course of a single run. 

I highly recommend picking it up with or without sale and persevering through the challenges and mistakes that make you feel like uninstalling and refunding. It should challenge you, and in doing so it makes overcoming the mistakes that much more rewarding. I know it did for me, getting to each level of understanding gives me such a feeling of accomplishment.

I can't recommend this game, it's just too hard for its roguelike format. All of its systems push you to make fun, reckless decisions that could blow you up or put you in a terrible spot. That's fun. Losing all progress because you try to have fun is not. Playing the game as it incentivizes you to is an incredibly boring, tedious experience as you camp and wait for enemies to come close so they can be fought on your terms. The bones of two great games are here, but they destructively interfere with one another to result in a frustrating game that wants you take risks but insta-kills you if you try.

Gameplay
✅ Epic spell craftin 'n shootin, rock throwin, platform jumpin, flask flingin, boss killin action, with Alchemy Mechanics, and a spell system that will boggle your mind and amaze your eyes
🟦 Lots of travel through tons of empty "scenery" and maybe fight one or two monsters every ten minutes
🟦 Tedious and repetitive gameplay with mediocre rewards that make you regret life but keep trying
🟦 Watch a cutscene for 30min, then run to the next room to trigger another 25min cutscene

Visuals
🟦 MSPaint Stick Figures On Notebook Pages
✅ Elemental Pixel Particle Simulator w/ beautiful, fully destructible environments (aka Powder Toy meets Metroidvania)
🟦 -slaps screen- this baby has more cell shading than that GameCube game about the kid and his red boat
🟦 Actually Crisis 3

Soundtrack
