I had a hard time figuring out how to describe this game. Here's what I've settled on:

Noita Hates You.

It does not matter how far along you are. It doesn't matter what you're doing in the moment. It doesn't even matter if the nearest enemy is 4 klicks away. Noita can - and will - find a way to ruin your run.  Maybe you mix two pixels that really don't like each other, maybe you just get hit by a falling rock. Maybe you explode. All of these things have happened to me separately before.

But yknow what? It's fine.

I have modded the absolute bejesus out of this game, to the point that it's nearly unrecognizable. There is a plethora of online resources to help you understand the earlygame and get better as you go, learning what spells to use and what not to use, how to get gold, how not to die (and you will die a lot), etc. So if I had to distill any advice in this review, I would say this: slow down, take your time, dont charge into things. And if you die, you die. Big deal. Just start a new run.

Good luck.

I really enjoy the mechanics and wand building in this, thoroughly. In fact those and the secrets are why I keep throwing myself at this game so much, because I'm hoping I get to experiment with more spells and explore. The game is brutal, and even the skilled can't guarantee their survival. The odds are against you, and if you want to have any semblance of a chance then you must consult a wiki or a guide (something I have no problem with, but with Noita it is REQUIRED to know everything). Success in the early game relies very heavily on RNG for you to find the right materials, spells, wands, potions, ect. because if you don't it's like playing with a missing arm. 

Overall, I really enjoy what the game is, but the patients required to actually PLAY it is exhausting and causes me to not want to come back to it after unfairly dying (be it a god run or off spawn).

This is my favourite Genre of game. 
Not Platformer.
Not Roguelike.
Not Indie.
SYSTEMS BASED.
Notia is a game built upon of variety of systems. For example, Heat water and it evaporates and leaves steam. Freeze water and it becomes solid. EVERY pixel in this game has a property that can be interacted upon within the games systems and it can lead to utter, hilarious chaos sometimes. 
At it's core Notia IS a Roguelike Platformer but what sets it apart is the SYSTEMS. As you progress you pick up all sorts of spells and passive abilities that always have drawbacks and boons depending on the scenario.
A wand that Fires TNT? That's great!
A want that Fires TNT when you permanently emit a death beam from your eyes. VERY BAD! Because that beam will immediately ignite the TNT as you fire it causing an explosion millimetres from your face.
Also, The dedicated KICK button is an absolute godsend for a game like this. Kicking ash into a lake of oil is VERY satisfying!
This is a game where you WILL die in unexpected ways regularly but you will be able to work out what it was and be weary of it happening again. Do NOT cast your frost shield while underwater for example!
If all this sounds boring and frustrating to you then Notia problem won't be your cup of tea. If ANYTHING above sounds fun to you then I 100% recommend purchasing it.

A lot of fun, a lot to explore. It's a little bit like Spelunky so if you like that you'll probably like this. There's a lot of physics stuff to discover, and figure out how to take advantage of the environment
Life is fragile.

Its fun because each run can really take you in such a different direction. It truly feels like a rogue-like as virtually every run will yield a different path (assuming you don't immediately die, which will happen a lot, then its kind of the same run, but in a good way.)

The environment is such an incredible trope for a video game. When they say every pixel is incorporated, they mean Every. Single. Pixel. It makes for some incredibly dynamic and at times hilarious runs. 

The replayability comes from several facets of this game. Obviously the uniqueness of each run lends a lot to it, but another very interesting portion is the minimal to non-existent explanation of how to play. This may seems like a fault but really lends to the game because as you die and learn you start to feel very proud of yourself as you piece together different strategies and your play style becomes more polished. Before you know it your crafting insane spell combos in anticipation of ridiculous possibilities. The third part that lends to replayability is definitely the kicks. Kicking shit is some of the dopest stuff I've ever seen.

Would I recommend this game? I would comfortably recommend it at an 8.5/10 scale. Higher if you enjoy rogue-likes or challenging dungeon crawlers.

There are good kind of difficult games that require you to get good at the game. And then there are bad kind of difficult games that are difficult because you're completely at the mercy of RNG. That said, Noita is HORRENDOUSLY bad kind of difficult.

Not only do you need to get lucky at getting perks that make a run doable but you're also at the mercy of RNG to get even decent wands and spells to help you keep yourself alive. Yes, there are some cheeky tricks you can do, but in order to do said tricks, you STILL need RNG to be on your side. However I'm 90% sure that the game is hard-coded to give you perks and spells from certain pools, rather than being truly random. Oh and even if you do get lucky and get a wand that can kill the final boss in five seconds, you're then gonna die to something like acid or lava, which essentially mean insta-death if you're not moving.

And I'm not even going to begin on the bugs, like
1) getting stuck on random pixels you can't do anything about except beg for the game to realize it's BS and delete those three pixels off of you, 
2) small gaps you SOMEHOW can get through ONCE, only to realize that it's a dead-end but then the game won't let you back out, killing the run right then and there, OR
3) how the game can stack a pile of enemies inside one another, especially with spiders, which will then trick you to think it's just one spider, you shoot it as you're getting closer to get the gold, only then to be attacked by the other ELEVEN spiders that were hiding in one pile, thus killing you before you can even properly begin a run. Just to name a couple of things.

Don't trust those gifs and videos with wands that basically just delete anything and everything with 50 perks loaded up to essentially nullify all damage. You're not gonna get to that point without mods (which disable achievements, BTW).

This game is just frustration.

Avoid.

That said, I'm still going to 100% this heap of garbage since I'm already here. Pray for my mental health.

--- EDIT 03.07. ---

I should be done with this fucking pile of garbage but it just keeps bugging out like the pixely shit it is. How the fuck is acceptable that when the game starts stuttering and I save and exit to get rid of said stuttering, the game forgets about your run?!?! What the FUCK is wrong with the morons who made this game?! Not to mention how many times I lost goddamn hours and hours of progress because of all the crashes that have wiped my progress! And as a bonus, it turns out that because this game has been so horribly programmed, it can't handle Steam Cloud properly. Just today the game decided to REALLY try to sync up the Cloud files and decided to override my files on my computer. So in a nutshell, apparently I lost quite a bit of progress I've done in three weeks. More specifically, 1/3 of all the enemies in the "codec" are now blank again.

How the Hell do people defend this game?!

--- EDIT 08.07. ---

DONE!

Jesus Christ, never in my live have I encountered a game that handles its own data as poorly as this heap of garbage. Seriously, how stupid can these excuses for game developers be when they are perfectly aware of how easy it is to crash their game and yet they can't be bothered to create an auto-save function?! Instead of that, the game will desperately scramble to find whatever bits of data it can find but it often forgets about some of the key parts of the game like, oh I dunno, some of the more recent spells and perks you acquired and the very existence of parts of the world! If your game crashes, the Island on the West side of the map is gone 95% of the time.

Actually, here, a screenshot to show just a hint of the kind of garbage behavior you can expect from this game:

https://steamcommunity.com/id/juud0lf/screenshot/2052001304413311068/

Yes, those are golden outline on "unknown" enemies. If you crash after killing a new enemy, the game will remember that you've killed a new enemy but doesn't remember that you've killed said enemy. Good luck figuring that out with the bosses that only spawn once in the very specific parts of the world! And that's just the tip of the iceberg of the technical issues!

My previous points also still stand. This game is NOT fun for those who actually want to play it. The only reason this game has the "Difficult" tag is because of the technical difficulties, the sheer amount of luck you need to even start a decent run and the amount of stuff you either need to figure out painfully one attempt at a time or open up a Wiki. "Okay, attempt #8 at this boss, this time I have the Omega Saw!" *pew* "Oh damn, the saw actually got- [i]Oh he can copy my spells even after he's dead and he fired about 30 Omega Saws at me, that's cool![/i]

I would rather go through the stress of seeing blood in my urine and stressing out if I have cancer or something else again rather than ever playing this game again. And dare I say, I'd rather play the bot-infested TF2 again rather than playing another minute of Noita.

"have you ever wanted to play a game that looks like terraria but has all the pain, suffering and depth of a dark souls game? well noita is for you the game gives you just enough information to start and that's it. this game is like someone took ten, 1000 piece puzzle dumped them on the floor, threw away the boxes and injected you with a lethal dose of Fentanyl and said solve them," - source - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UhetH7PwVh8

Every single pixel is fully a fully simulated piece of the environment with interactive properties. Take that fact and attach it to the greatest 2D Spell Casting combat, then add the most ranom and interesting magic and wand creation I've ever seen. That is Noita in a nutshell. Like Terraria and Teardown had a little Rogue-Like Mage-Baby lol
  I've never really gotten too far in a rogue-like. I have some fun in them, but never push through to the end - until this game. It's just way too fun when you start learning how to benefit from the systems at play. There are also so many ways to re-balance or completely modify the gameplay and difficulty for anyone that feels the game is a bit too punishing.
 The game probably isn't for everyone, but if you love Terraria, Teardown, and roguelikes - then you'll probably adore this game.

An actual diamond in the rough, which will somehow find it's way into your bloodstream to kill you out of spite. Noita is a game with zero handholding. No game is like it. EVERY pixel is simulated. Threw a bomb to get to a heart? well now you've set fire to the wood around you, which caused a potion of acid to fall over and now you're melting to death while far enough to have the false illusion of safety. This game will beat you to a bloody pulp, it takes a certain kind of stubborn player to enjoy. Also has an incredible modding community, and the devs are back making updates again. I am not exaggerating when I say this is my favourite game ever.

10 / 10, once you get the hang of things you rarely feel like you've had no say in your death, it's a bit rough in some places but with the right knowledge that just adds to it's charm. Balance is an illusion, some spells will actively cause you more harm than any enemy ever could, but with a single other spell turn into level clearing murder machines. Other spells have near zero downside to ever using. Incredible wand-building system which gives more build diversity than any procedural roguelike could ever. Flaming sawblades that lash out tentacles homing in on wands in the world only to explode into actual living deer which rapidly multiply and explode? Doable. Genuine actual ballistic missiles which run away from enemies, eating terrain then after a delay firing out a square of tiny death particles, only to cast another wand which turns each and every little particle that just created into literal nukes? This game won't stop you. Magic which creates massive bubbles of ice, flooded with water, teleporting around chaotically towards enemies only to latch on to them, downing them while repeatedly firing circles of healing magic only to prolong their suffering? Just hope you don't drown yourself. This game knows no bounds. The pixel sim is beautiful and brutal, a thorny rose which will cause you to bleed out just by looking at it. Alchemy which explodes, burns, freezes, zaps, melts, and tries it's hardest to murder you. Come across the right reactions and you might brew flasks of infinite wealth and vitality, or melt entire biomes with all consuming void liquid. 

Noita is a game like no other. And if you've got the patience, you can go on endless self imposed challenges, play with even more content mods, speedrun to beat the game in literal seconds, there are users with thousands upon thousands of hours for a reason. I will never find a game quite like noita again, a literal masterpiece made of divine spite from a handful of sadistic arson-inclined finnish people behind other brilliant games like Baba Is You (this game also has reality bending tomfoolery, to a lesser extent!) and The Swapper. 

Do yourself a favour, buy this game. If you can't handle it, I understand.

This game is difficult, but the difficulty decreases as you learn the game. There's skill involved, but a lot of the skill is dependent on what you already know. Knowledge of how the game is played and works can compensate for a lack of skill, in many cases.

This makes it a pretty rewarding experience. It also trivializes death in a lot of cases because, once you get used to dying, every step you retrace can be done faster and with a better plan. Success, in this, isn't about completing the game, but seeing how much better you can do this life than last life.

The physics are great. Since there are so many calculations and the engine isn't perfect, it does need regular restarts to avoid crashes which have the potential to damage the save game. It helps to set a timer for about 15 minutes. Hopefully that gets better, one day. Until it does, however, this is the worst complaint I can come up with.

All around a great, thoughtful, inventive game that feels like a unique experience every time! Thanks for making this!

There is literally only two things not perfect about this game; and it's so obscure that i only found at after 250+ hours. The slime bats can catch on fire despite slime being the best fire extinguisher, and the popcorn flame skulls don't die to water. EVERYTHING else is perfect: the physics, the replayability, the development team, the handling, the movement, the potion system, the wand system, the modability, the art style, the SOUNDTRACK?? Adaptive music is hard to find, especially music that adapts to when and how OFTEN YOU SHOOT, as well as enemy numbers, type of enemies, UGH the underground desert theme is so fucking amazing.

To go more into detail, the game gives you the knowledge of the basic features (shoot, walk, kick, throw, and inventory) and you figure out the rest. What's challenging about everything, however, is how used to you probably are with games functions that simply don't make sense; you think "I bet the devs didn't think about this" THAT DOESN'T EXIST HERE! For example: Broken wands and concentrated mana. You throw a broken wand-- it shoots sporadically for a couple seconds and then stops. When you throw a wand into concentrated mana, however, it CONSUMES a liquid and keep shooting UNTIL THE LIQUID IS GONE!! It's such a niche tiny detail you wouldn't even think about, but the devs did. Got a fire based enemy? Kill it with water (the majority of the time). Got an enemy with a shield or protective armor? Use plasma cutters to cut through it. Worm eats a fire mage? Dies because the blood of a fire mage is lava. Did YOU consume lava?? YOU BURN INTERNALLY AND CANT PUT IT OUT WITH WATER!

This game is the best game I've ever played, the only thing I wish it had was a multiplayer mode where the enemy count is multiplied by the amount of people on your lobby.


--Spoilers--

OH, and there is SUCH an expansive world. How large? Literally INFINITE! It will not stop! You thought the cave was hard? There are far more caves, and far more enemies. Which one is the most dangerous? It's you, to yourself, and to others, but it's mostly yourself. Most of the time to an explosion because you forgot that your wand shuffles.

Noita is game about using your magical wands as weapons of mass destruction, to harness gold from the poor souls roaming the mines and Area’s bellow, to buy even Stronger wands and Spells.

Pros:
- Smooth controls and simple combat
- Large amount of Spells, wands, and unique trinkets
- The map itself is fairly big but thanks to the addition of parallel universes, it’s basically infinite
- Everything is destructible and can be broken down to its last pixel
- Amazing enemy design and variety
- Steam Workshop Supported

Cons:
- Secrets are hard to find and getting to them can be a mayor hustle as well (personal preference)
- Inventory System can be really annoying when trying to obtain/transport key items

Conclusion:
It is a game worth your money but I would not recommend it, if you can’t invest much of your free time into it. Runs can take hours and the game is not hesitant to severely punish you for even the slightest mistake you do.

This game is TOO random, even for a Roguelike. I get that's part of the appeal but this is a badly designed game for a variety of reasons :

1. Wand building, the only way you're going to figure out wand building is by watching a tutorial on YouTube. There is no indication that things like spell wrapping exist unless someone else tells you about it. This is TERRIBLE game design. Like unforgivably bad. I like games that don't spell everything out for you but most of the advanced mechanics or even just....regular mechanics you NEED to progress through the game are hidden behind YOUTUBE VIDEOS!

2. Starts suck....you always with 1 attack wand and one explosive(the vast majority of the time you're going to have a spark bolt and a bomb) and one flask. Your first job is to find water if you don't have it which is not fun, it's tedious. Then you have to explore the entire level for hearts and wands which may or may not drop. If they don't. Your run is unwinnable. Also have fun farming gold so you can buy the upgrades you need at the holy mountain because without those...again...your run is unwinnable. This is bad game design.

3. The coolness of the whole gimmick of every pixel being simulated wears off very quickly when you realize that all this actually really means 90% of the time is "every pixel can burn you to death, melt you death, blow you up, etc". You will almost never get the opportunity to actually use this mechanic in an interesting way to your advantage or really do anything cool with it yourself... Most of what this mechanic actually does in an average play is force you to pour water on yourself constantly all the time to avoid being hurt by acid, poison, fire, etc. This is bad game design.

4. The community has an entire term dedicated to the BS deaths in this game where you just seemingly randomly explode because something happened ten miles above you and acid landed on your head or whatever, they call it being "Noita'd"....if even your biggest fans are pointing out that the RNG nature of deaths is cheating them out of a win....you created a bad game.

5. There is a mechanic where you can "anger the gods" in this game but most of the time when it happens it's not because YOU did anything to upset them. Usually it will happen if any destruction or harm comes to holy mountains but usually this happens because a giant worm spawned at the bottom of the level and destroyed it long before you even  got there......when you anger the gods...or I should say....when a randomly generated blatantly unfair enemy angers the gods.....you basically start the next level and unless you have a powerful wand....you die... It's not something you can really avoid. A skeleton guy with a giant forcefield around him to avoid any of the meager damage you levvy at him kills you.....this can happen even in the first level before you can be reasonably expected to have much more than a spark bolt. This is terrible game design.

6. There are so many upgrades that are just completely worthless to most players. And since it's all RNG all the time....you're going to get them a lot. And they're gonna be it, it's entirely possible that no matter how well you're playing... You'll just get trash upgrades that you can't use....and your run is completely unwinnable...or you'll get upgrades that would be useful in tandem with something else that you never find. Etc. This is bad game design...I know I keep saying that but honestly it goes beyond that at this point ..this doesn't feel like a designed game anymore after a while. It feels like a slot machine. Hades is a roguelite game too with a lot of random elements but it's also consistent...enough...to work...I have a bias towards games with like... real actual level design in them....but a game like this CAN work even if it's not my preference. And this one doesn't.

The worst part is....this game is terrible...but it's also easy to like....and hard not to like...which means I keep coming back to it in short bursts like "this is gonna be the time this is gonna be where it gets good" I would not be surprised if this has happened to a lot of people....which means you waste even more time on a game that sucks....at least most of the time a bad game shows itself early on, you realize it's terrible very soon, you uninstall it and you never touch it again(that's what you SHOULD do if you play this....but you won't) because of this factor I actually think Noita might be the worst game I have ever played.

Noita is a brutally unforgiving game to learn. That being said, it is completely addicting and fun.

As with most games there are builds and combinations to learn that allow better survival and game play, so there is a bit of learning more than combat. The variety of spells, abilities, potions, etc. keep the game from getting stale.

Speaking of that, the primary method of playing is procedurally generated maps, so it's not just memorizing the layout and enemies. There is lots of exploration per level to build up your character. 

Overall it's not a bullet fest. You need to work your way through and strategize methods to clear out areas while avoiding the terrain trying to kill you. Good times!

Also great tinkering, procedural content and surprisingly huge game to explore; Rewards analysis, logic and dedication. 100% recommended.

A unique masterpiece, despite its technical flaws.  It's a rouge-like in a dark fantasy setting inspired by Finnish mythology, with supremely interesting lore that's deeply rooted in the ancient pursuits of hermeticism and European alchemy (i.e. bringing the world under your command by mastering and manipulating its physical elements).

The primary mechanic is spellcrafting, which involves the combination of spells, modifiers, and other components to achieve a truly incredible range of effects.  This ends up feeling like its own mathematical language, and is apparently structured like a card game under the hood.  It takes a lot of dedication to fully understand how this system works, but doing so pays off immensely.

There's also a chemistry engine that allows you to transform and transmute materials, effecting reactions that heed things like temperature and motion.  If you ever played a Falling Sand game in the mid-2000s, then imagine [i]that[/i] as a massive, intricate world with monsters and magic.  You'll be burning, electrocuting, and exploding both creatures and materials along your way, leaving the world scarred in your wake.

Pick it up if you like getting kicked in the dick.

I have played plenty of hard games in my life. Noita takes the cake. 

It is not for the faint of heart. It will do nothing to hold your hand. You are expected to figure your shit out or suffer the consequences. For people that buy the game, only 10% manage to get the achievement for beating the game. If you can't handle that, don't pick it up. But if you can suffer the difficulty, if you can weather the shitstorm, this game holds uniquely in-depth secrets and mechanics waiting for you to exploit them.

No healing methods, 101 ways to be set on fire or covered in acid ect and thus your health depletes quickly unless you are smart, however, there are so many situations where it is out of your control as enemies can attack you, even with ranged attacks, before the player can see them. There are spells in the game such as explosion which literally just removes your health bar 90% of the time. Your hour long run can be stopped short by trying something new or turning a corner and getting blasted point blank by an overpowered enemy. The enemies after a certain point all explode into various gases or oil or fire which becomes utter chaos and unfun to deal with.  I enjoy playing the game but i do not recommend it. its very unsatisfying most of the time. you are constantly forced to douse yourself in water to prevent death and whilst youre doing so, you get lit up and killed by various enemies. Not to mention the RNG in the game can be ridiculously good but mostly bad. Most of the early game wands are utter trash and you need a good understanding of the wand stats and spells you can use without killing yourself in order to survive without min maxing peeking around corners and effectively sucking all the fun out of the game. The game is brilliant to explore and experiment and theres so much to it. it really is a great game. BUT i just cannot recommend it.

When I first played this game I didn't enjoy it because I'm used to faster paced less forgiving roguelike games such as Nuclear Throne and Isaac. Years after release and the name of the game is still "getting stuck on random pixels on the screen that refuse to go away when you blast it with explosives". The game is fun when you are in mid air, casting spells and hitting things from offscreen or being immune to damage. In literally any other situation you are just asking to get clipped into some random pixel and die because you are now stuck for several seconds until the game figures out you are stuck (yes, being stuck is so ingrained into the game that there is a system that noclip the player after several seconds).

If you move at high speed (fall from high elevation/acceleratum) you'll randomly clip into parts of the wall and get yourself stuck. You can sometimes squeeze yourself through into tight areas and be unable to get out even though the terrain has not changed. There are spells that spawn objects with collision box (summon cart) and you can instantly get yourself stuck the moment you cast them (they explode btw). Use the teleport spell against a ceiling and you'll randomly get stuck in it (sure you can escape by shooting elsewhere, but why does this even need to happen in the first place?)

The worst part is that even undamaged walls can sometimes just cause you to clip into it. The clearest example is the dense rock wall that surrounds the chasm east of the mines, but realistically any wall can do this. If you fly against these you'll randomly get stuck, and to make it worse you'll be stuck in a flying state which means you can't even regenerate your flight gauge to get out.

I sincerely cannot recommend any platformer where getting clipping/softlocking is a literal feature at this point.

Edit: I enjoyed the game during the beta but a lot of things seem to have been changed for the worse since. The game is barely playable without proper digging spell and now there are so many random crap spells diluting the drops that you'll have a tough time getting one. Let's be very honest: nobody cares about 20 variations of fireball/bombs that don't even dig through steel, which can appear on the literal first level. To make it worse there are some really nasty enemies now like the swapper enemy and the ghost that spawns with random wands. I really don't understand how these add anything to the game other than to add "lolsorandom XD" deaths and piss off the player.
It used to feel like a reasonable roguelike game, now it's just a glorified tech demo with some bare minimum attached.
I have been playing for about 66 hours and only now I managed to kill Kolmisilmä, this has been one of the worst experiences of my life. I highly recommend Noita.

Game is fun, some of the time.

Early game takes too long. 
-Try to speed through and you have no money to buy anything or re roll perks.
-Going slow and taking you time means you will find more hidden wands and items, but by the time to get to the interesting weapons and perks, you have been slogging for almost an hour. Finding anything interesting or useful is NOT guaranteed either.

Plenty of people love the game, look at the reviews. And I did at one point. But the tedium is becoming very apparent.

I think there is a good game buried under there, that shows itself every one and a while.
But the time/fun ratio is too off for me.

TL;DR
Early game is too slow and boring for the amount of times you will be playing it.
Mods might be able to fix, but this review page is for the game, not mods.


As a side note, the physics of the world kinda become blah after some time. A lot of emphasis on things burning, and this also takes way to long. TONS of floating single pixels you will get stuck on. You are also apparently wearing a nylon robe soaked in lighter fluid.

Great variety in spells, so much fun. That being said, this game sorely needs a progression mode where you restart at the beginning of the zone you died in, maybe with half health or such. I just find it annoying when you'll have an amazing wand and die before you get to use it or when I'm stuck in the first couple areas because I'm not playing my best. I get that it's a design choice, but to me it doesn't make sense to have the majority of players not ever see anything past the first 60% of levels. 

Yes, I can use the CheatGUI to get more health and see more of the game, but it's not the same. I get that eventually I'll get a good run but after two hours of being in the first few levels I just wanna quit because I want to do wand building, instead of collecting all the items and gold from the first level, over and over again.

The more I play, the more this rings true. I like difficult games but I guess I don't like difficult games that give you the feeling of making absolutely no progress after playing for hours. Games aren't supposed to always be about progress but when you consistently are stuck in the first half of the areas, it starts to be frustrating more than fun. Seems like I'm dying right as I get to the good part. 

Edit: As solutions I think an optional, somewhat limited(or not!) progress system would help. Other than that, maybe wands in earlier levels should have a bit more spell variety so you get to try stuff out.

I have a feeling this new update is going to be controversial due to the balancing changes, but I need to say: I love it. Before, I felt like despite my knowledge of the game, my 1-2 hour runs could be doomed from a bad seed; these changes allow for a variety of powerful spells to appear more often while also keeping everything as difficult as it was prior. I’m no longer feeling like I need to play the game exactly how it should be to finish a run; this update encourages to diversify play-styles and discover new possibilities. Major positives overall!

Absolutely incredible roguelike game with the best spell-crafting system in any game I've ever played.

[b]*Updated Review, 800 in-game hours later*[/b]
It is safe to say this is my favorite game of all time. I don't put that lightly. I will tag any potential spoilers - this game has soooo many secrets and hidden mechanics. The biggest issue Noita has is that its main mechanic, spellcrafting, is not explained to the player at all. While this is the only complaint I have, I also love and respect the decision to have the entire world - mechanics and all - be completely unknown at first. It is what makes this game so addictive as you uncover how huge and mysterious this world is. The amount of [i]things[/i] to learn feels damn near unlimited. And like any good roguelike, you are rewarded for breaking the game.

[b]The physics engine[/b] is primarily what drew me in and is still my favorite aspect. The "Every single pixel is simulated" concept is perfectly executed here with each pixel having a bunch of properties which in makes the world feel truly alive. Is it a soft material like dirt, or hard like steel? Is it flammable like wood, or fireproof like glass? Is it a liquid? A gas? Can it absorb explosions? Does it evaporate? If you look closely, you'll notice materials like metal will get rusty if water has been touching it. Try walking around and paying attention to the environment to see what sorts of unscripted events happen. I have countless memories of sitting back and watching a hilarious chain of events play out as if Noita was my own personal Rube Goldberg machine. For example, game starts > kick a mine cart down the entrance > knocks over a torch > catches a wooden floor on fire > floor burns away, oil barrel on top falls > barrel absolutely CRUSHES a nest of spiders (yay gold! [spoiler]2x bonus gold because it was an environmental kill![/spoiler]) > aforementioned fire has spread to a pile of coal > catches giant eyeball on fire > giant eyeball freaks out and searches for water > does not find water > explodes upon death, sending acid flying > acid touches the spider-crushing oil barrel > it explodes > I lose a huge chunk of health and catch on fire because I was collecting the spider nest gold. This type of thing plays out constantly and it can be pure chaos but it is such a great part of this game.

[b]Alchemy[/b] is built into the game so incredibly well that you don't even realize you're doing it. Day 0 alchemy lesson: Fire + Water = Steam. Day 1 alchemy lesson: [spoiler]pour some water from your flask into a pool of toxic sludge, it'll turn the whole pool into water[/spoiler]. I'm brushing over system, but it's so satisfying seeing all the different kinds of reactions, there are a ton to discover.

[b]Spellcrafting[/b] is the bread and butter of the game. I'm doing it a disservice by not putting it first in this gigantic wall of text. You will always come across some new combination of spells that make your jaw drop. I am going to describe the gist of building a wand to get you started, but it can be as simple or as complex as you want it to be. There are a ton of great guides out there, 95% of my Noita knowledge comes from DunkOrSlam.
[spoiler]You can modify any wand at a Holy Mountain. That's the place with the healing and the perks in between the levels.
First, There are [i]spells[/i]. These include things like Spark Bolt, Magic Arrow, Bouncing Burst, Bomb. A few spells have versions of themselves with a trigger, like Spark Bolt With Trigger. This will cast another spell after the initial spell hits something.
Also, there are [i]spell modifiers[/i] like Electric Charge, Damage Plus, Triple Spell.
When inspecting your wand from your inventory, it will either say Shuffle: Yes or Shuffle: No. in its description. [b]This is the key to understanding spellcrafting[/b]. If your wand is a shuffler (Shuffle: Yes), then every time you fire the wand, it will pick from all of the spells inside that wand and it will shoot one at random. If your wand is a nonshuffler (Shuffle: No), when you fire, it will shoot the left-most spell in the wand. When you shoot again, it'll go to the 2nd spell, and so forth.
Combining all of these ideas, a wand you could put together with common materials found in the world is: A nonshuffler with, say, 5 spell slots. Starting from the left, the wand slots have the following spells and modifiers: [u]Spark Bolt with Trigger[/u] (spell), [u]Fire Trail[/u] (modifier), [u]Double Spell[/u] (modifier), [u]Bouncing Burst[/u] (spell), [u]Bouncing Burst[/u] (spell). Every time you shoot this wand, a purple bolt will fire out. When that bolt hits anything, it will release 2 bouncing green balls which on are also fire. If we took the Fire Trail and moved it all the way to the left, now what would happen would be: A flaming purple bolt will shoot out of the wand, and when that flaming bolt hits anything, 2 (non-flaming) green bouncing balls will be summoned. Where the Flame Trail effect happens depends on where the modifier is in that chain of spells. It can be super confusing at first but just try moving things around and shooting the wand. [i]Experimentation is what Noita is all about[/i]. A very fun and easy build to try out is to slap the Homing Projectile modifier onto the Rock spell. You really can create ANY type of wand you can imagine. I have made world-deleting wands, ones that lag my computer so hard the game gets 1 frame per 10 seconds, and some that have so much recoil and explosions that my character looks like a rocket taking off into space without ever touching the jump button[/spoiler].

[b]The artstyle[/b] is absolutely perfect in my opinion. I am a huge sucker for well-done pixellated art, but this is another level of detail. The more you explore, the more immersed you get.

[b]The music[/b] is so good that I tracked down the band (shoutout to From Grotto) online and threw them a bunch of money out of pure appreciation for their work.

[b]The lore[/b] is very deep but seriously well hidden. You'll never piece it all together yourself unless you are a die-hard player. I am only just scratching the surface of the lore of this world, I know that sounds hard to believe with so many hours played but it is true.

[b]The perks[/b] add yet another layer of replayability as you learn how they interact with different spells and environments. They are one of my favorite parts of the game and are a big reason I keep coming back. [spoiler]Perks can often stack with themselves... so imagine what it looks like if you figure out a way to get 10 instances of the More Blood perk for example. Your world would quickly be flooded with blood as creatures from different factions fight each other. Now think about if you snagged a Vampirism perk, now you have infinite healing which is a hell of a luxury in this game. You're still gonna die, but you'll at least feel safer for a little while[/spoiler].

[b]The community[/b] is actually a huge bonus for this game. The modding scene is great (the modders are so good that you can now play Noita multiplayer) and the people that frequent the subreddit, Twitch, Discord etc tend to be super nice and helpful.

And ultimately, [b]the difficulty[/b] is the icing on the cake. It will make you sit in silence, mouth agape, as you stare at where your corpse [i]should be[/i] after some stupid mountain man picked up [spoiler]an always-cast Nuke wand[/spoiler] and deleted you both from existence.

THE CHRISTIAN PERSPECTIVE

The game (sort of?) portrays magic. Sorcery in real life is a sin. However, I don't think this is really portraying sorcery. Magic in real life isn't like in this game.

If you found a stick on the ground which could shoot lasers, you probably wouldn't call it sorcery, you'd call it awesome.

If you do believe that the portrayal of magic in this game is akin to real life sorcery (I disagree) then see my review of Fallout New Vegas for more on "Should video games allow the player to roleplay an evil character?"

Super fun and challenging rougelite!

Edit:
After a year and a half of playing, this has become one of my favorite games of all time. The depth of the wand crafting is truly unlike anything I've ever seen in another game. So much room for creativity.

Be warned, the game makes no effort to explain itself to players. While a player can definitely come to understand some of the basic mechanics from experimenting and messing around in the world, the vast majority of this game (MANY wand/spell mechanics, bosses, secrets, hidden locations, parallel dimensions) will only be accessible to people to who search for guides or watch streamers discuss how to access this content. I didn't like that at first, but the trick is that even when you know all the theory, reaching and achieving this content in a normal run is still a massive challenge and makes the game really fun. I couldn't recommend this game any higher than I do!

High recommend, but go in knowing you won't be reaching the end anytime soon, just mess around with the plethora of tools the game gives you.

Disclaimer: Below might have a few spoilers but hopefully not much.

Edit: After playing this game for 10 more hours or so I feel qualified enough to say that this game is one of the most fun and most infuriating experiences you can have in your life. To expand on that I have a story for you, to start I got a wand of short teleport and I got a matter eater wand basically making the whole game world easy to get to. HOWEVER after 3 hours of play I get a nuke wand and I forgot that I had glass cannon and decided to shoot an enemy causing the entire ice level to disintegrate instantly, luckily I had an extra life but I died anyway due to me falling down into lava after the explosion, which made me stop playing the game for about 2 months. On another note I really like this games use of magic and how the wand building system works, using mana to fuel spells you can effectively build any spell you want with enough time and modifiers. Along with the magic system I really like the world of Noita and i'm not just talking about the lore. The level design is really interesting because normally in rouge likes you move from one level to the next sometimes going to a sub level like in Enter The Gungeon with the abbey of the true gun while in Noita you can (with the right spells or equipment) move between the levels and sub levels and in doing so get better spells and equipment. This wouldn't be a review without talking about what I feel are bad parts about the game so im going to begin with the difficulty. Noita is a hard game enemies can kill you instantly, you can kill you instantly, and even singular pixels can kill you which makes the game more interesting and fulfilling but for people that don't play games every often this game is almost impossible for them to beat and strait-up impossible for them to get to the "late game" which is very hard for even experienced players. Me as an example I would say that I am a competent gamer but after 32 hours I have only beat the game twice and gotten to one parallel world. The only other thing I would say makes the game less fun for some people is the problem of the lore of the game being La Mulania levels of cryptic and the problem of having to remembering the map layout and the positions of things without a map (or at least a good one) can put a real dampener on the experience, it almost makes me want a easy mode or something similar to be able to find the lore and have a bit more of a sandbox experience without resorting to mods. To sum it all up Noita is a interesting game with basically limitless potential for fun and it is very rewarding when you beat the game or get far into the game and complete self set challenges. On the other hand Noita can be a grueling experience with its difficulty and it has virtually no hand holding making newer players have a really hard time experiencing the fun parts about the game. To finish I feel that Noita deserves the score of "The amount of times I wondered 'is this going to kill me?' shortly before it kills me/ The amount of skittles I can eat in a hour before dying of hyperglycemia".

Nice and Chaotic, quite difficult, death is around every corner, and the secrets are very obscure.
Here are some examples to set the mood:
I once had a viable build that was about eating slime so I could turn my vomit into rats.
Most spells originate from the player, this includes spells like explosions, lets just say that the entity that got I got killed by the most so far is myself, by a wide margin.
There is a status effect called: "Tripping Balls" that proved a gameplay ""benefit""
There are more secret biomes than main biomes
Wand tinkering can become as complex as you want to make it, with concepts like wand wrapping, stacking modifiers, copying limited spells, ect.
A critical does not deal some simple x1.5 or x2 damage, its the full x5 damage
You can stunlock enemy's with freezing or electric damage, however they might also be able to stunlock you with freezing or electric damage, the funnyest outcome is when they make you stunlock yourself with electric damage though.

"Noita: Where I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Chaos"

Rating: ★★★★★ 5/5

Do you crave magical mayhem? Have you ever wanted to feel like an all-powerful wizard one moment, only to be doused by your own acid rain the next? Then buckle up, friends, because "Noita" has got you covered.

"Noita" is a roguelike that's less 'cuddly companion on a cozy journey' and more 'sadistic teacher chuckling in the corner as you repeatedly fail your alchemy finals'. Every pixel in this game is simulated, which at first sounded like a cool techy brag to me. But no, it's their way of saying, "We've meticulously crafted this world just so you can blow it up in the most spectacularly unexpected ways."

The environments in "Noita" aren't just for show, they're the bread and butter of your survival (and often the cause of your hilarious downfall). Get caught in a fire? Better find some water to dive into - unless, of course, you've just turned that water into a deadly pool of acid with a miscast spell. Oops!

Oh, and let's talk about the wands. These magical tools aren't your run-of-the-mill point-and-shoot affairs. No, they're customizable masterpieces waiting to blow up in your face. Want to mix bouncing bombs with chainsaws that spit lightning? Go ahead. Will you annihilate your enemies, or zap yourself into a roast wizard dinner? Only one way to find out!

The game is tough. And by tough, I mean I've had an easier time assembling IKEA furniture without the manual. Yet, each demise is a lesson (often in what NOT to do), and you'll find yourself coming back, eager to test your newfound wisdom.

The pixel graphics are charmingly simple, and the ambient music is fantastic, providing a soothing counterpoint to the countless times you'll scream, "That's not what I meant to do!" at your screen.

So, if you've ever wanted to feel like a powerful wizard and the world's biggest magical klutz all at once, "Noita" is your game. It's an unforgiving crash course in spellcasting survival, where the only predictable element is your unpredictably spectacular demise.

If this review tickled your funny bone or you can relate to my magical blunders, feel free to give it a thumbs-up. Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got to go die in a self-inflicted fire... again. Happy gaming!

It's hard to write up anything that wasn't said before in about a thousand reviews. So, Noita...

Rest assured that nothing in this game comes close to the destructive force of Minä - yourself. There is no hazardous material as potent, no enemy as difficult, no boss as disgustingly overtuned as your own personal flaws. It is quite liberating to know that no matter what the game throws at you, it can't ever be worse. Curious, but not cautious? Impatient? Just that one spell in an unpleasant area, but your HP bar says 200 - you can absolutely take this, right? Feeling tired? Missed a tap on your keyboard when switching wands, didn't check twice? You will fail so many runs it will not even be funny.

But failing also helps you learn, and honestly there is so much in Noita you can figure out. And the more you learn, the more you can appreciate all the little quirks and nods. The more alive the world feels after exploring it dozens of times over. Knowledge helps offset even the RNG when it comes to loot or enemy generation. You might even keep going against a run with horrible starting drops, just to test how far you go through perseverance - though spite is just as strong when it comes to motivation.

So take a plunge into forgotten depths of the soil. Clear a paradoxical jungle, far below where rays of the Sun can reach. Swim in gold, fly to the Moon and back, turn an enormous lake into liquid energy and drink it all. Find creatures and structures even the deities won't touch. Break through physical and mental barriers that exist to break [b]you[/b]. I strongly recommend at least trying this game out.

For those saying that this game is bad, you have a huge skill issue :)

Jokes aside, this is Noita. Noita is an extremely brutal and difficult roguelike that is kinda like Spelunky, but also not Spelunky in any way except for the part where you descend to multiple areas and biomes.

Story: Long story short, you're a wizard/mage in search for the treasure or artifact at the bottom the mountain and the orcs want to stop you or something like that.

Game: In this brutal roguelike, patience is key. If you're not a patient player, then you probably won't succeed very well in this game. This game is full of surprises. Even after beating the game, you'll still find more and more new things. For the patience aspect of this game, it's exploring and experimenting. There are multiple areas in the game, some hidden from the naked eye, some on the path to the bottom of the mountain. You can experiment with wands at the holy mountain and buy spells/wands there. They all have different results when you apply certain spells to certain wands, all wand stats being randomly generated. Rushing through the game to get to the end will result in your failure.

Enemies: You will find that everything wants to kill you in this game. From creatures, to orcs with machinery, to mages using spells. The game goes on even without you being in the area. Meaning that they fight among themselves.

Brutal gameplay: Every single pixel makes a difference in this game, making it brutal. Don't know what I mean by that? Take liquids for instance. You step on a pixel of acid. Just a small little pixel. Harmless, right? Nope. Even just one pixel of acid can stain and deal damage. This includes fire and other various liquids. But the pixels are not the only brutal crap. In fact, you can die to some really stupid bs. From electric shocks, to explosions, to some creatures causing electricity and the player getting absolutely stunned from it and most likely murdered, or being combo'd to death by melee.

Patience reward: There are other areas besides the mountain. If you can find a way to get to those said areas, you'll be rewarded, but you'll still be asking more questions mostly. Like "I got past the tree and found a new area. Never seen this before.", making you want to explore a lot more and experiment with the new areas. Some of the exploration CAN take time. A lot depending on where you're exploring. You're not just rewarded for exploring and taking the time to experiment. You are also rewarded for going slow down the mountain as there is no time limit. Some of the rewards include: Extra HP, wands, gold, survival, etc.

That is all I'm gonna say for this review. Highly recommend this great game. I'd appreciate any criticism or feedback in the comments. Kind of new to the whole reviewing thing, but I did my best.

Rating: ★★★★☆

Noita, the captivating and chaotic game developed by Nolla Games, is a mesmerizing experience that puts players in the shoes of a powerful sorcerer exploring a procedurally generated world. With its unique blend of spellcasting mechanics, emergent gameplay, and stunning pixel art, Noita offers a refreshingly unpredictable and endlessly entertaining adventure.

At the heart of Noita lies its spellcasting system, which allows players to combine different elements to create a vast array of spells. From launching explosive fireballs to summoning deadly acid rain, the possibilities are almost limitless. Experimentation is key, as each wand you discover holds the potential for new and surprising spell combinations. The joy of stumbling upon a powerful spell combination and wreaking havoc upon the world is unparalleled.

One of the game's standout features is its physics simulation, which permeates every aspect of gameplay. The environment is fully interactive, and each pixel has its own unique properties. Casting a fire spell can set nearby flammable objects ablaze, creating a chain reaction that can lead to catastrophic consequences. This dynamic environment adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay, making each playthrough feel unique and unpredictable.

Noita's pixel art style is nothing short of breathtaking. The game is a visual feast, with intricate details and stunning particle effects bringing the world to life. The environments are beautifully crafted, ranging from dark and treacherous caverns to vast, open underground lakes. The attention to detail in the pixel art is commendable, and the art style perfectly complements the game's chaotic nature.

The game's difficulty is worth mentioning, as Noita is not for the faint of heart. Permadeath is a constant companion, and every step forward can be met with danger at every turn. While this level of difficulty can be frustrating at times, it also adds to the thrill and sense of accomplishment when you finally overcome the challenges. The learning curve can be steep, but it rewards perseverance and experimentation.

However, despite its numerous strengths, Noita does have a few shortcomings. The lack of a clear overarching objective or narrative may deter some players who prefer a more structured experience. The game's reliance on procedural generation can also lead to occasional inconsistencies in level design, resulting in frustrating moments. Additionally, some may find the controls to be a bit clunky, especially when trying to navigate through tight spaces or during intense combat situations.

Noita is a game that thrives on the unexpected. Its spellcasting system, interactive environment, and beautiful pixel art create an immersive and addictive experience. While it may not appeal to everyone, those willing to embrace the chaos will find themselves engrossed in a world of magic and mayhem. If you have a penchant for exploration, experimentation, and the thrill of the unknown, Noita is a must-play game that will keep you coming back for more.

this game is fun, if you consider yourself a wizard or an enjoyer of physics simulations, i'd strongly recommend, there is a lot here to experiment with, every material in this game can be destroyed or converted to other material, you only need to find the right spell for it, every liquid is drinkable, water, toxic sludge, boiling acid, blood and piss, and each have their own effects on you and enemies. 

combat is frantic and dynamic. explosives can be detonated and structures dropped to do damage to foes, their attacks are also simulated projectiles that can be avoided, though they will attack from offscreen. lower levels increase the insanity, 

exploring will find you more powerful wands, otherwise you can modify the ones you have with speels acquired from shops inbetween stages. every wand has some slots to add spells to them so you can freely mix up your loadouts and see what works best, though you can only do this in the inbetween sections and not inside the dungeons so if you find your loadout is a bit crap, then your stuck with those wands that'll probably get you killed via an explosive chain reaction.

also i'm gonna say for exploration that it pays off to look around instead of just going down

This game is more frustration than fun. If you easily die from shooting at an enemy but you die because your firebolt is blocked by a single pixel, then it shouldnt be perma death. If the game requires you to practice deadly unknown spells and spell combos to find one that works then there should be a place you can do that where you can heal. If the game requires you to collect items to do those experiments then you should be able to cary more than 4. If the game relies on you manipulating the environment chemistry and physics to get an edge then it better be extremely accurate. The few times I got insanely lucky and got the perfect sequence of items to make super powerful weapons, I died the second I left the temple because a lamp got in the way. Theres just a lot of extremely annoying game mechanic clashes that ruin what would be amazing. Even with mods to try to fix them, overall this game just makes me have irritation, anger, and bad feels, and got no game progression from any of it.

This game is truly unique, and you won't find an experience like this anywhere else. 

The simulated physics serve as an amazing backdrop for some really neat experiences, and interacts with the spell crafting system wonderfully. The spell crafting itself is basically limitless, and there are always new ways to learn how to deal with enemies, or obliterate everything on the screen in one click, including yourself. 

This game is really hard, it's unfair, and you may die a (few) hundred times before getting a win, but some deaths are quick and you can just start right over, and learn from each one. And once you've finally won, you've still barely scratched the surface. 

Absolutely recommend it, just know that you will die. A lot. Mostly by your own hand.

Probably the only rouge-lit that I've found genuinely enjoyable and engaging. While I suck at rouge-lit games and Noita is certainly no exception, the game has more details and nuance and special conditions than a 3000page non-disclosure agreement. Noita is also made beautiful by its complexity, the effect is similar to Minecraft in-that parts of its beauty and atmosphere seem almost like a side-effect of the world generating algorithm.

 I've noticed people bitching about Noita because of all the horribly unfair outcomes you can run into and because you can't just beat Noita by being skilled. Winning in Noita requires a bit of luck, a bit of skill, a bit of patience, a bit of caution, a bit of intelligence, familiarity with the game's mechanics and features, as well as a willingness to experiment and explore in the face of lost progress. 

 Noita is fun and unique and i definitely recommend buying it

"A game where every pixel is simulated, and every death is getting oneshot by random BS you can't even see."

Good points:
- Great concept
- Pixel physics !
- Wand crafting
- Lots of content
- Map is huge and full of secrets
- Runs vey well (for the most part)
- Moddable
- Steam deck support (although playing with a controller is a no-no imo, see below)

Less good points:
- Ridiculously difficult, probably the most noob-unfriendly game I've ever played, makes Spelunky 2 look easy in comparison
- No tutorial, and everything is extremely cryptic,be prepared to read/watch hours of guides to understand anything
- You will keep getting killed by seemingly random things you can't even process for hours and hours
- You keep getting stuck in walls/floors/ceilings all the time, gets annoying quickly
- Some ennemy bullets are tiny and barely visible
- When you're new, it's often hard to tell the difference between the background and the actual level
- Forget about controller support, it's pretty much impossible to aim efficiently, you'll need mouse and keyboard if you want to have the slightest chance at making progress

Overall 8/10.

if you can't run it at full framerate, it does slow down, making it a bit annoying to play, but this can be avoided by capping the framerate in the file settings, of course, given the game doesn't let you mess with this in the first place, this does mess with the game in a couple ways.

(at 30 fps)
most physics objects move incredibly slowly, wand firing stats are about 2x less effective (refreshing firing, cast delay), and your flight goes barely anywhere, but its up to you whether those drawbacks are worse than playing the game in slow motion, if your computer can't handle it.

regardless of that! its a very enjoyable game with indepth wand crafting mechanics, and an expansive world to discover, which, hard as it is, i'd say you should go in blind, for the best experience.

hard to say too much without spoiling anything, so go for it.

UPDATE: if you're experiencing slowdown, you can also go into config.xml and change the two settings called "internal_size_h" (or _w) to change the resolution in fullscreen. this might let you get slightly higher fps than the default resolutions and avoid the physics and wand alterations by limiting it to 30, at the cost of messing up the menus and hud. i'm unsure of how to fix this yet.

Noita is truly brutal. A good run can last several hours and you can die in seconds. But I keep coming back to it because it can give you an experience that nothing else can. A sense of exploration of not merely the world, but the very mechanics of magic itself.

When you play Noita, you're not there to win, or even to survive. Hell, most of the time you will kill yourself with your own magic, but for every step you learn something new, which will motivate you to persist.

But the best aspect is the magic. It is made from a few hundret building blocks that are easy to understand. But then emergent behaviour begins to kick in, and the logic of it all comes together to become a topic that can be Studied. This is a childhood fantasy for me, where I can finally unleash the abhorred creation of magic upon the Denizens who have brought torturous days upon me. Where I can seek deep truths of the great work through countless hours of study and willingness to sacrifice even my life for knowledge. Where with a keen mind the rumoured barriers of you world can be broken.

An entertaining introduction is Noita, a roguelike for the mentally deranged.

The game is too hard even for me, so I use Spell Labs, Glowing Hearts and Wand Dbg from the Steam Workshop. For those who don't want to invest hundreds of hours in this game, Dead Isn't Dead is a good option.

I originally refunded this game around a year ago I think? Played it again because I felt like I didn't give it a chance earlier. After playing it again I remembered exactly why I refunded it, but it's mostly the game not being suited for me not because its a bad game. So let me break it down for you:

There are too many secrets to get that it would take so long to get them even with guides. The game also dosen't have a real tutorial behind it, they just expect you to learn most things by yourself (like small annoying things, my example being how add triggers work) The areas get significantly harder really fast while it gets harder and harder to get money since the enemies are way harder to kill.

The game is basically alot to unpack with no real indication of what to do, basically trial and error until end of time and I just can't see myself learning it. Not to discourage you, it's defenetley worth atleast one shot because I believe it could be a really enjoyable game for some people, like mentioned earlier.

I think this is a game that you have to take in some ways at face value.
Noita is a hardcore roguelike that the only progression is skill (I think). 
It is devastatingly beautiful, frustrating, rng heavy, precise, Power fantasy ridden journey.

There is no tutorial, no handholding, barely any direction, so you have to decide to figure the game out.

That is a tall ask for some, but I am taking the time to do it for the first time since I heard about this game years ago. 
It feels like taking a college course except every time you enter the classroom, The teacher is screaming, Theres 3 mutants and a floating firehead, acid is raining from the ceiling, and there is a pop quiz every day that kills you if you dont pass. 
So yes, I think you should take the time to power through the initial learning curve, because Noita is an incredible undertaking, with depth, fun, and one of the best OP player gameplay.

Absolutely fantastic roguelite, but very unforgiving. It has a relatively low learning curve to get started, but the depth of the wand and alchemy systems are incredibly complex. 500+ hours in and still feel like I only have scratched the surface of what's possible.

Emphasis on very unforgiving - you will not likely enjoy this if you're easily frustrated at failure, but if you want something with a high skill cap, unique skill system, and hundreds of hours of content, Noita is a good choice.

Almost everyday for the past month I've been playing this soul sucking game. I first got it because it looked fun. Wow! The mechanics are so interesting! Wow! There's so much story to be told in this game! Wow! You can do anything you want!!! 
I get on, start a new game, I enter the cave, i die, restart. I enter the cave, i die, restart. I enter the cave, i die, restart. I enter the cave, I die, log out, pound out all my frustrations and cry myself to sleep. The next day, i get on once more.
What this game does to the mind is a marvel to be behold. The way it pulls you in and keeps you in its tight grip. There is no escape when you're hooked. You feel it infecting your mind and getting tighter the more you struggle, and struggle you will. I've never gotten more competitive with myself in any other game but this one. This hellish rougelike. Always making me restart in quick succession like the wands I've made with the little hours I've played.
It very much is a skill issue. "i shouldn't have done this" "maybe if i had avoid that" "i should've blown up that canister when i saw it" "i should've known gigasaw would've merc'd me like everything else" "had i been faster with the tele i would've escaped"
The above thoughts are what happens every time i restart. only masochists of the highest degree get this game.

Among my favorite games. It's a masterclass. A review won't do it justice.
Cliff notes:
- Soundtrack 10/10 "It's my favorite new album, and it comes with a great game too!"
- Fully destructible world with material reactions and effects is amazing. Incredible game engine.
- Massive world to explore, many bosses, and fabulous prizes.
- Wand crafting is fantastic. I'm still learning new, fun builds at 1600 hours played.
- I love the tablet. Fun skillshots, so handy. My favorite thing to do now is just clear the Mines with mainly the tablet. And invis+tablet is a fun run.
- Kicking is good fun too.
- High skill cap. I was reminded, things like the tablet and kicking are a lot of fun once you hone the skill.
Seeing how well you can do compared to how bad you were is pretty cool.

- Great lore. Great game design that accentuates the lore. Knowledge is a boon (and a curse).
- Huge reward for knowledge of the game, especially hidden mechanics.
- Even the replay gif maker is awesome. So many good highlights.

If pixel graphics and a 2D platformer is your jam, Noita gets my biggest recommendation. There's so many ways you can play it. Messing with Fungal Shifts, win streaking, achievement runs, long runs with big power, or whatever else you want to do.

The game is good for the first hours, you get to love tinkering with wands, discovering the secrets and trying to get the achivments et all (not spoiling).

Noita has so many fun bits to it, from the "sand game" physics & alchemy reactions to the incredibly in-depth wand crafting. But Noita fundamentally has no respect for the player's time, even by rogue-like standards. Seriously fun! Combines the chaos and difficulty of roguelites and feel of a game like Terraria. Some runs are absolutely miserable and you just get sent straight back to the beginning area, but sometimes, when you're very lucky you get a special treat of a run and make it deep into Noita.

EDIT: 
I made my initial review after ~9 hours, and now I'm at ~360 and this game has only gotten better and better since then. In my mind, it's up there with The Binding of Isaac as one of the best roguelites available and one of my favorite games of all time. If you end up picking up the game, don't give up. Don't be afraid to look at guides or get help from the Noita community because the game is an absolute meat-grinder until you've gotten Noita'd so many times that you start to figure out the ins and outs of the game. Go young wizard, build some wands and mix some potions and you'll probably end up loving this game.

It took me nearly 150 hours -- nearly 1000 deaths, ~80% of them self-inflicted -- before winning my first run of Noita, and I still keep coming back to it almost every day. It is without exaggeration the most uncompromising roguelike game I've ever played, but its deceivingly complex spell and material dynamics make it feel almost limitless in scope and potential;  it's truly no wonder why folks will commit thousands of hours to it. You will inevitably make many fatal mistakes, given that the game does not hold your hand *in the slightest*, but learning from them is the ultimate key to its mastery. Experiencing this game has only been made even more special through the blossoming of a generous and curious community of players and modders, all who continue to share secrets and new discoveries hidden in its cryptic, dangerous, and ever-shifting world.

Additional notes: it is a good rogue like, some weird mix of Spelunky meets Terraria meets... any good procedural rogue like where you need to go deeper each time to get to the next level, while having breaks between each level to refill, buy stuff, etc. Design is smart and rich, art is colorul pixels everywhere... Good stuff. Sadly, the downside for me is the difficulty. My god this game is unforgiving. If you don't like dying because of a stupid unlucky conjunction of tough enemies, deadly poisonous/lava environment, lethal traps, and recharging/out of ammo weapons... and if you don't like the idea of "well, I progressed that far, but now I have to start it all over again and anyway it will be a new procedurally generated level"... then you will end up like me, agreeing on the quality of the game all the while disagreeing with the harsh reset > repeat nature of it and wasting too much time on it... I can't do this anymore sadly. So, it might be a B or even a A from me if I was 15 again and had all my life ahead of me, OR if there was a coop mode that gave me more incentive to push and try more... If you have the time, enjoy. If not, still an okay game to try for a while.

After 31 Hours I've finally beat this game after completely obsessing over it. This is the most unbalanced, chaotic and awe-inspiring game I've ever played. The amount of times I had a good run going, all for it to be swept out from under me when a worm destroys the holy mountain and angers the gods, or gotten one-shot by an ukko, or been polymorphed into a sheep and oneshot by a basic attack. The most upsetting experience ever, but after my last run, a run where i felt like an unstoppable god ploughing through hordes of enemies lagging my game by blowing everything up, and the lingering excitement as I author this review, I cannot recommend this game enough. It is fundamentally different to any other game I've played. There's just SO much happening, the latent parallel dimensions and mythological implications instantly make me impatient to start another run. To explore another universe, and to ascend. Its like a power fantasy just out of reach every play through. So good.

With the experience this game creates, I have to recommend though be warned, this game is sandbox through and through. Although there is an 'end' goal, there is more than enough to experiment and play with, just be warned the environment and even spells can be deadly. It is one of those games that rewards you for having game knowledge but is very punishing with the physics/magic simulation at times. It is the appeal of the game, though often time very unforgiving.

wand building is a lot of fun, but after eventually youll find that the majority of the standard projectile spells are mostly useless outside of extremely specific spell combo builds. at times you could go a dozen or so runs without getting any decent spells/wands (though that is just how roguelite games tend to be, so im not counting that against the game). 

after youve learned how spell wrapping works, it can be hard to break the habit of just defaulting to the same busted wand build every time you get the spells available for it. but this is supplemented by the occasional wand you find with a spell built into it thats cast each time for free. sometimes this can give you infinite, high level spells (like Giant Magic Missile) earlier than they would appear normally on wands in the wild. so the randomness does help prevent gameplay from getting stale too quickly

music is *PLATINUM* tier. excellent instrument choice and the drums in every piece are top notch. if you play with no sound/music muted, youre missing out BIG TIME

enemy and environment design are also wonderful. once you master projectile timing, paths, and enemy behaviors, the bullet hell aspect of the game can be a lot of fun. especially if you were lucky enough to get some fun wand combinations in your arsenal. 

after the 3rd level, the difficulty does shoot up a bit more than i think most newcomers will expect. but once you overcome that difficulty spike, its very satisfying to beat each level, even if the one after ends your run when you get to it for the first time

I like this game a lot, and i never get tired of it - when you get bored of going down the mines, you can explore outside, when you get bored of that, try downloading a mod or two to spice up your game play, if your even tired of that, why not challenge yourself and try a no - hit run (where you beat the game without being hit).
I really don't think I'm going to uninstall this game. ever.

Fantastic game. I already have 200ish hours and I'm still learning new stuff. The wand building is super fun and rewarding when you get it right. (also funny when it outright kills you). If you like a steep learning curve this game is for you. Very good 9/10 also i love hamis.

Let's make this clear: If you go into this game expecting a Terraria-like rougelike you will probably be disappointed.

This game will not hold your hand [b] at all [/b] which is both its strength and its weakness. Noita offers a surprisingly deep gameplay and lore if you are willing to explore it but that's the thing: You have to accept that it's entirely up to you to push yourself forward in this game.

I relly enjoy the game and especially the wand building mechanincs, but for a new player I would reccomend checking at least a few tips and tricks videos on YouTube or in the Steam Workshop just to understand some things that might be frustrating. Don't worry too much about spoiling some things. This game is deep enough that you will have plenty to explore even though you get some things explained to you before you found or learned them yourself.

If you want a unforgiving exploration game in a rougelike package with an extremely deep and flexible weapon mechanic this game is for you. If the feeling that the world is centered around you is important for you in a game, I wouldn't go near Noita.

Crazy. Chaotic. Explosive. Inscrutable. Deep - so very deep. Full of secrets. Tremendously rewarding of experimentation.

In Noita's simulated pixel perfection, explosions tear holes in the environment very satisfyingly. Fire spreads, liquids flow and spill, heavy rocks fall and crush. Noita feels like a unique experience and development achievement purely on the basis of the depth of its environment simulation. And when you add in a magic spell and wand construction system that is equally deep, surprisingly complex, and incredibly rewarding - you find an unending variety of gameplay. That's not even mentioning magical potions, hidden secrets, a sprawling world(s) map, and lore and objectives that even after 600 hours I'm still uncovering.

If I had to level a criticism at the game, it would be that it is brutally unforgiving. Most play sessions end abruptly with the player's violent death. But it feels like the majority of the time that's due to of having severely underestimated the destructive power of a newly-created wand, so it's probably not fair to complain.

I have 'completed' the game once only. But I later found out that what I did, despite telling me I'd won, was only the first and shortest of the possible paths you can take.

By far the best Roguelike I have ever played. Incredibly addicting and I adore the fact that a run is exactly as long as you could want it to be. Either 30 minutes or several months long (though the latter gets problematic because of the data saved, so environmental glitches such as some areas missing do occur. Luckily, these areas are seemingly always optional and of low-importance, so it's not much of an issue). 

Noita allows you to make and customize your own weapons in a menu that is very easy to understand. 
It has a colossal variety of different spells that can be combined in an incalculable amount of ways. Even the weakest spells have special traits that could be incredibly useful depending on what you find. Noita rewards exploration, caution and, in general, knowledge of how things work and what does what. Experimenting is incredibly entertaining. Especially when you find a nice combination of spells. 

The difficult tag is no lie for sure. Everything in Noita is skill-based to the players level. There is nothing useful you can bring into different runs other than what you learnt (which is most often something you died to). It can be frustrating at times, but I am always drawn back to it because of the freedom in how you decide the game to be played. Every time I play it I always find some new interesting thing.

One really fun thing in the game is setting stuff on fire, or creating enormous explosions, as the engine allows it to be very accurate and incredibly beautiful. But the best moments are when you kill a powerful enemy with a freshly modified wand.

Noita is a 2D pixel physics based particle effect simulator programmed via a deck-building card game with rules that become increasingly bizarre to the point of insanity. (There's also a Roguelike in there too). Relentless, unapologetic difficulty and a seemingly infinite set of edge cases between the physics effects, magic effects, AI behaviours, etc., means that while you will die - a lot - it probably won't be in quite the same way twice. 11/10 highly recommended to anyone that likes fun.
