Probably one of the greatest roguelikes ever made. It can have a bit of a learning curve but the game's systems almost let you do anything. Really is amazing how most things don't seem off limits. You can quite literally become a god in the world of the game, but funnily enough still die pretty easily. It's a nice fun and challenging game that even allows you to go at your own pace between zones. There is no time limit or anything like that when you are playing and progressing. And the main "gimmick" of simulated pixels is amazing. Different interactions fluids and solids (and even gasses) have is fun to see. Either way just get this game it is great and as I said probably one of the greatest roguelikes ever made.

So, I´ve played about 80 hours or so now, and I've just recently got my first win after 130 games played! Stranger yet, I played two more games after that, one ended in tears, and the other, was my second victory! Both the victories were earned by playing the game the long way, exploring and fighting my way through everything the areas had to offer, getting the best wands, all the health boosts and the best items, combining my ingenious killer wands, energy spheres bursting into 900 damage worth of scrap projectiles and rapidfiring precision lasers and whatnot, but the real noteworthy experience was the confidence-fueled game between those two wins, where tangled up in my crafty bullshit I misplaced two adjacent spells in the wrong order.  My wand of supreme domination, that which was equipped with a trigger spitter bolt meant to lob my hollow egg loaded up with six omnidirectionally aimed lightning bolts had become inverted, where my egg now contained the spitter bolt, that would then at the end of its lifespan, deliver the spicy payload. It just so happens that the eggs are subject to gravity, but the spitter bolts, not so much. So freshly out of the holy mountain, I go down to the hiisi-base, aim to fire my spitter bolt through a gap in the steel and the snow, and whoop, what do you know, out comes an egg that just so barely scrapes the edge of the snow, cracks open, and hurls the spitter bolt of Ragnarok right at my now frozen pale likeness, proceeds to unfold and electrocutes me for 200 damage. Stunned, I fall into a pool of polymorphine, where I then reduced from god to sheep, get domed by a lone kranuhiisi and am promptly sent outdoors to get my daily exercise like I was supposed to, anyway.

Stellar game, properly addicted, full of everything. Not necessarily the easiest to get into, but a load of fun when you start figuring it out.

This is some genuinely creative game design. The game gave me a sense of excitement and mystery that i haven't had in a long time. This game's spell system is totally unique to my knowledge. It lets you create complex spells and spell interactions in a super simple and intuitive way. The randomly generated world is a voxel environment that fully interacts with the physics system, and in doing so it adds a whole other level of mad science in terms of how you can use a given spell interaction to your benefit in combat.

Noita presents real innovation in both technical execution and game design. 

I do think the game would really benefit from some quality of life changes. Its a bummer to have the stat tracking disabled when you install mods to do some  easy things that really should probably be part of the vanilla experience.

Overall: 9/10

I highly recommend Noita.

Picture if you will - A relationship with a person who may not look the best, but can do incredible things to you. The kind of things that are spoken about as legend in high school locker rooms - except they are real, and this one can do them... Around every corner a new adventure, in every crack or crevice a new experience to tickle your senses.

Except, while they tease you with them constantly, and you may have a very clear way to them, they are incredibly fickle, and often throw not only a wrench in the works, but a whole damn tool box - sometimes both metaphorically and literally. They will bring you close to the peak of absolute ecstasy given half a chance, just to kick you square in the genitals with a steel toed boot, and laugh about it over your weeping broken form.

Or I guess to some degree you could just compare the game to hard narcotics. Might feel great for a little while, but it is going to fuck you up harder than life its self at some point whether you like it or not. There is no good end until you stop.

I think the three things that describe this game best are player agency (or RNG lack thereof), chaos, and the looming threat of death (no matter how godlike you become). But the order of those three varies from run to run.

The game can be exceptionally frustrating, and some design choices are questionable, but it is legitimately one of the most interesting games ever made. If you take an experimental approach after you get the hang of it, instead of a point A to point B style, and accept that you are going to get randomly murdered by unavoidable deaths sometimes, you will get more out of your play time.

I have spent two weeks collecting the True Knowledge of this world but my work thirsts for more. I have angered the Gods and slain their sentinel to empower myself in parallel worlds and take Corrupted Knowledge. I studied the long-since dead Alchemists and harnessed forbidden understanding of this world that terrified even them. The old have been devoured for the new to take their place, resting in the Skies and Hell itself. I have struck corruption into the heart of the infinite Hellscapes, and united the Dark Sun to the skies above, tearing the land between to shreds. I fear nothing. The High Alchemist, whose path I have followed, has been killed in many realities. The Leviathan is dead, taking the pure water of the world with it to the grave. The many witnesses and minions of Kolmisilma have been killed, as the great one awaits below for the very same fate. I look at the Lava that once threatened me and drink it to satiate my power. I bask in the burning glory of the two suns I forged without care, for even they serve no threat to me. The gods I once enraged are since afraid of me, and shall I find them, they too shall suffer a fate they designed themselves. However, in such glory I shall always live in fear of the ever-looming possibility that, at any moment, I could transform into a sheep.

I wish you could give a positive and negative review at the same time, because this game is a masterpiece and unplayable at the same time. Sometimes you can blow up the entire level, and sometimes you get instakilled by a stealth propane tank. Sometimes you're solving huge mysteries that unfold into a game around ten times bigger than what you think you're getting, and sometimes you're walking for 10 minutes through a completely empty desert just to get a little more health. Sometimes you're using the game's ridiculously deep wandbuilding system to create a wand from hell that does 5 *quintillion* damage per second (yes, and without any glitches), and sometimes you're crawling through midgame levels with your starter wand because you never found any good wands.

This is a game only for people who are mentally prepared for it. If you like putting yourself through pain to succeed, you'll love this game. Even if you don't, you might still like it. You can tune the game to your liking if you're not so masochistic. Unless you eat nails for breakfast, I'd recommend playing with the "Peace With Gods" mod, to avoid getting endgame enemies shoved in your face on the first floor to punish you for something you didn't even do (damn worms). Just don't be one of those people who uses seed tool to find their lively concoction and alchemic precursor recipes and acts like it's not cheating. Most people won't be able to solve most of the game's puzzles alone, but playing this game with no guide is an experience you can't get from anything else these days. This game is like what you thought videogames were when you were a kid, like using strength on the truck to find Mew.

Final review: Sit against a wall as long as you can. If you physically fell over instead of giving up from pain, buy this game.

The best rogue-like I've played since Binding of Isaac, albeit this is a far different beast.  As fun as it is brutally difficult.  The environmental interactions are outstanding.  The creativity demanded upon the player to tweak the wands with what he has available, and what he's capable of purchasing, can lead to interesting results (usually disastrous when you tinker with something knew, but it's something to be learned for the next go around).

Haven't beaten this game yet, and neither has 90% of those who have played this as of this writing (according to the Steam achievement stats).  You will die a lot, but you will keep coming back for more.

The game starts to come alive once you get to the Holy Mountain, learn how you can customize your wands, learn about perks, and then start to figure out exactly how to make them efficient.  There is always a way to make something useful with the hand you're dealt, you just need to think of the right combinations.  From making a wand acting as a machine gun blasting a dozen bolts per second, or something that makes a concentrated but powerful sniper blast every couple seconds, or something that's inaccurate as hell but is firing projectiles all around you as if you're protected by a cloud of magic balls.

Noita was inspired by an old game called The Falling Sand Game/The Powder Toy that many people first played at school. While that game was fun, it would be more apt to describe it as a pixel-based material simulator. Noita is what happens when you take that simulator and craft a fully fledged gaming experience around it. The game leans heavily into mystery, combat, exploration, and material interactions for it's main experience. It's a roguelike, meaning the world is randomly generated in a somewhat predictable manner, and that failing and trying again is to be expected. Noita manages to cultivate a feeling of danger and discovery behind every corner, thanks in no small part to it's excellent art direction and sound design. Every mechanic of the game is fashioned to make floating through unexplored areas as engaging and dynamic as possible. You'll fight new enemies, craft and fire spells, traverse varied landscapes, and discover secrets and treasure on a scale both large and small.
Love the textures, love the spells, love everything.

There is a common fantasy trope of "the arcane arts" holding great power, but also extreme danger if used carelessly. A lot of games incorporate this idea as lore, but few manage to do so as a mechanic.

Noita will make you feel like a worm, completely helpless and at the whims of the simulated forces around you.
Then, after many failures, it will make you feel like a god, mastering those same forces to your benefit.
And when hubris overtakes you, it will cruelly remind you of your place.

The end result is a wise old Minä, with the knowledge to change the world around them to their whims, but the wisdom to only do so very carefully. This is how wizards are always portrayed, but this game makes it *genuine*.

It pains me to write this review, because deep down I know I like this game, but I can't say I recommend it. A lot of Rogue-like games are some of my favorites of all time because they're easy to pick up, but incredibly tough to master, Noita on the other hand tells you nothing at all, no tutorial or anything. At first glance that might seem like a smart approach, after all plenty of games have players learn with experience, but this is way too complicated for players to easily learn. I've had to look up stuff WAY MORE than I had to with any other game, especially wandbuilding tutorials, which is something that the game should teach you itself considering it's your main source of damage. Combined with how unforgiving the game is and the presence of Spelunky's "Sometimes the game just decides you die" gimmick, with 30 hours behind me, I still haven't escaped the part of every Rogue-like's playthrough where the game feels frustrating to play. This kinda sucks, because as I look online, I see how satisfying successful wandbuilding can be, how fun the world is to explore, how many secrets there are to uncover, but the game requires you to master mechanics that it never teaches you before you can even do any of this. There was a moment, in one of my recent runs, where I realised that not only did I not know what I was doing, but that I was also not having fun and that absolutely saddens me, because this definitely looked like a game I'd enjoy and grind out. The music is really good, the artstyle and physics are very satisfying, the controls are fluid... I know for certain that if you can overcome the learning that I wasn't able to wrap my head around, you can find one of the most rewarding games of the genre.
Please buy this game if you want happiness in your life.

If you were wondering if the incredibly cool particle physics and modeling or if the gimmick would wind up being a hinderance to the game part of this video game, I'm sad to say that it's more the latter. I died several times because my wizard magnetized to the 2 pixels of dirt left from an explosion when trying to fly up. Otherwise, the different particles are basically different ways to have something catch on fire. Sometimes this means you'll just burn to death, sometimes it means poison vapor will kill you, sometimes it means oil will explode. Often times these things will happen regardless of your own actions. Ultimately the RNG in this game isn't just with the procedural map generation and enemy placement, but whether or not you get any kind of functional wand, potion, or perks. Runs will come to a dead stop because the game decided this one, this one you just don't get to win. It's why all these reviews talk about death. That might be good in Dark Souls where the game is complex and fun, not so much when everything is just random. Because you have so little control, it encourages hyper conservative gameplay that I just don't have the patience for given how boring the Terreria-esque combat stays. That might be different for you, and if it is check out the game. Otherwise I would try something any of the several action rogue-likes out there with better balance.

If you came here for a review of this game you Will be let down but if you came for a good pie recipe you came to the right place

Step 1
Make the custard: In a medium saucepan, whisk together egg yolks and sugar until well combined. Whisk in cornstarch and salt. In a slow, steady stream, whisk in milk and then the cream. Add butter. Cook mixture over medium-low heat, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon, just until it starts to thicken. Immediately whisk mixture until smooth, then continue to cook and stir custard until it has come to a very low boil for 2 minutes, about 6 to 8 minutes total. Strain custard through a fine mesh sieve into a small bowl, pushing it through with a small spatula. Stir in vanilla. Cover with plastic wrap, pressing the plastic directly onto the surface. Chill for at least 3 hours and up to 24 hours.

Step 2
Prepare the cake: Heat oven to 325 degrees. Butter a 9-by-2-inch round baking pan, generously greasing the sides, and line it with parchment paper. Butter parchment paper. In a medium bowl, whisk together flour, baking powder and salt.

Step 3
In a small saucepan, bring the milk and butter to a simmer over medium heat. When the butter is melted, remove pan from heat. In a large bowl, beat eggs and sugar with an electric mixer until pale and thick, about 4 to 6 minutes. With the mixer running on low, add the milk mixture and beat until combined. Then add flour mixture and vanilla and beat until combined.

Step 4
Transfer batter to the prepared pan and smooth the top. Bake until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean, 30 to 35 minutes.

Step 5
Transfer to a rack and let cool 10 minutes. With a very thin knife, cut around the edge to release the cake from the side of the pan. Carefully flip the cake onto the rack, then turn it right-side-up to cool completely.

Step 6
Assemble the cake: Using a serrated knife, carefully cut the cake into two layers and place the bottom layer on a serving plate. Stir custard, and spread it onto the cut side of the bottom half. Replace the top half of the cake, cut side down.

Step 7
Prepare the glaze: In a small saucepan over medium-low, heat the cream to a simmer. Remove the pot from the heat and pour cream over the chocolate chips, oil, salt and let stand for 3 minutes. Whisk until smooth. Spread the glaze evenly over the top of the cake.

INGREDIENTS
Yield: 10 servings

For the Custard
3 large egg yolks 
½ cup/100 grams granulated sugar 
2 tablespoons cornstarch 
Pinch kosher salt 
1 cup/240 milliliters whole milk 
¼ cup/60 milliliters heavy cream 
1 tablespoon/14 grams unsalted butter 
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 

For the Cake
8 tablespoons/114 grams (1 stick) unsalted butter, cut into pieces, plus more for the pan 
1¾ cups/224 grams all-purpose flour 
1¾ teaspoons baking powder 
¾ teaspoon kosher salt 
¾ cup/180 milliliters whole milk 
3 large eggs, at room temperature 
1 cup/200 grams granulated sugar 
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 

For the Glaze
¼ cup/60 milliliters heavy cream 
4 ounces/113 grams semisweet chocolate chips 
1 teaspoon neutral oil, such as safflower 
Pinch kosher salt

11/10

Put a few more hours in to the game to see if my review was too harsh. It was not. This is by far the worst game I have ever played.
The good- building powerful wands can be fun
The bad- everything else. Enemies with blood that hurts you spraying blood everywhere on screen because all the starting wands do slice damage and if a single drop of that blood hits you, and you don't have water handy, you're going to be taking damage for a good five minutes. Those same enemies often spawn blood where they were killed, several seconds after dying and falling away from that spot. Every starting wand takes multiple hits to kill enemies that are fast, perfectly accurate, and can kill you in one to two hits. Healing is only available when you don't need it, unless you get super extremely lucky with spells you find. Any spell that can kill enemies in less than five hits will also do massive damage to you, usually killing you instantly. Some spells that are absolutely useless for anything but digging can take an hour to dig through a single pixel. Enemies can juggle you in the air, chain stunning you until you die. Gold can spawn far above enemies if they're close to a ceiling, making it unobtainable. Worms can dig through the safe areas and spawn a super powerful mini-boss type of enemy right after the first stage, and this isn't an uncommon occurrence. Some spells can cause you damage without even using the wand, they just damage you passively by holding the wand in certain situations, often killing you in milliseconds. There are a ton of secrets in the game, that require hours of research outside of game to even figure out the first steps for. I don't buy a game because I want to spend hours not playing the game just to start playing it. 

This game could be amazing, if it wasn't focused on difficulty over challenge. As it is, it's just another in a long line of games that think pissing people off means the game is good. One in five hundred runs, you're going to find a wand and spells worth using. Basically if you buy this game, you're paying for one minute of fun for every ten days of frustration. If this game was free it wouldn't be worth the price.
Noita 👍

Rogue-like side scroller in world where every pixel is animated. Oil can pour and pool, makes you slide round, can burn and billow smoke. Water can freeze over. trapping you in ice, while ice can be fracture into chunks. Electricity can arc through water and metal objects. And everything can kill you, from the terrain to the enemies. If the RNG gods are feeling happy fight back with customisable wands and perks, or die trying. 10/10

If you're motivated by getting creative and wondering "I wonder what this does?", then laughing when it completely backfires in the most unexpected way... Then Noita is for you. I'd actually avoid reading much more about it and just go in as blind as possible if you already sound interested.

It isn't fair a lot of the time, it'll punish you with insta-death in some cases. But most deaths in the game are there to teach you just a bit more about how magic works in this game (and therefore, how YOU can use it to your advantage). This game does a fantastic job of making magic really feel like you're actually playing with forces beyond your capability. But what becomes intoxicating is when you really start to learn how to use it to turn yourself into a literal god.

The game's full of secrets, surprises and dials to tweak and I highly recommend it.
